post.Title: Nabisunsa Girls' School and Mariam High School Set for Thrilling Lacrosse National Ball Games II Finale
post.Content:
In a historic showdown, Nabisunsa Girls' School and Mariam High School are preparing to face off in the much-anticipated final of the Lacrosse National Ball Games II. Nabisunsa Girls' School, competing in their maiden edition, aims to etch their name in the history books by clinching the national championship. However, they will face fierce competition from a determined Mariam High School team.

Nabisunsa Girls' School boasts an impressive attacking lineup, led by Tushemerirwe Ruth Tracy, a prominent member of the Uganda Lacrosse national team. Tracy's ability to score from various angles has been pivotal to her team's success throughout the tournament. Alongside her, Captain Mutayisa Clarissa, Aguti Precious, Mulumba Lady Shima, and goal tender Bafumba Geraldine have played crucial roles in guiding Nabisunsa to the final.

Mariam High School, on the other hand, will rely on the dynamic Nakibuli Jovia, who has emerged as the top scorer for the team based in Kisaasi. With her sights set on making this championship her own, Nakibuli aims to lead her team to victory in a bid to secure the coveted title.

The final day of the tournament will kick off with the bronze medal match between St. Mary's High School Ziroobwe and Lowell Girls' School. Lowell Girls' School has been a remarkable surprise package throughout the championship, posing a challenge to all the competing teams. Both schools will battle it out for a place on the podium, showcasing their skills and determination to finish the tournament on a high note.

The Lacrosse National Ball Games II has provided thrilling matches and showcased immense talent among the participating teams. The final promises to be a captivating contest, as Nabisunsa Girls' School and Mariam High School go head-to-head in pursuit of the championship trophy. Supporters and lacrosse enthusiasts are eagerly awaiting the outcome, ready to witness an exhilarating clash between these two formidable teams.

As the tournament nears its conclusion, the spirit of sportsmanship, teamwork, and determination has been on full display. The Lacrosse National Ball Games II have not only provided a platform for competition but also fostered camaraderie and passion for the sport among the players.

The stage is set for an unforgettable finale, as Nabisunsa Girls' School and Mariam High School prepare to battle it out on the lacrosse field. The teams are geared up and ready to leave everything on the field, vying for victory and the honor of being crowned champions of the Lacrosse National Ball Games II.

post.Title: Thrilling Volleyball Matches Unfold at Ball Games II National Championships on Match Day 5
post.Content:
By Jordana and Aaron (USSSA Media class students)

Kabale University, July 14 - The volleyball games at the Ball Games II National Championships, hosted by St. Mary's College Rushoroza, continued with great enthusiasm on Friday, July 14. Several schools participated in the matches, as they wrapped up their group stage games in a bid to advance further in the competition.

In the girls' category, teams such as St. Mary's Zirobwe, Nabisunsa Girls' Secondary School, Amizima Schools, Mariam High School, SMACO RUSH, and many others showcased their skills on the volleyball court. The intensity was palpable as the girls fought hard to secure victory for their respective schools.

Among the girls' games played, St. Mary's Zirobwe defeated St. Mark College Namagoma with a score of 2-0, demonstrating their prowess on the court. KYEBAMBE Girls' School dominated their match against Kanyum Comprehensive, securing a convincing 2-0 victory. Mariam High School displayed their strength by defeating Amizima School with a similar scoreline of 2-0.

The matches were fiercely contested, with Nyamirima Secondary School narrowly emerging victorious over Trinity College NABINGO with a score of 2-1. St. Catherine Girls' School claimed a well-deserved 2-0 victory against St. Mary Magdalene, showcasing their skills and teamwork. St. Elizabeth Girls' School dominated their match against Namugongo, securing a confident 2-0 win.

In another exciting encounter, Kisaana Secondary School faced off against Nyondo SS Mbale, with the latter emerging as winners with a score of 2-1.

Moving on to the boys' category, St. Augustine emerged triumphant with a commanding 2-0 victory over Nyamirima Village. MUBENDE Army showcased their strength by defeating SMACO RUSH with a convincing scoreline of 2-0. Masaka SS displayed their dominance on the court, overpowering Kilembe Secondary School with a resounding 2-0 win.

STAHIZA demonstrated their skills and determination, securing a 2-0 victory over MENGO SS. The match between Kibuli Secondary School and Bombo Army was closely contested, with the latter emerging as winners with a score of 2-1. Mbarara High School exhibited their superiority, defeating Trinity Catholic School 2-0.

Ntare Secondary School displayed their exceptional skills, claiming a 2-0 victory over San-Givanni School. Hilton High School put up a stellar performance, defeating Mbale SS with a confident 2-0 win.

The day was filled with thrilling matches, with some notable games standing out, such as STAHIZA versus MENGO SS and St. Elizabeth Girls' School against Namugongo, which showcased exceptional skills and competitiveness.

With the conclusion of the day's matches, participants and spectators eagerly look forward to the upcoming games, expecting more captivating displays of talent, teamwork, and sportsmanship. The Ball Games II National Championships continue to captivate and excite as schools compete for glory and the chance to be crowned champions in their respective categories.

post.Title: Building Bridges: Africa Continental President of ISF and Uganda School Sports President Discuss Advancements in School Sports at CAF Congress
post.Content:
On the sidelines of the CAF congress here in Abidjan, the Africa Continental President of the International School Sports Federation (ISF) and Director General of OISSU (Ivorian Office Of School and University Sport), Mamadou Souleymane Kone, hosted a fruitful meeting with Justus Mugisha. The guest, the President of USSSA, FEASSSA, who is also the 1st Vice President FUFA, expressed gratitude for the opportunity to engage in discussions regarding ISF, the Federation of Africa School Sports Federation (FASS), and the structure and implementation of school sports in Cote D'Ivoire.

During the meeting, titled "Building Bridges: Mamadou Souleymane Kone and Justus Mugisha Discussed Advancements in School Sports at CAF Congress," the two sports leaders exchanged insights and experiences, with a focus on enhancing the development of school sports in Africa. The knowledge gained from this exchange will undoubtedly contribute to the Justus's role at ISF, FASS, and within the USSSA system.

One key area of discussion was the establishment of fully-fledged School Sports Federations in each country, aiming to provide a platform for organized sports competitions and events at the national level. Additionally, they explored the idea of introducing zonal school sports competitions in the five regions of Africa. Such regional competitions would not only foster healthy competition but also serve as a means of talent identification and promotion.

Another significant topic was the vision for FASS to operate independently and autonomously in implementing its activities, particularly in organizing competitions at the continental level. This aspiration aligns with the objective of creating a robust and self-sustaining structure for school sports across Africa, thereby ensuring the continuous growth and success of the movement.

Expressing gratitude to his host, Justus Mugisha acknowledged Mamadou Souleymane Kone as a brother, friend, and comrade. The meeting served as an important platform for collaboration and mutual learning, laying the foundation for future cooperation in advancing school sports in Africa.

As Mugisha returns to Uganda, armed with newfound knowledge and experiences, the expectation is that his involvement with ISF, FASS, and FUFA will be further strengthened. With a shared vision for the development of school sports, it is anticipated that collaborations between Uganda and Cote D'Ivoire, as well as other African nations, will contribute to the continued growth and success of the African school sports movement.

post.Title: Empowering the Future: USSSA Capacity Building Program Receives Praise from Students and Officials
post.Content:
By John Wycliffe Musinguzi (USSSA Media Class student)

Students and officials are lauding the Uganda Secondary Schools Sports Association (USSSA) Capacity Building Program, which has already begun yielding positive results. The program, aimed at training students to become coaches, officials, umpires, and media officers, was introduced in 2022 with the goal of developing a new generation of young individuals to handle all USSSA events and activities.

"The USSSA Capacity Building Program has been a game-changer for us. It has provided us with the necessary skills and knowledge to actively contribute to the sports community," expressed Sarah, a participant and aspiring coach from Kibuli Secondary School. Another participant, Peter, a student from Mbarara High School, shared his excitement, saying, "Being part of this program has been an incredible opportunity. I have learned so much, and it has inspired me to pursue a career in sports officiating."

In December 2022, the inaugural USSSA Capacity Building Program was held at Kibuli Secondary School, attracting over 500 participants, including students and teachers. The success of the program sparked interest, and it quickly spread across the entire country. Two additional training sessions were subsequently held in Western Uganda at Mbarara High School and in the Teso Zone at Amus College. Patrick Okanya, the Program Chairman and USSSA President Emeritus, commended the dedication of the students and schools involved in the training.

"We would like to thank schools and students who have embraced this training, which is school-government sponsored because they have made it powerful and shining," he remarked proudly. Regarding the impact of the training program, Okanya emphasized, "Currently, all the games in Kabale have officials who are our products from the December and January training sessions, which empowers us because we have started harvesting fruits." "From 2025, Uganda Secondary Schools Sports Association shall be using its own products to officiate our games, coaches coaching schools, and media officers covering our games will be our products," Mr. Patrick insisted, outlining the association's vision for the future.

"Everything we achieve in life starts with hope, faith, self-belief, conviction, including life," said acting president Hajj Twahill Kiteezaala, as he encouraged students and wished them the best in their endeavors. "Be of good character, personality, values, self-discipline, and self-control participants," he urged, emphasizing the importance of personal development and responsibility in shaping a successful future.

It should be noted that the instructors training the students are federation coaches and instructors, meaning that the certificates participants receive are from different federations. This creates more opportunities for excelling students, as they gain recognition beyond the USSSA program.

The USSSA Capacity Building Program has proven to be a significant step towards enhancing the quality of school sports in Uganda. By equipping students with the necessary skills and knowledge, the program aims to cultivate a new generation of capable coaches, officials, umpires, and media officers, ensuring the sustainability and growth of school sports across the country. "The program has empowered us to actively contribute to the sports community and has opened doors for future opportunities. We are grateful for the USSSA Capacity Building Program," Sarah added, summing up the sentiments of many participants.

post.Title: Rugby Quarter Finals Heat Up USSSA Games at St. Mary's College Rushoroza, NTC Kabale
post.Content:
Complied by:
ATUHAIRE SHIVAN,
Media Officer, ST. MARY'S COLLEGE RUSHOROZA.

Saturday, July 15th, 2023 - The rugby quarter-finals at NTC, Kabale, were nothing short of exhilarating as different schools battled fiercely to secure their spot in the semi-finals, scheduled to take place tomorrow at the same venue.

The action-packed day commenced with the clash between Jinja Senior Secondary School and Mwiri Secondary School. Jinja exhibited their superiority on the field, securing a resounding victory with a scoreline of 27-00. Their impressive performance set the tone for the day's enthralling matchups.

Next up was the intense encounter between Kiira College Butiki and Nyakasura School. Both teams displayed immense vigor and determination, making it an intriguing spectacle for spectators. Ultimately, Kiira College Butiki emerged victorious, with a convincing scoreline of 27-07.

The third match witnessed a western showdown between Mbarara High School and Ntare School. The clash between the two regional powerhouses had everyone on the edge of their seats. In the end, it was Ntare School that claimed the hard-fought victory, prevailing with a score of 14-05.

The final game of the day featured a battle of the giants - London College versus St. Peters Nalya. The teams left no stone unturned, and the match was fiercely contested. When the final whistle blew, London College emerged triumphant, clinching the game with a score of 15-05.

Each match was fiercely fought for a duration of 14 minutes, divided into two halves lasting 7 minutes each, with 1 or 2 minutes allocated for time-outs.

As the sun sets on the quarter-finals, all eyes now turn to the upcoming semi-finals. Tomorrow's matches will determine the teams that will advance to the East African competitions, as well as the finalists who will vie for the grand championship. Among the participants, Hannah International in Rwanda stands as the defending champions from last year, adding an extra layer of anticipation to the upcoming battles.

The rugby quarter-finals showcased the talent, skill, and passion of the participating schools, creating an unforgettable sporting experience for players and spectators alike.

post.Title: USSSA Ball Games II Final Games of Woodball 2023 Culminate in Intense Showdown at St. Mary's College Rushoroza, Kabale
post.Content:
Date: 17th July 2023

Complied by Katende Ryan and Nangendo Madinah from SSEKE SS, Lwengo District

GIRLS' COMPETITION

The much-anticipated final games of Woodball 2023 under the Uganda Secondary Schools Sports Association (USSSA) took place at St. Mary's College Rushoroza, Kabale, with an exciting clash between Mityana S.S and Luzira S.S in the girls' category.

In the singles matches, the students of Mityana S.S, Nanfuka Jeremina, and Nabitula Ruth Nabwami showcased their skills against Luzira S.S's Nakeesi Sarah and Nagudi Shakirah, respectively. Nanfuka Jeremina managed to secure 3 fairways, but her opponent Nakeesi Sarah outshined her, winning with an impressive 5 fairways and 4 ties. This outstanding performance led to Nakeesi Sarah's victory in the singles competition.

However, in the other singles match, Nabitula Ruth Nabwami displayed her prowess, achieving an impressive 6 fairways. Her competitor, Nagudi Shakirah from Luzira S.S, fought valiantly but could only manage 4 fairways and 2 ties, resulting in Ruth's victory for Mityana S.S.

In the doubles competition, the team of Nambalirwa Bitiyali and Namulwana Sonia Mary from Mityana S.S demonstrated their excellent coordination and skills, securing 5 fairways. Despite a fierce effort from Nakimera Sandra and Namajja Caroline of Luzira S.S, who also scored 3 fairways, both teams ended up with 3 ties. Ultimately, Mityana S.S emerged victorious in the girls' competitions, earning the honor of representing Uganda in the FEASSSA games in Huye, Rwanda.

BOYS' COMPETITION

The boys' final was equally exhilarating, featuring a gripping clash between Luzira S.S and Airforce S.S.

In the singles category, Etyang Kenneth from Luzira S.S showcased exceptional form, claiming an impressive 6 fairways. His opponent, Agaba Brain from Airforce S.S, fought valiantly but secured only 1 fairway, resulting in Kenneth's triumph in the first single competition with a 1-point advantage.

The second singles match was equally intense, with Kawooya Godfrey representing Luzira S.S and Amanyire Darry Gilles from Airforce S.S. While Godfrey achieved 4 fairways, Amanyire Darry Gilles showcased great skill, securing 5 fairways. However, it was the 3 fairway ties that ultimately led to Amanyire Darry Gilles' victory by a single point.

The doubles competition brought even more excitement as the team of Okello Jimmy James and Adrigo Norris from Luzira S.S managed to secure 5 fairways. Ssekidde Bruno and Muwanguzi Mark of Airforce S.S put up a valiant fight, achieving 4 fairways, and both teams tied in 3 fairways. However, it was James and Norris from Luzira S.S who emerged triumphant in the double competition, securing the win by a single point.

Final Verdict

With an outstanding performance in both the singles and doubles competitions, Luzira S.S emerged as the victors in the boys' category, showcasing their remarkable talent and dedication to the sport.

The USSSA Final Games of Woodball 2023 at St. Mary's College Rushoroza, Kabale, undoubtedly left the spectators and participants alike in awe of the exceptional skills displayed on the Woodball course. Congratulations to Luzira S.S in the boys' category and Mityana S.S in the girls' category for their remarkable achievements. These talented teams have earned the honor of representing Uganda in the upcoming FEASSSA games in Huye, Rwanda.

post.Title: Thrilling Showdown at DanceSport Finale: Winners Emerge in Popping, Breaking, and Crew Battles
post.Content:
Date: 16th July 2023

Compiled by: Aaron Niwamanya(USSSA Media Class Student)

"Dance Sport Finale: Popping, Breaking, and Crew Battles Ignite the Stage"

The dance floor was set ablaze as the DanceSport Finale unfolded, showcasing electrifying performances in the categories of popping, breaking, and crew battles. With hearts pounding and spectators cheering, dancers from different schools gave their all to claim victory in this high-energy competition.

Popping Category:

In the popping girls' category, it was a fierce battle between Charity from London College and Elizabeth from St. Julian. Both dancers displayed incredible skill and creativity, but in the end, it was Elizabeth who emerged triumphant, securing the gold medal for St. Julian.

The popping boys' category was no less intense, featuring an exciting face-off between Ramathan from SMACON and Abdul from Nyakasura. The crowd was treated to a breathtaking performance, but ultimately, it was Ramathan from SMACON who wowed the judges and claimed the top spot in the final battle.

Breaking Category:

The boys' breaking category saw a thrilling showdown between Miracle from St. Julian and Ntulime from Crown City. These talented breakers brought their best moves to the floor, but it was Ntulime who managed to outshine his opponent, securing a well-deserved victory and the gold medal.

For the girls' breaking category, it was an intense battle between Sophia from St. Julian and Gloria. Both dancers displayed incredible strength and style, but it was Sophia who impressed the judges the most, walking away with the coveted gold medal.

Afro Dance Category:

The Afro Dance finals were reserved for the closing ceremony, adding to the excitement of the event. The semi-finalists, Akurut from St. Julian and Jackie from Gombe High School, wowed the audience with their mesmerizing performances, setting the stage for an epic finale.

In the boys' Afro Dance category, the final battle was between Dickson from Ntare and Vincent from SMACON. The two dancers gave it their all, leaving the judges with a tough decision to make in determining the winner.

Crew Battles:

The crew battles were another highlight of the competition, with Mbarara High School facing off against St. Mark's Namagoma. The energy in the room was electrifying as these talented crews battled it out for the title. In the end, Mbarara High School's crew delivered a show-stopping performance, earning them the well-deserved championship title.

Awaiting the Afro Dance Finale:

As the DanceSport Finale came to a close, all eyes were on the Afro Dance category, where both boys and girls were set to compete in the closing ceremony. The anticipation was palpable as the dancers prepared to give it their all in pursuit of the gold medal.

The winners of each category will receive not only the prestigious gold medals but also certificates of recognition from the Uganda Dance Sport Federation, acknowledging their exceptional talent and dedication to the art of dance.

The DanceSport Finale showcased the incredible talent within Uganda's dance community and highlighted the passion and commitment of these young dancers. The event was a testament to the growing popularity and appreciation of dance sport in the country, and it left everyone eagerly looking forward to future competitions.

post.Title: USSSA Ball Games II 2023 Culminates in Kabale with a Remarkable Display of Sportsmanship
post.Content:
By Joel Muyita

Kabale, July 17, 2023 – The picturesque town of Kabale played host to nine days of exhilarating sporting action during the 2023 USSSA Ball Games II. From the bustling corridors of St. Mary's College Rushoroza, the host school, to the vibrant town center, Kabale witnessed an unprecedented influx of sports enthusiasts and participants, turning it into a hub of sportsmanship and camaraderie.

The eagerly awaited games, which commenced on July 9, came to a thrilling climax on Monday, July 17, with deserving winners across various disciplines recognized and awarded for their outstanding performances.

The closing ceremony, held at the Kabale Main Stadium, was graced by the esteemed presence of the State Minister for Sports in the Ministry of Education and Sports, Hon. Peter Ogwang. Joining him were Commissioner for Physical Education in the Ministry of Education and Sports, Rev. Duncans Mugumya, USSSA President Justus Mugisha, USSSA President Emeritus Patrick Okanya, Headmaster of St. Mary's College Rushoroza, Remigio Byamukama, and RDC Kabale Geoffrey Nyakahuma, among other distinguished guests.

During his address, Hon. Ogwang expressed heartfelt gratitude to Kabale district and the entire Kigezi region for being gracious hosts of the games:

"I bring greetings from the First Lady who is also the Minister of Education and Sports. We thank the people of Kabale and Kigezi region as a whole for being wonderful hosts. St. Mary's College Rushoroza, the local authorities here have done a tremendous job in ensuring the games are played and completed without any major glitches."

The Minister, however, sternly warned against the use of non-bona fide students and age cheating in school sports:

"I am here to warn schools that use non-students and those that practice age cheating. The new sports law which awaits ascent from H.E the President is tough on this. We shall arrest headteachers, games teachers, and ban schools and students who are found guilty."

USSSA President Mugisha took the opportunity to commend the participating schools for their involvement in this year's edition, noting a significant increase in the number of schools and students partaking in the games:

"On behalf of USSSA, we thank all the schools that have taken part in both Ball Games I and II. We thank our hosts St. Mary's College Rushoroza who have done a great job. 2023 has been a successful year with a significant increase in the number of schools and students."

Headmaster Monday Christopher of St. Mary's College Rushoroza expressed his pride and joy in hosting a championship of such magnitude, reaffirming the school's readiness to host the FEASSA Games should Uganda be granted the opportunity:

"I'm grateful that we have been able to host the whole of Uganda for this long and the Championship coming to an end without any negativities. I can confidently say that we are now able to host the FEASSA games, and if Uganda gets the chance to host, please always think about us as the first priority."

The impact of the USSSA Ball Games II extended beyond the realm of sports. RDC Nyakahuma acknowledged the positive influence of the event on the local business community, which experienced a significant boost in economic activity during the tournament:

"We appreciate USSSA for bringing the games to Kabale, and the business community benefited immensely."

The 2023 edition witnessed the introduction of new sports disciplines, such as Beach Soccer, DanceSport, and Lacrosse, enhancing the diversity and excitement of the games.
