post.Title: Uganda's Schools Unite for Sports Development: Collaboration and Training Spark Enthusiasm
post.Content:
Date: 28th August 2023

Uganda's sports scene is buzzing with unity and commitment as the Uganda Primary Schools Games Association (UPSSA) extends its gratitude to the Uganda Secondary Schools Administration (USSSA). This partnership aims to boost sports across the nation by sharing expertise with primary school athletes. Pauline Musigire, Chairperson of UPSSA, highlighted this collaborative initiative during an address to games teachers at a five-day training event in Mbarara City's St. Mary's Technical Institute.

"We're standing together to lift Uganda's sports arena. The joint effort of UPSSA and USSSA shows our dedication to nurturing young talents and laying the foundation for sports success," noted Pauline Musigire, Chairperson of UPSSA.

The training, a combined effort by USSSA and UPSSA, takes a step towards enriching sports education for budding talents in primary schools. Two games teachers from each district have been chosen to partake in this enlightening event.

"Your active involvement will make this initiative a success. Embrace this training to shape Uganda's sports future," encouraged Harriet Apolot, 3rd Vice President of the Uganda Secondary Schools Games Association.

Sam Odongo, Assistant Commissioner of Physical Education, joined the event's launch, sharing motivation for all participants. "Your dedication to learning these skills will ripple beyond the field. You're architects of a brighter sports future for Uganda," he said.

The training covers diverse sports like Athletics, Netball, Football, and Volleyball. The goal is to empower games' teachers with tools and knowledge to coach young sports enthusiasts effectively.

"This training equips us with modern coaching techniques to unlock our young athletes' potential. We're grateful for this opportunity to improve our skills," expressed one of the attending games teachers.

The UPSSA-USSSA collaboration showcases how unity and shared expertise can create positive change. This joint effort promises to uncover hidden talents and build a robust sports culture in Uganda, nurturing a generation of empowered and inspired youth through sports education.

post.Title: "Empowering Primary Teachers for a Brighter Sporting Future: Mugerwa's Vital Message as 253 Educators Complete Training"
post.Content:
By Wycliffe Musinguzi (USSSA Capacity Building student)

On September 2nd, 2023, a groundbreaking capacity-building program marked a significant milestone in the journey to strengthen the foundation of primary school sports education. With joy and enthusiasm radiating from the participants, 253 teachers successfully completed a five-day training program held at St. Mary's Vocational School in Mbarara, covering four distinct disciplines: football coaching and refereeing, netball coaching and umpiring, volleyball coaching and umpiring, and athletics coaching.

Here's a breakdown of the participants: 44 in football refereeing, 52 in football coaching, 50 in netball umpiring, 54 in netball coaching, 22 in volleyball coaching, and 30 in athletics.

"This marks the beginning of a new era for primary school sports education. We will plan and organize more courses in December to continue this positive momentum," said Ms. Harriet Margaret Apolot, the 3rd Vice President of USSSA (Uganda Schools Sports Association), expressing her excitement about this pioneering program in primary schools.

Acknowledging the crucial role of grassroots talent in fueling international success, Ms. Apolot emphasized the importance of putting knowledge into action. She added, "As USSSA, we have seen that we are performing well on the international level, but we have to go back to the grassroots who feed us with the talent. I congratulate you all and request you to go and put into action what you have studied."

"As UPSSA, we can't thank USSSA executive and everyone behind this innovation; we believe this is the way to go, and we shall organize more," expressed Mr. Musigire Pauline, President UPSSA, reflecting the enthusiastic support for the partnership and its potential for future initiatives.

Mr. Gilbert Orikiriza, an education officer from the Ministry of Education and Sports, commended USSSA and UPSSA (Uganda Primary Schools Sports Association) for their partnership in launching this initiative to promote grassroots sports. He noted, "We appreciate USSSA for the partnership with UPSSA to bring such an initiative that will promote school sports from the grassroots."

Hon. Robert Kachebezi Mugabe, the Mayor of Mbarara City and the chief guest at the capacity-building closing ceremony, extended his gratitude to the Government of Uganda for its support of sports, particularly school sports, which he sees as a catalyst for tourism and development. He urged parents to nurture their children's talents alongside their academic pursuits.

"I would like to request parents to support their children with talent so that they can develop it instead of focusing on education only," Mayor Kachebezi concluded.

However, the event took a poignant turn when She Cranes Head Coach Fred Mugerwa addressed the male coaches. Expressing his concern about inappropriate behavior, Mugerwa delivered a strong message: "To you male coaches working with girls, treat them as you would your own children. Support their growth and development; do not exploit them." His words resonated strongly with the audience.

As the capacity-building program concluded, participants praised USSSA for its partnership with UPSSA and expressed a heartfelt desire for similar courses to be accessible in their respective regions.

The dedicated instructors who facilitated this program include Samuel Turyomuriwe (Football Refereeing), Ssali Tom (Football Coaching), Fred Mugerwa (Netball Coaching), Zubedda Nansanga (Netball Umpiring), Nicholas Obeke (Volleyball Coaching), and Teddy Awol (Course Coordinator, USSSA Secretariat).

This event marks a crucial step forward in nurturing young sporting talent and ensuring the ethical development of sports education at the primary school level.

post.Title: USSSA ,Primary Schools marriage made in heaven
post.Content:
Uganda Secondary School Sports Association (USSSA) president Justus Mugisha believes their partnership with their primary schools counterparts “is a match made in heaven.”

Speaking at the closing ceremony and later dinner of the August 28 to September 5 National Primary School  Ball games at Kakyeeka stadium, Mugisha said the move will ensure that “in a few years Uganda will be at the top of the world because all games start in school.”

You (Ministry of Education and Sports) asked us to cooperate with schools and also asked us to work with (sports) federations for maximum results and we are onto that,” Mugisha said addressing the Commissioner Physical Education and Sports in the Ministry of Education and Sports Rev. Canon Duncans Mugumya, who was the chief guest on the day.

“We took 14 years to win the FEASSSA Games. Now for the third year running, we are winning and with a big margin.But what is important is not that we are beating Kenya but that we are contributing immensely to sports development in the region”.

However, despite all this, we still came to a conclusion that starting sports at secondary school level is too late. So we tried to put up U-16 tournaments but nothing was changing.

 That is why we have returned to collaborate  with the primary schools,” Mugisha said at the games which were broadcast on the USSSA YouTube channel and where the body held capacity building training for the teachers. Mugisha also promised the body has the money to push this to district level unlike the case in Mbarara where each district was allowed up to two participants.

Incentivizing primary schools

Unlike USSSA, which brings the winning school teams to the nationals, the primary school association brings district select teams to the national games. Although this theoretically brings the very best talents, it ends up demotivating the schools, which put in so much to develop these talents. At the national level, the sporting primary schools get no mileage out of their investment. Secondly, the teams have to camp before the games at national, which takes the pupils out of their schools for prolonged periods of time, hence missing out on academics

Mugisha also added that there are challenges like financing that need to be addressed.

“We can work together to ensure games in schools can be financed by government. In Kigali, we had many MPs and they were interested in having this discussion.”

Mugisha also shared that there should be participation incentives for the primary schools as the ISF (World School Federation) Games are not for only secondary school going students.

Uganda will need more games to help it win at international level. The FEASSSA games where some of these teams could have gotten more competition ended on the same day these primary school games were starting. Uganda, therefore, missed an opportunity to win both the primary and secondary categories at the just concluded FEASSSA Games.

School games competitions are for different age categories; U-12, U-14, and U-16.

Age cheating

However, it was observed that the age categorization is not dependent on the date of birth but rather a unit reached according to one height and weight.

“Tall kids and those who are well fed end up being disadvantaged by the system. Unfortunately, it's the tall athletes that are on demand in most, if not all, sports disciplines.

“Unlike at secondary, where players are registered online and verified prior to the championship, in the primary games, players are weighted, categorized, and registered on arrival. The organizers have no knowledge about the number in the different categories prior to this process. As such, draws and fixtures delay for as many as two days. The registration forms do not have a field for the school attended by pupils nor the pupils' EMIS number. It's therefore difficult to verify whether the athletes go to school. It is highly suspected that a good number of athletes in the U-16 category are actually  secondary school students,” added Mugisha, who has the experience as a director at Standard High School – Zzana, first vice president fufa, president of USSSA, president of FEASSSA for 20 years, and president technical commission for football ISF.

Feeding issues

Mugisha also noted that “unlike USSSA games, where we have centralized feeding, at primary games, each district fends for itself. The children are at the mercy of the officials who travel with the team. This also creates classes as some children are fed on rice and chicken, while others take porridge for meals. No wonder some teams could not honor all their fixtures after running out of upkeep funds.”

Free-up games

The president also advised that the students be given more playing time instead of putting them under strict competition rules.

“Do not eliminate teams at preliminaries. Have them play classification games so that each team plays the same number of games. Kids need to play as many games as possible,” Mugisha said.

For this, he was backed by Mugumya who added that “This (primary schools) championship is not intended for gold, silver or bronze medals but to identify talent and get an opportunity to nurture it for a good future.”

post.Title: USSSA court headteachers at ASSHU Annual General meeting in Teso Region.
post.Content:
Uganda Secondary School Sports Association (USSSA) are pushing to have all stakeholders on board in terms of sports development.

The executive led by president Justus Mugisha spent the better part of the week in Soroti as part of the Association of Secondary School Headteachers of Uganda (ASSHU) Annual General Meeting (AGM) held at Teso College, Aloet.

The headteachers are seen as key internal stakeholders that could help USSSA make strides in the eight strategic areas of; administration, communications, competitions, governance, infrastructure and facilities, marketing, talent identification, and technical development –in the 2022-2026 period.

In this term, USSSA, according to Mugisha, seek to grow the existing competitions to include more of the disciplines like dance sport, lacrosse, woodball, beach (soccer, volleyball) and mind games plus also popularize athletics inter-school competitions.

The association has also introduced age category games but seeks to do it for all sports (U15, U16) and also start Sunday Leagues for major sports in cities and towns across the country.

USSSA has also trained 4,236 students and teachers but is now trying to encourage them to participate in the games as referees, coaches, administrators, media officers and volunteers.

Annual General Meeting

The meeting held on Saturday, 9th September was officially opened a day earlier by Hon. J.C Muyingo,Minister of State for Higher Education(MoES).

Hon.Muyingo appreciated the teachers for the work they do and to ensure that learners not only focus on academic work but also sports and vocational studies.

The meeting was chaired by the now President Bro. Augustine Mugabo , headteacher St. Henry's College Kitovu in Greater Masaka.

During the meeting the members unanimously agreed to sue the title President instead of Chairperson.Brother Mugabo thanked USSSA led by Justus Mugisha for helping secondary schools get organized as far as participating in sports is concerned. He also thanked the schools that have recently participated in ISF World Football Championship that was held in Rabat, Morocco. The schools were St Noa Girls, Zana , Kibuli SS and Amus College.

“Endavour to always call Mr. Mugisha and ask for clarity on anything regarding participation in USSSA activities than using whats app to vent”

Bro. Augustine Mugabo, ASSHU President.

A moment of silence was observed for the departed members including Brother John Bosco Kato, Headteacher Bishop Comboni College Kambuga and USSSA Executive committee member who passed away on 16th August 2023.

Closing ceremony

The chief guest Ms. Ketty Lamaro, Permanent Secretary , Ministry of Education and Sports was represented by Enyomu Richard , Commissioner, Human Resource Management (MoES).

While giving his speech on he commended ASSHU leadership for always organizing this annual event AGM midst all the challenges and he reminded the headteachers to ensure maximum supervision of the implementation of the new curriculum.

post.Title: Uganda Secondary Schools National Championships 2024: Call for Hosting Bids
post.Content:
Kampala, 13th September 2023 - The Uganda Secondary Schools Sports Association (USSSA), in collaboration with the Ministry of Education and Sports (MoES) and the Association of Secondary School Headteachers of Uganda (ASSHU), has officially extended an invitation to all interested secondary schools to bid for the privilege of hosting or co-hosting the prestigious Uganda Secondary Schools National Championships in 2024.

The championships are a showcase of talent and sportsmanship in the Ugandan secondary school system and consist of several exciting events, including the Fresh Dairy Secondary School Games, Secondary School Football Boys Championship, Secondary School Swimming Gala, and Ball Games II/Athletics Championship. This opportunity is a chance for schools to play a significant role in promoting sports excellence among the nation's youth.

To be eligible for consideration, schools must be situated within any of the following USSSA Zones: Kampala, Luwero, Masaka, Mpigi, Mukono, and Wakiso. These zones encompass a wide array of districts, including Nakawa, Rubaga, Makindye, Central, Kawempe, Nakasongola, Nakaseke, Luwero, Kiboga, Kyankwanzi, Bukomansimbi, Kalungu, Kalangala, Rakai, Lwengo, Lyantonde, Sembabule, Kyotera, Masaka, Butambala, Mityana, Mpigi, Gomba, Mubende, Mukono, Kayunga, Buikwe, Buvuma, and all zones in Wakiso.

Interested schools are required to carefully review the provided checklist and complete the hosting bid form in accordance with the guidelines. Completed forms should be submitted to the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the Uganda Secondary Schools Sports Association (USSSA) at their office located in GNS Plaza, opposite Gaddaffi Mosque. Alternatively, schools can send scanned copies of their completed forms via email to usssa2002@gmail.com. All submissions must be received by the USSSA no later than 5:00 PM on September 30, 2023.

It is important to note that for a hosting bid to be considered, schools must also seek endorsement from their respective Local District Authorities, including the Resident District Commissioner (RDC), Chief Administrative Officer (CAO), District Education Officer (DEO), and District Sports Officer (DSO). This endorsement is crucial in the evaluation process and ensures the support and cooperation of local authorities.

This is a unique opportunity for secondary schools to not only showcase their commitment to sports development but also to contribute to the overall growth of youth athletics in Uganda. The championships have historically served as a platform for nurturing talent and fostering a spirit of healthy competition among students.

In his official invitation, Mr. Mugisha Christopher Banage, the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of USSSA, expressed the organization's enthusiasm for hosting another successful championship and encouraged schools to participate actively in the bidding process.

All secondary schools interested in hosting or co-hosting the Uganda Secondary Schools National Championships 2024 are urged to act promptly, adhere to the outlined guidelines, and make their mark on the future of Ugandan sports.

For further inquiries or clarification, interested parties can contact USSSA at the provided email address: usssa2002@gmail.com.

The entire Ugandan educational community eagerly awaits the selection of the host schools and the subsequent excitement and thrill of the Uganda Secondary Schools National Championships in 2024.

See the Guidelines below;

post.Title: USSSA Annual General Assembly 2023: Shaping the Future of School Sports in Uganda
post.Content:
Kampala, 13th September 2023 - The Uganda Secondary Schools Sports Association (USSSA) extends a warm and enthusiastic invitation to all its esteemed members, Honorary Zonal Chairpersons, and Secretaries to the much-anticipated General Assembly (AGM) for the year 2023. This significant event will be held on Saturday, October 14, 2023, at the GNS Hotel, situated within GNS Plaza, just opposite the iconic Gaddaffi Mosque on Old Kampala Road. The AGM will commence promptly at 09:00 AM.

The USSSA AGM is a crucial gathering that serves as a platform for members to come together, discuss vital issues, and make decisions that will shape the future of school sports in Uganda. To ensure that the AGM is a productive and meaningful event, a proposed agenda has been prepared, outlining the key topics that will be addressed:

Proposed Agenda:

1. Arrival, Registration, Prayer, and Introduction: The AGM will commence with a warm welcome, followed by registration, a prayer to invoke blessings for the event, and an introduction of all participants.

2. Address from the Chairperson: The USSSA Chairperson will provide a comprehensive address, highlighting the association's achievements, challenges, and future plans.

3. Minutes Reading, Correction, Approval, and Matters Arising: The minutes from the previous AGM will be reviewed, and any necessary corrections or amendments will be made. Matters arising from the minutes will also be discussed.

4. Activity Report: The association will present a comprehensive activity report, summarizing the key events and initiatives undertaken during the past year. This report will shed light on the progress made in promoting sports at the secondary school level.

5. Financial Report: The financial report will provide a transparent overview of the association's financial status, including income, expenditure, and any financial challenges encountered.

6. Sports Calendar and Hosting of FEASSA Games & National Championship 2024: The USSSA will present the sports calendar for the upcoming year, as well as plans and considerations for hosting the FEASSA Games and the National Championship in 2024.

It is essential to note the following key points:

1. Representation: Each USSSA Zone will be represented by a maximum of five (5) Delegates at the AGM. Among these delegates, at least one (1) must be a female member. This representation ensures diversity and inclusivity in decision-making.

2. Proposals: Any new proposals or suggestions to be presented at the AGM must be submitted to the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) no later than September 28, 2023, by 5:00 PM. Proposals can be sent via email to usssa2002@gmail.com or cbkbanage@gmail.com. Your ideas and input are invaluable in shaping the future of school sports.

3. Attendance: Attendance at the AGM will be by nomination, as designated by the Zonal Chairpersons and Secretaries. Please ensure your active participation by following the nomination process.

The USSSA General Assembly is a pivotal event where members come together to foster collaboration, discuss important matters, and chart the course for the growth and development of school sports in Uganda. Your presence and active participation are highly encouraged, as they contribute to the collective success of the association.

For further inquiries or information regarding the AGM, please do not hesitate to contact the USSSA via email at usssa2002@gmail.com or cbkbanage@gmail.com.

post.Title: Qualified Schools Invited for ISF World Championships 2024: Uganda Prepares to Shine on the Global Stage
post.Content:
Kampala, Uganda - Excitement is building in Uganda's school sports community as several Qualified secondary schools are invited for the prestigious International Schools Sports Federation (ISF) World School Championships in 2024. These championships, set to take place in various locations around the world, will feature talented athletes representing Uganda on the global stage.

Volleyball Champions Lead the Way

The journey to ISF World Championships glory begins with the ISF World Schools Volleyball Championship, scheduled for April 19 to 29, 2024, in Belgrade, Serbia. The boys' category will see Standard High School Zana, the national champion, leading the charge, with support from Bukedea Comprehensive College and Namugongo Vocation & Secondary School, both national finalists. On the girls' side, St. Elizabeth Girls School, the national champion, will be joined by Ngora High School, a national finalist.

Cross Country Excellence in Kenya

Next up will be the ISF World Schools Cross Country Championship, which will take place from May 10 to 15, 2024, in Nairobi, Kenya. Uganda's cross-country team is FEASSSA's defending champion in both the girls' and boys' categories, having secured victory in 2022.

Football Stars in China

In May 2024, from the 17th to the 27th, the ISF World Schools Football Championship will be held in Dalian, P.R. China. St. Mary’s B. Secondary School Kitende, the FEASSSA and national champions, will represent Uganda in the boys' category, alongside St. Henry's College Kitovu and Amus College School, both national finalists. Amus College School, the national champion, will proudly represent Uganda in the girls' category, along with St. Noa Girls Secondary School, the national finalist, and Kawempe Muslim Secondary School, the FEASSSA champions.

Basketball Stars Head to Macao

From June 23 to July 3, 2024, Macao, China, will host the ISF World Schools Basketball Championship. In the boys' category, Buddo Secondary School, the FEASSSA and national champions, will showcase their skills, with Elite High School Entebbe as the national finalist. The girls' category will see St. Mary’s Boarding Secondary School Kitende, the FEASSSA and national champions, in action, along with St. Noa Girls Secondary School, the national finalist.

Multi-Discipline Gymnasiade in Bahrain

The ISF World Schools Gymnasiade 2024 is set to take place from October 23 to 31, 2024, in Manama, Bahrain. This multi-discipline event will feature talented athletes competing in various sports, including table tennis, badminton, basketball 3x3, tennis, swimming, athletics, chess, and handball.

Table Tennis and Badminton Talent

In the table tennis category, Kibuli Secondary School, the FEASSSA and national champions, will lead the boys' team, joined by St. Andrews College Ssanda, the national finalist, and Mbogo College School, the FEASSSA finalist. In the girls' category, Mbogo College School, the national champion, will compete alongside Kibuli Secondary School, the FEASSSA champions, and Kawanda Secondary School, the FEASSSA finalist.

In badminton, Kibuli Secondary School, the FEASSSA and national champions, will represent Uganda in the boys' category, alongside Kinaawa High School, the national finalist, and Kakungulu Memorial School, the FEASSSA finalist. In the girls' category, Mbogo High School, the FEASSSA and national champions, will participate, along with Rubaga Girls School, the FEASSSA and national finalist.

Basketball 3x3 and Tennis Excellence

Bethel Covenant College will represent Uganda in the boys' category of basketball 3x3 as the national champion, along with Buddo Secondary School, the FEASSSA champion, and Hope Secondary School Nakirebe, the national finalist. In the girls' category, St. Mary’s B. Secondary School Kitende, the FEASSSA and national champions, will compete, joined by Ssaku Secondary School, the national finalist, and Nabisunsa Girls School, the FEASSSA finalists.

Tennis enthusiasts will see Kibuli Secondary School and Ntare School represent Uganda in the boys' category. In the girls' category, Kibuli Secondary School and Mt St. Mary’s Namagunga will showcase their talents.

A Call for Confirmation

As the selected schools prepare to take on the world, it's important to note that confirmation to participate in these championships is expected by September 30, 2023. The nation eagerly awaits the performances of these young athletes, who have already demonstrated their excellence on the national stage.

The Uganda Secondary Schools Sports Association (USSSA) and the entire Ugandan sports community are proud of the accomplishments of these talented students, and they will continue to provide support and encouragement as they represent Uganda at the ISF World School Championships 2024.

Stay tuned for updates on Uganda's journey to international sports glory!

INVITED TO ISF WORLD SCHOOL CHAMPIONSHIPS 2024Download

For media inquiries, please contact:

Omaria Bosco
Director of Marketing and Communications
Uganda Secondary Schools Sports Association
Email: boscoomaria@gmail.com
Tel: +256 752 841 468 | +256 785 714 798

Website Link: USSSA

Note: This news article is based on the provided information as of the publication date, and any changes or updates may not be reflected in this article.

post.Title: USSSA Embraces Mind Games: A New Era for Ugandan School Sports
post.Content:
In a landmark development, the Uganda Secondary School Sports Association (USSSA) convened a strategic meeting with the Mind Games Association of Uganda. This groundbreaking onboarding marks a significant shift in Ugandan school sports, focusing on introducing mind games into the Schools' Sports.

Ms. Apolot Harriet (USSSA 3RD Vice President):

Ms. Apolot Harriet, USSSA's 3RD Vice President, kicked off the event by highlighting the association's prior preparations for this momentous venture. She revealed that USSSA had already designated a delegate for mind games before the games were fully established. Their patience has paid off, as the time has finally come for discussions, idea-sharing, and the charting of a course for these innovative sports.

"We are thrilled to have included these games in the roster of secondary school sports associations. This initiative extends beyond secondary schools and aims to encompass primary and secondary school sports associations, thereby transforming the educational landscape," stated Ms. Apolot Harriet.

Ms. Apolot Harriet expressed her excitement about the discussions held during the meeting. The USSSA is eager to learn from the President and all participants, who are expected to provide invaluable insights that will shape the future of mind games in Ugandan schools. Plans are already in motion, with USSSA aiming to kickstart these games next year, pending the gathering of outcomes and recommendations from this historic meeting.

Upon launch, these games will become an integral part of the USSSA calendar, allowing for efficient scheduling and coordination. All relevant information will be communicated transparently, and terms and conditions will be established to ensure smooth integration into the educational system.

Hajj Lwembawo Hussein (USSSA EXCOM Member):

Hajj Lwembawo Hussein, a USSSA EXCOM Member tasked with overseeing the growth and development of mind games within USSSA, shared his journey and experiences. He acknowledged the challenges posed by some of the games' unique names and rules but emphasized their eagerness to learn and adapt.

Hussein highlighted the critical need for early sports development, stating, "We have devised a program to introduce these games across all our schools. It has become clear that one reason our national teams struggle in physical sports is that we often start training too late."

The program aims to promote sports at an earlier stage, ensuring that children have a strong foundation by the age of 13, enabling them to progress to more advanced training and, ultimately, national teams.

Doctor Dan Isabirye (President of Mind Games Association of Uganda):

Dr. Dan Isabirye, President of the Mind Games Association of Uganda, emphasized the significance of the partnership and the promising future it holds. He highlighted USSSA members' enthusiasm and commitment to integrating mind games into secondary schools. Their previous success in introducing activities like dance sports and woodball into school curriculums has set a promising precedent.

Dr. Dan Isabirye, Expressed his optimism for the partnership by stating, "This collaboration opens up exciting opportunities for the future of mind sports in Uganda and the broader East African region."

Dr. Isabirye outlined a comprehensive approach that includes online and physical training and addressing potential challenges. He also noted the exciting prospect of expanding these games to the regional level, given that the President of USSSA also holds the position of President at the East African Association.

The collaboration isn't limited to secondary schools; the Mind Games Association is exploring partnerships with primary schools, supported by USSSA's commitment to expanding these sports into primary education.

The list of mind games slated for introduction is extensive and diverse, promising a bright future for mind sports in Uganda. Chess, various Draughts variants, Morabaraba, Xhangi Qi(Siangi), Duplicate Bridge, Ludo, Omweso, Scrabble, Owale, Draughts, and Go are among the twelve games proposed for integration into the curriculum.

This partnership signifies a monumental transformation in Ugandan school sports, offering students the chance to cultivate strategic and intellectual skills while fostering healthy competition and camaraderie. The future of mind sports in Uganda looks incredibly promising, with USSSA and the Mind Games Association taking the lead in this exciting journey.

post.Title: WAKISSHA Honors Victorious Schools in Nationals & International Sports and MDD Events for 2023
post.Content:
Wakiso, September 30, 2023 - The Wakiso Secondary Schools Headteachers Association (WAKISSHA) celebrated the exceptional achievements of Wakiso schools in national and international sports and Music, Dance, and Drama (MDD) events for the year 2023. This recognition took place during their third-term General Meeting held at the WAKISSHA Resource Centre. Distinguished guests, including the Chief Guest, Mr. Fredrick Kiyingi Kinobe, District Education Officer (DEO) of Wakiso, were in attendance to honor the winning schools.

A Commemoration of Excellence

WAKISSHA's third-term General Meeting became a commemoration of excellence as schools from across Wakiso District handed over their hard-earned trophies and medals to the esteemed Chief Guest, Mr. Fredrick Kiyingi Kinobe. The event served as a testament to the dedication, talent, and commitment displayed by these schools throughout the year.

Celebrating Nationals & International Victories

The recognition included schools that clinched gold medals and trophies at both national and international levels. In sports, schools like Buddo Secondary School, St. Mary's Secondary School Kitende, King's College Buddo and Stand High School Zzana (STAHIZA) stood out with their remarkable achievements.

National Champions

International Glory

Certificates of Excellence

In addition to the trophies and medals, schools were awarded certificates for their excellent performance. These certificates recognized the schools' commitment to excellence and served as a testament to their dedication to both academic and extracurricular activities.

A Bright Path Forward

The General Meeting at the WAKISSHA Resource Centre was a momentous occasion that allowed Wakiso District to celebrate and honor its exceptional schools. With these institutions consistently raising the bar in various sports and MDD events, the future looks promising for Wakiso. WAKISSHA, alongside the entire community, salutes these schools for their remarkable achievements and eagerly anticipates their continued success in the years to come.

post.Title: FEASSSA 2024: Schools Line Up to Host The Prestigious Event
post.Content:
Published on October 2, 2023

KAMPALA, UGANDA - In an exciting turn of events, Uganda has been chosen to host the 21st edition of the East Africa School Games (FEASSA) in 2024. This highly anticipated sporting event, known for uniting secondary schools, primary schools, and special needs institutions (SNE) from across East Africa, is set to celebrate athletic prowess like never before.

The 2024 FEASSA Games will offer a spectacular showcase of a diverse range of disciplines, including soccer, basketball, volleyball, netball, handball, rugby 15s, hockey, athletics, badminton, 3x3 basketball, lawn tennis, table tennis, swimming, rugby 7s, and goal ball for SNE participants. With such a wide array of sports on the roster, the event promises to captivate the hearts of both participants and spectators.

Uganda's selection as the host for the 21st edition follows a rotational system. Following Rwanda's successful hosting of the 20th edition, Uganda now has the opportunity to showcase its commitment to nurturing young sporting talent and promoting sports development.

This decision underscores Uganda's dedication to providing a platform for budding athletes to shine. As preparations for the 2024 FEASSA Games gain momentum, the nation is gearing up to display its world-class sporting facilities, warm hospitality, and organizational prowess. The goal is to deliver a memorable and seamless event for all participants and spectators.

While Uganda secured the honor of hosting the event in 2024, several schools from across the country demonstrated their enthusiasm by submitting bids to host various sports disciplines during the games. The bidding schools included:

  1. St Mary’s College Rushoroza - Located in the picturesque Kigezi district, this school will represent the Western region of Uganda.
  2. Teso College Aloet - Nestled in Soroti district, this institution will be the face of the Teso region in Eastern Uganda.
  3. Nabumali High School - Proudly located in Mbale district, this school will carry the banner of the Bugisu region in Eastern Uganda.
  4. Jinja Secondary School - Found in Jinja district, this school will be the torchbearer for the Busoga region in Eastern Uganda.
  5. Bukedea Comprehensive School - Situated in Bukedi, this school will join Teso College Aloet in representing the Teso region in Eastern Uganda.
  6. Namilyango College - Based in Mukono district, this school will champion the Central region of Uganda.
  7. Nyakasura School - Nestled in the charming Fort Portal, this school will proudly represent the Rwenzori region in Western Uganda.

The bidding schools exhibited their commitment to promoting sports development and showcasing their respective regions' capabilities. While Uganda takes center stage as the host nation, these schools' active participation adds an extra layer of excitement and anticipation to the 2024 FEASSA Games.

As the countdown begins for the 2024 FEASSA Games, all eyes are on Uganda to deliver an extraordinary sporting extravaganza that will leave a lasting legacy for years to come.

post.Title: USSSA convenes 41<sup>st</sup> Ordinary Assembly 2024 activity, financial reports endorsed.
post.Content:
The Uganda Secondary School Sports Association (USSSA) successfully convened its 41st Annual General Assembly at GNS plaza in Old Kampala on Saturday, 14th October,2023.

The well attended congress was chaired by president Justus Mugisha, who was flanked by CEO Christopher Mugisha Banage and other members of the executive committee.

Honorable Peter Ogwang, Minister of state for Sports (Ministry of Education and Sports) was the chief guest at the assembly that was also attended by David Ngugi, FEASSSA General Secretary as well as the delegates from the different zones.

The assembly endorsed the activity and financial reports from the previous years as well as approving the ones for the 2024 season.

In the year 2022, USSSA generated 5,210,723,675 Uganda shillings with 2,700,000,000 Uganda shillings as the contribution from the Government. The remaining revenue was derived from subscriptions participation fees, accreditation sponsorships, fees from accommodation and feeding.

The projected budget for the year 2024 is 11,636,941,500 Uganda shillings (with 7 billion of this being contributed by the government through the Department of Physical Education, Ministry of Education and Sports).

Honorable Peter Ogwang appreciated the executive of USSSA for the work well done over the years as he hinted on the element of sports infrastructure development, a key pillar heading forward.

“I commend the leadership of USSSA for promoting school sports in Uganda. I appreciate the private sector for their effort to invest in sports infrastructure docket. Let us use the right age group of players in promoting the games. We shall apply the law to address age cheating and use of non bonafide students”. Hon Ogwang remarked.

FEASSSA representative Ngugi commended USSSA for leading by example in East and Central Africa region.

He projected successful tenure of the FEASSSA games in the forth coming years where Amus College and Bukedea Comprehensive schools will co-host the games in Uganda.

“FEASSSA is very proud of the development at USSSA, you are the shinning armor of FEASSSA. The FEASSSA games help to empower students as they develop their talents. The next FEASSSA games in 2024 will be hosted in Uganda and we aim to have very successful games” Ngugi stated.

“As USSSA, we have learnt and benchmarked a lot from our brother in Kenya”. President Mugisha added before notifying the assembly that combat and mind games will be added on the USSSA 2024 Calendar.

Zulaika Nabukeera, General Secretary, ASSHU singled out USSSA’s role in collaboration with the primary schools’ section to uplift the games from the grassroots.

“I laud USSSA fort the good management and administration. In a special way, I thank USSSA for adapting primary schools into the system. For pending issues of over aged students and the use of no bonafide students, we are with you in the struggle”. Nabukeera said.

The assembly also voted Monday Christopher, Head teacher, St. Mary’s College Rushoroza in a bye- election after Brother Kato who represented western region passed on in August this year. Monday beat the duo of Onesmus Rukundo and Joshua Kagaba in a closely contested election moment before the assembly was adjourned.

President Justus Mugisha informed the members that in 2024 USSSA will continue with the vast sports programs, domestic and international competitions and capacity building.

post.Title: USSSA-USPA MEDIA ENGAGEMENT: USSSA To Hold Maiden Stakeholder Engament
post.Content:
Kampala, Uganda - October 25, 2023

In an effort to foster a closer and more productive relationship with the Uganda Sports Press Association (USPA), the Uganda School Sports Association (USSSA) is excited to announce a collaborative workshop designed to address critical issues surrounding media coverage of school sports in Uganda.

Registration link - CLICK TO REGISTER

About USPA

The Uganda Sports Press Association (USPA) stands as a significant representative body for sports journalists and media professionals in the heart of Uganda. Founded on the principle of promoting excellence in sports journalism and media coverage, USPA plays a pivotal role in facilitating partnerships between media stakeholders, sports organizations, government entities, and other invested parties to enhance the coverage of sports events throughout Uganda.

In light of these principles, USSSA has organised a half-day workshop aimed at providing a platform for media stakeholders to engage in meaningful dialogue with USSSA, discussing crucial matters related to their involvement in the coverage of school sports. The workshop's central objective is to cultivate an informed and constructive partnership between USSSA and USPA.

Workshop Details

Event Date: Wednesday, 8th November 2023
Time: 8:00 AM – 12:00 PM
Venue: GNS Hotel main hall

Agenda:

  1. Welcome and Introduction: A warm welcome and introduction to the workshop's objectives.
  2. Overview of USSSA and USPA: An overview of the roles and responsibilities of USSSA and USPA in the context of school sports.
  3. The Role of Media in Promoting School Sports: An exploration of the vital role played by media in promoting and popularizing school sports.
  4. Challenges Faced by Media in Covering School Sports: A discussion of the challenges and obstacles media stakeholders encounter while covering school sports.
  5. Opportunities for Collaboration: Identifying and discussing potential collaboration opportunities between USSSA and USPA.
  6. Open Discussion and Q&A: An interactive session where participants can share their views, ask questions, and provide insights.
  7. Photos and Networking Session: A chance for attendees to network, build relationships, and take memorable photos.
  8. Lunch and Departure: A pleasant conclusion to the workshop, allowing participants to share a meal and bid farewell.

Expected Outcomes:

  • Enhanced understanding of the media's role in school sports: A deeper comprehension of the media's pivotal role in promoting school sports.
  • Identification of challenges faced by media stakeholders: A comprehensive understanding of the challenges that media professionals face while covering school sports.
  • Discussion of potential solutions and collaboration opportunities: A platform to brainstorm solutions and explore collaboration prospects.
  • Strengthened relationships between USSSA and USPA members: The workshop seeks to foster a stronger and more productive relationship between USSSA and USPA members.

The USSSA firmly believes that this workshop will prove mutually beneficial by addressing the specific needs and concerns of media professionals covering school sports. Furthermore, it will provide USSSA with an opportunity to share its vision and initiatives for school sports in Uganda.

Together, we can make a substantial impact on the media coverage of school sports in Uganda.

post.Title: USSSA Announces Capacity Building Program 2023/24: Empowering Uganda's Youth Through Education and Training
post.Content:
Date: 30th October 2023

Kampala, Uganda - The Uganda Secondary Schools Sports Association (USSSA) is thrilled to unveil its upcoming Capacity Building Program, designed to empower students, pupils, teachers, and sports enthusiasts across Uganda. The primary goal of this initiative is to prepare the 2023 candidates from P7, S4, and S6 for a brighter future in the world of sports. USSSA's commitment to nurturing talent and fostering excellence in school sports is at the heart of this program.

To register for the USSSA Capacity Building Program, interested participants can complete the registration process online through the provided link: Capacity Building Registration. Please note that the registration deadline is 24th November, 2023.

Diverse Training Courses

USSSA's Capacity Building Program offers a wide array of training courses across various sports disciplines, ensuring that participants can enhance their skills, knowledge, and passion in their chosen field. Courses include Football, Netball, Volleyball, Athletics, Basketball, Handball, and Racket Games (Table Tennis, Badminton, Tennis). Additionally, a special course in Media is available for those interested in sports journalism and broadcasting.

Key Program Details

  • Duration: The program spans one week(7 days).
  • Dates: The program is set to take place from December to January.
  • Cost: For nonresidents, the course fee is 98,000 UGX, while residents register for 150,000 UGX.
  • Limited Capacity: Each class is limited to 40 participants, with registration available on a first-come, first-served basis.
  • Flexibility: Participants can register for multiple courses, allowing them to expand their skill set without as long the courses sare not taking place at the same time (schedule conflicts).
  • Comprehensive Training: The program includes theoretical sessions, practical training, and examinations to ensure a holistic learning experience.
  • Certification: Upon completion, each participant will receive a certificate of attendance from USSSA. Successful candidates will also be awarded internationally recognized certificates of merit from the respective sports federations.

Financial Information

To make this program possible, USSSA generously covers the costs associated with literature, instructors, accreditation, training equipment, and publicity. The parental/school contribution of 98,000 UGX is allocated towards meals (including breakfast, lunch, and evening tea), venue expenses, and essential training kits.

Registration Details

To register for the USSSA Capacity Building Program, interested participants can complete the registration process online through the provided link: Capacity Building Registration. Please note that the registration deadline is 24th November 2023.

Training Venues and Dates

  • Kampala, Jinja, Fort Portal, Lira: 3rd - 9th Dec. 2023
  • Kampala, Mbale, Mbarara, Arua: 10th - 16th Dec. 2023
  • Kampala, Soroti, Hoima: 7th - 13th Jan. 2024
  • Kampala, Entebbe, Gulu: 14th - 20th Jan. 2024

Join USSSA in Shaping Uganda's Sports Future

USSSA encourages parents, candidates, and schools across Uganda to seize this exceptional opportunity for capacity building and skill enhancement. By investing in the development of our youth in Refereeing, Coaching, and Media, we collectively contribute to the growth and success of school sports in Uganda.

For further inquiries and registration details, please contact USSSA at the following numbers:

  • Phone: +256 393 256 054 | +256 772 684214 | +256 752 841 468 | +256 783 293067 | +256 701 376353
  • Email: usssa2002@gmail.com

Join USSSA in shaping the future of school sports in Uganda. Together, we can empower our youth to achieve greatness.

Don't miss this unique opportunity to empower the youth of Uganda through education and training in the field of sports. Register today and be a part of a brighter future for school sports in the country.

post.Title: Celebrating Sporting Excellence: USSSA and Athletics Teams Honored at State House
post.Content:
The Uganda Secondary Schools Sports Association (USSSA) and National Athletics Federation were granted a prestigious luncheon at the Entebbe State House, marking a significant recognition of their remarkable sporting achievements in the year 2023. The honors were attributed to their remarkable performance at the recently concluded FEASSSA Games in Huye City, Rwanda (17th - 27th August) and their international success at the ISF Games.

Uganda displayed sheer dominance in Huye, securing a remarkable 17 out of 25 possible trophies and, consequently, emerging as the overall winner for the third consecutive year. This impressive victory further solidified Uganda's reputation in the region as a sporting powerhouse.

Internationally, the prowess of Ugandan students extended to Morocco, where Buddo SS claimed the Africa 3X3 girls' basketball championship. Meanwhile, at the ISF Games, St Noa, Kibuli SS, and Amus College represented Uganda in the World Schools Football Championship and exhibited exceptional talent on the global stage, held once again in Morocco.

The athletics team also showcased their exceptional talent on the world stage, participating and emerging victorious in the World Championships hosted in Budapest City, Hungary.

The event at the State House was graced by several dignitaries, including FUFA President Hon. Eng. Moses Magogo, key officials from the Ministry of Education and Sports, Directors within the ministry, and members of the Board for the National Council of Sports (NCS), led by chairman Ambrose Tashobya and General Secretary Dr. Bernard Patrick Ogwel.

The event's Master of Ceremonies, Hon. Peter Ogwang, introduced both the USSSA and Athletics teams, and USSSA President Justus Mugisha conveyed his appreciation for being hosted at the State House.

USSSA President's Speech

Mugisha expressed his gratitude to His Excellency the President and the First Lady for their continued support and acknowledged the invaluable contributions of Mama as the Minister for Education and Sports. He also commended the commissioners and the Permanent Secretary, highlighting the ministry's upward trajectory.

In addition, Mugisha proudly recounted the success of the USSSA teams at the ISF football tournament in Rabat City, Morocco. St Noa Girls, Amus College, and Kibuli S.S made Uganda proud, with St Noa clinching the bronze in girls' football. He also announced that the 2024 FEASSSA Games would be hosted by Uganda, specifically in Bukedea, jointly with Amus College School and Bukedea Comprehensive.

The Request

Mugisha earnestly implored for affirmative action in the recruitment, placement, and promotion of games teachers, recognizing their pivotal role in encouraging student participation in sports. His plea underscored the importance of providing opportunities and recognition to educators who nurture sporting talents among students.

FEASSSA 2024

He conveyed to His Excellency the President that Uganda has been awarded the honor of hosting the 2024 FEASSSA Games, which will take place in Bukedea, marking a departure from the traditional Kampala venue. The event will be jointly organized by Amus College School and Bukedea Comprehensive.

The First Lady

The First Lady, Janet Kataha Museveni, and Minister of Education and Sports encouraged students and athletes to consistently strive for the top position. She emphasized that being 3rd or 11th is never enough and urged them to work harder to secure the first position.

"Whenever you are out there know that we have you in our prayers and our thoughts. We appreciate you once again”. concluded the Minister.

His Excellency's Speech

President Yoweri Kaguta Museveni delivered a powerful speech, urging the students to maintain discipline at all times. He emphasized the importance of sports in character-building, cooperation, teamwork, and entertainment for spectators, acknowledging its significant role in providing income for athletes. He congratulated all the medal winners and advised sports leaders to ensure the public understands the value of sports.

The Pledge

In a remarkable pledge, the President promised substantial support to USSSA and the general sports subsector.

  • He committed to providing two sports facilities in each of the 19 USSSA zones, one within schools and another for the general public. Furthermore,
  • He assured USSSA that each zone would receive a bus for convenient transport, and sports teachers and
  • Coaches would receive special consideration regarding additional pay for their invaluable contributions to nurturing young talents.

The event celebrated the outstanding achievements of the USSSA and Athletics teams, recognizing their significant role in developing and showcasing Uganda's sporting talent. President Museveni's presence and his commitment to supporting the sports sector marked a memorable and promising occasion for the future of Ugandan sports.

World 10,000m record holder, Joshua Cheptegei, delivered an inspiring message to the students, emphasizing the importance of self-belief and persistence, underscoring that anyone can achieve success in life. He expressed his gratitude to His Excellency on behalf of all athletes during his vote of thanks.

Notably, one crucial issue remained unaddressed during the President's speech – the matter of affirmative action for teachers in terms of recruitment, deployment, and promotion. This concern highlights the significance of supporting educators who play a vital role in nurturing sporting talents among students.

The Awards

During the ceremony, five schools were specially recognized for their sporting excellence at national, FEASSSA, and Global levels. St Mary’s Boarding School Kitende, Kibuli S.S, St Noa Girls, Kawempe Muslim, and Buddo Secondary School were awarded accolades by His Excellency, President Yoweri Kaguta Museveni, for their exceptional performances.

Dominic Otuchet, President of the Uganda Athletics Federation, expressed his gratitude to Justus Mugisha for his leadership in the early development and subsequent integration of young athletes into the national team. Under Mugisha's guidance, promising talents are nurtured from a young age, enabling them to eventually reach the national team level.

The USSSA stands as a cornerstone for numerous sports federations in the country, providing a fertile ground where a wealth of talented young athletes can access a platform to both exhibit and cultivate their abilities.

post.Title: USSSA Unveils Spectacular Lineup for Major Championships in 2024
post.Content:

  3. ISF World Schools Football World Cup (Dalian, P.R. China): May 17 – 27, 2024
  4. ISF World Schools Basketball Championship (Macao, China): June 23 – July 3, 2024

A Packed Calendar of Activities:

The USSSA activity calendar for 2024 is filled with key events and deadlines leading up to the major championships. Highlights include:

  • October 5-8, 2023: 1st Inspection of Venues - USSSA (Central region)
  • November 5-9, 2023: 1st Inspection of Venues - FEASSA (Uganda)

post.Title: USSSA and USPA Seal Historic Relation in Collaborative Engagement Session
post.Content:
The Uganda Secondary Schools Sports Association (USSSA) marked a significant milestone on Thursday, November 30, 2023, as it successfully solidified a long-term relationship with the Uganda Sports Press Association (USPA). The interactive engagement session, held at the Kati-Kati Restaurant in Kampala, garnered a robust attendance, including key figures such as the Commissioner of Physical Education and Sports, Rev. Canon Dr. Duncans Mugumya, and ASSHU General Secretary Zulaika Nabukeera.

Led by USSSA President Justus Mugisha and USPA President Moses Alysad Lubega, along with their respective executive members, the event provided a platform for fruitful discussions and collaborations. The opening remarks by USSSA CEO Christopher Mugisha Banage set the tone for the engagement, emphasizing USSSA's commitment to innovation and the importance of public understanding of school sports.

Banage stated, "We take this engagement seriously, seeking input from media personnel for the betterment of school sports. School sports serve as a nursery bed for various sports federations in the country."

President Mugisha echoed the sentiment, expressing delight about the newly forged partnership and highlighting USSSA's recent innovations, particularly in capacity building. He outlined key aspects of USSSA, including governance, administration, stakeholders, membership, activities, and focus areas.

President Mugisha: "We have done a lot and feel that this should be reported to the public. We are here to interface with USPA and show them what we are doing. Among the things we have done which are new is capacity building."

USPA President Lubega praised the partnership, emphasizing the interconnectedness of education and sports. He urged positive journalism within the sports ecosystem and acknowledged the unique cognitive benefits that sports bring to students, teachers, parents, and sports fans.

President Lubega: "This partnership is very key and found. We (sports media) appeal strongly to your guidance. Education and sports are quite inter-linked. The cognitive abilities that sports give are the same as sports gives. The audiences are intertwined; parents, teachers, students, and sports fans."

Dr. Rev. Duncans Mugumya, the chief guest, celebrated the official union between USSSA and USPA, drawing inspiration from the Holy Bible (John 15:17). He emphasized the intrinsic motivation sports provide and called for early involvement in talent development.

Dr. Rev. Duncans Mugumya: "Thank God for this official marriage between the media under USPA and USSSA."

ASSHU General Secretary Zulaika Nabukeera commended USSSA for its inclusive approach and urged the involvement of disabled personalities in sports. She thanked President Justus Mugisha for his leadership and acknowledged the support of the Minister of Education and Sports, Mama Janet Museveni.

Zulaika Nabukeera: "Everyone can see the fruits of USSSA. I am seeing a vibrant USSSA, thanks to the efforts of President Justus Mugisha."

In a significant announcement, USSSA introduced the inaugural USSSA Excellence Awards, scheduled for December 15, 2023, at the Imperial Royale Hotel in Kampala. Hajji Twahil Kiteezala, the USSSA's 1st Vice President and Chairman of the Marketing Committee highlighted the growth in the relationship between USPA and USSSA during business times.

Hajji Twahil Kiteezala: "The relationship between USPA and USSSA has always been there. In business times, there has been tremendous growth."

The USSSA Excellence Awards will feature various categories, including Coach of the Year, Sports Teacher of the Year, School of the Year (Boys and Girls), Team of the Year, Fair-Play Award, and Special Recognition Awards. The voting mechanism will involve journalists, sports teachers, team captains, coaches, and an overall technical team, ensuring a comprehensive evaluation of outstanding achievements in school sports.

post.Title: CAF African Schools: SMASK and Kawempe Embark on CECAFA Zonal Qualifiers in Nairobi
post.Content:
Nairobi, Kenya - The excitement is palpable as Team Uganda arrives in Nairobi for the eagerly awaited CAF African Schools CECAFA Zonal Qualifiers Kenya 2023. The formidable delegation comprises Kawempe Muslim SSS (Girls) and St. Mary’s Boarding SS Kitende (Boys), both teams led by the experienced Hajji Hussein Lwebawo.

Ensuring the safety of the players is a top priority, as confirmed by Hajji Hussein Lwebawo, the Leader of the Delegation. "I confirm that our teams are safe and both accommodated at different hotels in Nairobi – Kenya. St. Mary’s Boarding is accommodated at Sun Star Hotel, and Kawempe Muslim SSS is ready to compete after settling in at Utalii Hotel," Lwebawo assured.

The championships, scheduled from December 10th to 13th, 2023, will bring together talented young athletes under the age of 15 from different parts of East Africa, including Uganda, to showcase their skills and passion for football.

Last year's championships saw Royal Giant High School clinching victory in the Boys' category, while Amus College-Bukeddea secured third place in the Girls' category. Kawempe Muslim SSS and St. Mary’s Boarding Kitende earned their places in the CECAFA Zonal Qualifiers Championships after triumphing in the national ball games II tournament held in Kabale for girls and boys, respectively.

Expressing confidence in his team, Male Daniel, the head coach of St. Mary’s Kitende, emphasized the extensive training the team has undergone. "I have prepared enough because we have been working on their attitude and mentality since we are going to a foreign country," said Male upon reaching Kenya.

On the other hand, Moses Nkata, the head coach of Kawempe Muslim, is optimistic about the girls' performance. "Based on the training and the similar weather to that in Uganda, I am sure the performance will be good; we are just waiting for the kick-off," Nkata confirmed.

The leadership of the delegations includes Hajji Hussein Lwebawo, Mutebi Julius as the Media Officer for Kawempe Muslim SSS, and Mulajje Ronald as the Head of Delegation for St. Mary’s Boarding Kitende. With dedicated coaches, trainers, and players on board, Team Uganda is poised for success in the CECAFA Zonal Qualifiers, aiming to make their mark on the international football stage.

post.Title: USSSA Launches Excellence Awards 2023: A Milestone Celebration of School Sports
post.Content:
Kampala, Uganda – November 30, 2023

In a momentous announcement, the Uganda Secondary Schools Sports Association (USSSA) has revealed plans for the inaugural USSSA Excellence Awards, slated to take place on December 15, 2023, at the prestigious Imperial Royale Hotel in Kampala. This grand event marks a significant stride in recognizing and celebrating outstanding achievements in secondary school sports across Uganda.

The Awards were officially launched by USSSA President Justus Mugisha during the USSSA-USPA Media Engagement held at Kati Kati Restaurant, Kampala.

While launching the Awards, Justus Mugisha noted that this is one of the ways USSSA will recognize and promote the young athletes who excel during national and International school sports competitions

Hajji Twahil Kiteezala, the USSSA's 1st Vice President and Chairman of the Marketing Committee, took the stage to emphasize the growing relationship between the Uganda Sports Press Association (USPA) and USSSA during business times.

Kiteezala stated, "The relationship between USPA and USSSA has always been there. In business times, there has been tremendous growth."

The USSSA Excellence Awards will showcase excellence in various categories, honoring the pillars of school sports, including Coaches, Sports Teachers, Schools, Teams, and special acknowledgments for Fair Play. The introduction of these awards reflects USSSA's commitment to recognizing and fostering exceptional talent within the secondary school sports community.

Concept: USSSA Sports Excellence Awards 2023 – Celebrating the Finest from the Best!

Introduction:
The USSSA Sports Excellence Gala 2023 is set to be a grand celebration of talent, dedication, and outstanding achievements in secondary school sports across Uganda. This concept showcases the gala's vision, objectives, and key elements.

Vision:
To create a prestigious and memorable event that recognizes, honors, and inspires excellence in USSSA competitions among coaches, teachers, and student-athletes.

Objectives:

  1. Recognize Outstanding Achievements: Celebrate the remarkable accomplishments of coaches, teachers, and student-athletes who have excelled in their respective sports disciplines during the year 2023.
  2. Inspire Future Success: Motivate and inspire young talents by showcasing the achievements of role models in the field of secondary school sports.
  3. Strengthen USSSA Brand: Elevate USSSA's profile and reputation as a leading authority in secondary school sports through a high-profile event.

Award Categories:

Key Elements:

  1. Event Highlights:
  • Top three nominees for the event
  • Red Carpet Arrival: Create a glamorous red carpet experience for attendees.
  • Awards Ceremony: Recognize and honor winners in each category.
  • Inspirational Speeches: Invite guest speakers to motivate and inspire the audience.
  • Entertainment: Incorporate cultural performances and entertainment.
  1. Nomination and Selection:
  • USSSA will consider a transparent and impartial panel to oversee the nomination and selection process.
  • Nominations from schools, teachers, and coaches.
  • Rigorous evaluation of performance, sportsmanship, and contributions to the sport.
  1. Voting

We shall follow a phased approach

  • First Phase – USSSA releases the list of nominees
  • Second Phase – Voting by sports teachers, team captains, and coaches of all schools that participated in national championships and Journalists to determine the top 5 and 3 for the case of female coaches and sports teachers. (5 days between 30th November to 4th December
  • Third phase – Zones (Chairman, Secretary, and Treasurer) vote to determine the Top 3 between 5th -7th December
  • Fourth Phase – Voted technical from 8th to 10th December

post.Title: USSSA Excellence Awards 2023: Cast Your Vote Now!
post.Content:
Kampla, 4th Dece,ber 2023 - The Uganda Secondary School Sports Association (USSSA) is thrilled to announce the commencement of the voting phase for the USSSA Excellence Awards 2023. This prestigious event aims to recognize and celebrate the outstanding achievements of coaches, sports teachers, and student-athletes in secondary school sports across Uganda.

Voting Process:
The voting process is divided into three phases to ensure a fair and comprehensive selection of the winners.

Phase One (November 4th to December 6th):
During this phase, Headteachers, sports teachers, team captains, and coaches of all schools that participated in national championships, along with journalists, will cast their votes. Each participant is entitled to one vote and must provide their email, contact information, and the name of their school or institution. This phase will determine the top 5 nominees in most categories and the top 3 for female coaches and sports teachers.

To cast your vote, use this form

Phase Two (December 7th to 9th):
In the second phase, Zones, represented by their Chairman, Secretary, and Treasurer, will cast their votes to determine the top 3 finalists in each category.

Phase Three (December 10th to 11th):
The third and final phase will involve technical votes to decide the ultimate winners in each category.

Award Categories and Nominees:
The USSSA Excellence Awards 2023 will honor excellence in nine categories, acknowledging the best in coaching, teaching, and athletic performance. The total number of nominees across categories is 49, showcasing the depth and breadth of talent in secondary school sports.

  • Coach of the Year (Male and Female)
  • Sports Teacher of the Year (Male and Female)
  • Athlete of the Year (Male and Female)
  • School of the Year (Boys and Girls)
  • Team of the Year (Girls and Boys)
  • Fair Play Award (Most disciplined school on and off the pitch)
  • SNEs Award (Best Special Needs School)
  • Primary Schools (Represented Uganda and won in FEASSSA 2023 - Huye, Rwanda)

Criteria for Voting:
Participants are requested to adhere to the criteria for voting, which includes submitting only one vote per person, along with providing their email, contact details, and school or institution affiliation.

Join the Celebration:
The USSSA Excellence Awards 2023 will culminate in a grand gala at the Imperial Royale Hotel on Friday, December 15th, 2023, starting at 2:00 pm. Join us as we celebrate the finest from the best in Uganda's secondary school sports. Your vote counts, so be sure to cast it and be a part of this momentous occasion!

post.Title: Murungi Diana FIFA football referee on her Interest in Netball Coaching.
First Aid and Injury management now part of the USSSA Capacity Building Programme.
post.Content:
This is a new course that has been introduced in the second year of the capacity building training.The training is taking place at Kibuli SS in Kampala between 10th to 17th December,2023.

Gabriel Isaac Otuk, the founder and CEO Fitness Health and Nutrition Sports is the instructor of this course.

Otuk expressed his appreciation to Uganda Secondary School Sports Association  as a stakeholder for working together with FHNS in the promotion of health and safety through education and idea sharing.

“I humbly hope that it can provide the platform for technical personnel working with coaches/trainers/nurses/physiotherapists/physical education/teachers/doctors/medical first aiders including fellow athletes/referees and umpires to understand the key concepts in injury causation/risk factors / emergency care and optimization of injury prevention strategies in long term athlete development”.

Nakanwagi Annet, a nurse from Wakiso is one of the participants and while she is already working with a few rugby players she is looking forward to learn how injuries in other sports are handled.

“I am here to achieve more knowledge on how to handle different injuries on the pitch and am very expectant because I know everything is going to go well.” said Nakanwagi.

The training will end on 17th December 2023 and resume in January 2024.Other disciplines include Football, Netball,Volleyball,Athletics these are for coaches and referees or umpires.

post.Title: USSSA Capacity Building: December Workshops Get Underway in Three Venues.
post.Content:
The Uganda Secondary School Sports Association Capacity Building has started at three venues across the country.

The participants who arrived on 10th December 2023 are to both study and reside at Kibuli SS in Kampala, Ntare School in Mbarara, and Lira Town College in Lira.

The inaugural training was held at Kibuli SS in December 2022 and January 2023. It was later rolled out to Teso Region in February 2023 at Teso College Aloet and Mbarara to Primary school Teachers at St. Mary’s Vocational School in September 2023.

The participants who arrived on 10th December 2023 are to both study and reside at Kibuli SS in Kampala, Ntare School in Mbarara, and Lira Town College in Lira.

The training that starts on 11th December will end on 17th December where participants will be awarded certificates of attendance and merit by the respective federations.

Participants will be trained in several disciplines as coaches or referees in Netball, Athletics, Volleyball, Handball, and Media.

The centers in Mbarara and Lira are facilitating only football coaching and refereeing while all those in other disciplines are at Kibuli SS.

A total of 298 participants had arrived by Sunday evening with football coaching and refereeing having the highest numbers at 60 and 70 respectively. There are 66 participants in Lira while Mbarara has 97 both for football coaching and refereeing.

A new course has been introduced in First Aid and Injury under the instruction of Isaac Gabriel Otuk of the Fitness Health and Nutrition Sports (FHNS) Brand. An entity that ensures not only player safety but also looks to skill the fans that surround these sports. FHNS also seeks to see that stakeholders have access to health care services.

Nakanwagi Annet a nurse from Wakiso expects to get a better understanding of how to handle Injuries in other sports.

“I work as a nurse  in rugby but I would like to learn how different sports injuries are handled especially on the pitch.” Said Nakanwagi.

Murungi Diana is a participant from Kabarole and  FIFA Referee who is training in Netball Coaching where she would like to understand the basic coaching skills and techniques.

“I would like to understand better the usage of digital media in the modern world ”Nankya Sauda, a teacher of English and Literature at Kawanda SS.

The training will continue in January 2024 in Gulu, Arua, and Kampala as communication will be made.

The instructors

Netball Coaching - Kaala Rosette

Netball Refereeing - Nassanga Zubedah

Football Coaching - Nantanda Majidah (Kibuli SS)

Namuyanja Hadijah (Mbarara )

Kizza Sharon (Lira)

Football Refereeing- Egesa W Samuel ( Mbarara)

                                  Ayub Khamish ( Lira )

                                  Sheikh Matovu Sulaiman

Athletics Coaching - Abdallah Muhammed

Athletics Officiating - Mukasa Henry

First Aid and Injury- Otuk Gabriel Isaac

Volleyball Umpring -Komakech Innocent

Media - Alex Kasirye

post.Title: 180 participants in Mbarara and Lira for Football Coaching and Refereeing.
post.Content:
The USSSA Capacity building programme is taking place at in Mbarara and Lira at Ntare School and Lira Town College respectively.

Over 180 participants in both venues are being trained in football coaching or refereeing.

The training is being conducted by FUFA and FIFA accredited instructors Hadijah Namuyanja and Egesa W Samuel are in Mbarara while Kiiza Sharon and Ayub Khamis are in Lira respectively.

This the fourth time time the programme has been carried out  in districts outside Kampala after Teso Region in February 2023,Kabale-July 2023 and Mbarara September 2023.

Participants are from several districts namely Kitagwenda,Kabale,Kazo,Rukungiri,Kiruhura,Kasese,Bundibugyo,Ntungamo,Kamwenge,Agago,Gulu,Lira,Apac,Amolator,Dokolo,Masindi,Otuke,Masindi,Oyam and Alebtong.

What the participants Said

Lira

Emmy Opio a teacher at Livingstone Christian School in Gulu attending a refereeing course

“I believe my understanding of the game and its laws will improve and eventually my match officiation”.

“I feel am being well equipped with information then I hope to officiate a few games this Christmas for practice.”

Sarah Okurut a student at Aye Seed,Nkware.

“The training of coaches and referees is moving on well and succesfully and I believe my students and teachers will benefit a lot ,I hope good referees and coaches will come from them which will benefit the region” Acen Sophia Rose, Headteacher Lira Town College.

Mbarara

“I hope to improve on my football skills and also encourage others to come for training and I thank USSSA for organizing this programme”.Tumusiime Adela,a student at St. Mary’s College Rushoroza.

“I am very happy that very many ladies have turned and I hope that we will go back and improve on Girls’ football from the grassroots since we were lacking the basics”. Tumushabe Innocent, teacher at St. Gerald’s SS Nyakibare.

“The Capacity Programme will enable teachers to go back and train their own students.This will also behefit not only students but the community at large”.Kyojjo Elly,a teacher at Kazo SS.

post.Title: USSSA Capacity Buidling Training at Kibuli SS 2023/2024 in Pictures.
