post.Title: 2024 USSSA National Boys Football groups confirmed
post.Content:
The 2024 Uganda Secondary Schools Sports Association (USSSA) National Boys Football groups have been confirmed after draws held at the headquarters in Old Kampala on Thursday.

The draws were held by USSSA communications manager Bosco Omario, Ayub Khalifa and other selected members who had attended the event.

The 2024 USSSA National Boys will witness 16 groups and each will have four schools. At this stage each school will play three games and the top two schools will go straight to the round of 32.

Defending champions St Mary’s Kitende have been drawn in Group A with Kisozi Seed School, Mbale Progressive and Ngora High School.

Hosts, Masaka SS are pitted in Group O alongside Andy Mwesigwa, Welden School and Makobere.

Last year’s runners up St Hery Kitovu are in Group P alongside Kabalega Secondary School, Kobulubulu Secondary School and Hillview College - Bulangira.

The tournament will kick off on Saturday April 26 until Sunday May 6 at Masaka Secondary School.

post.Title: LET STUDENTS PLAY WITH STUDENTS!
post.Content:
Police now to help in the fight against impersonators, none bona-fide, and over aged players in school sport.

In 2022, when the present USSSA executive committee was elected, it set its number one objective, riding school sport of impersonators, none bona-fide, and over-age players in school sports. Luckily, this resonated well with ASSHU, PES, and the Ministry of Education and Sports. The Parliament of Uganda has also joined the fight by enacting a law that criminalizes the above and sets very serious sanctions to the offenders.

Since 2022, USSSA has strengthened rules and regulations to ensure that real students of actual age participate in school games.

In 2023, a student registration system was introduced to help in the fight and overtime, new guidelines for registration, screening of players, and sanctioning of offending schools, administrators, and players.

Unfortunately, organizers at some districts and zones decided to disregard the set regulations and guidelines. In the end, many teams have been declared to represent zones in the national games by fielding those who do not qualify to play in students' games.

In the pre tournament screening exercise at the USSSA head office, a number of teams failed to raise the necessary 20 students to participate in the national games.

Any team that presents 5 or more students that do not qualify may be disqualified from participating in the national games . Additionally, as sanction to the zone that presents such a team, A slot is lost to other zones with clean teams. It's hoped that these measures will force those zones to be more serious in implementing USSSA rules, regulations and guidelines in future.

Pre tournament screening involves scrutinizing the original documents of players and subjecting them to EMIS, UNEB, national federations and where possible, NIRA registration systems. Any discrepancy in these may lead to disqualification of a player and / or a school team in line with tournament rules and regulations.

Pre tournament screening will be followed by physical screening at the tournament venue.

We have strict instructions from the minister of state for education and sports Hon Peter Ogwang to refer cases of impersonation to police. We made arrangements to have police at the screening venues at Masaka SSS and Ndejje SS, who will handle such cases. Head Teachers, Games teachers, and coaches are hereby requested to be more careful with the team they present.

Finally, students of actual age have a chance to participate in their games

Justus Mugisha.
President USSSA.

post.Title: Football Boys 2024:Countdown to glory! Matchday 1 in Masaka is here.
post.Content:
Following successful completion of the USSSA Qualifiers for the National Boys Football championship- Masaka 2024, the wait for this year's biggest school football showpiece is over.

The draws for the boys Nationals were held at USSSA head offices in Old Kampala on Friday and fixtures drafted there after.

All is set in Masaka as teams reported and pre-tournament screening occured at host school Masaka SS on Friday 26th April.

Day one will see plenty of eye watering clashes in Masaka City.

2023 champions also Wakiso zone champions 2024, St. Mary's Boarding School Kitende will start their pursue of defending their trophy as they go head to head with Kisozi Seed Secondary School in group A.

Hosts Masaka Secondary School will later entertain Ankole Zone's Welden School Mbarara at Kitovu 1 playground in the bid to top group O.

Meanwhile, Elite Games 2024 winners Jinja Progressive Academy doodled in group M will aim to extend their dominance to the National stage as they lock horns with Kampala's Uganda Martyrs High School Lubaga in a midday encounter while Kampala zone champions Kibuli SS welcome St. Augustine Minor Seminary in a game that will be played at Masaka SS ground.

Match day one will see a total of 32 games played at different venues which include Muteesa-1 Royal, Kitovu 1 and 2, Sports Arena, Nyendo Kasana, Technical Ground, Paul and Pauline ground, Mpunga- Arena Masaka and Masaka recreation grounds.

The National Boys Football championship will come to a close on 5th May 2024 but who will lift gold in Masaka?

St. Julian Seeta started off on a high note beating St Kagwa Bushenyi 6-0 the biggest margin on day one in a match that was played at Kitovu 1 ground.

St. Mary's Boarding School kitende needed extra magic from former Buddo SS starlet Denis Kisiriko to break down a resilient Kisozi Seed.

post.Title: USSSA Games: Denis Kisiriko guides Kitende past resilient Kisozi Seed
post.Content:
Denis Kisiriko’s lonely strike helped St Mary’s Kitende secure a 1-0 victory past resilient Kisozi Seed School in the ongoing 2024 USSSA Games at Masaka Recreational Centre on Saturday.

The games kicked off late as the secretariat delayed a bit to get done with screening though at exactly 2:00 PM were underway at Masaka Recreational Centre.

Kitende started on the front foot seeking an early lead but Kisozi Seed’s backline was well-organised.

But before the break, the holders increased pace upfront as Hassan Mubiru gave a hard time to Kisozi’s hardworking backline.

Kisiriko once again staged his poaching skills as he fired the holders in the lead from close range.

Kisozi Seed School will have several lessons to pick from because their backline looked decent against a star-studded backline.

After the game, Kisiriko revealed that his target is to take home the top scorer’s gong just like it was in the Wakiso Regional Qualifiers.

“I am longing to score more goals so that I can get the Golden Boot,” the forward stated.

“However the priority is to score goals that help the team because our target is to defend the trophy and am confident we can do it,” he added.

Kitende are the defending champions of this championship having edged St Henry’s Kitovu 1-0 in last year’s final.

However, they are also record 11 times champions sharing the throne with arch-rivals Kibuli Secondary School.

post.Title: USSSA Games: Amus set campaign target after slim victory against Ryakasinga
post.Content:
Amus College School secured a hard fought 1-0 victory against Ryakasinga in the ongoing 2024 USSSA Games at St Kitovu ground one on Saturday evening.

Hakim Musaba broke the deadlock in the 65th minute with a simple tap in after Ryakasinga’s custodian failed to grip a long range free kick.

Amus College created several chances but were not lethal enough and found themselves struggling to take the lead in a game they had an upper hand.

After the full-time whistle, Amus head coach Nimrod Kintu revealed that amidst a poor start the target for this year’s championship is to lift the trophy.

“We did not have the best game today but what matters is attaining maximum points,” Kintu told USSSA Media.

“We shall continue preparing the boys because I know how good they are. I will continue to remind you that this year we want the trophy,” he added.

“If we managed to reach the semifinals last year, then we only have to work on our mistakes and see that we perform better because we have all it takes.”

Amus will return to action on day two as they take on Madox Secondary School at Sports Arena.

post.Title: MEET Kasozi Ramathan Standard High School Zzana’s youngest-ever player in the ISF World School Volleyball Championship.
post.Content:
Standard High School Zzana’s Kasozi Ramathan who made International Schools Federation history in Belgrade -Serbia as he became the youngest-ever player in the ISF World School Volleyball Championship.

The young libero has featured at the international championship at only 14 years and 200 days old

His coach at Standard High School Zzana Richard Olupot says there is a bright future for the younger star, he sees him as one of the next pillars of the STAHIZA volleyball team

"My dream is to become a professional volleyballer, i want to play at national and international leagues but also I dream of representing my country on the national team" Ramathan Kasozi Revealed.

Who is Kasozi
1 –Kasozi Ramathan was born on July 10, 2009 at Kikomeko Village, Luweero district.

2 – He completed primary school at Murchison Bay Primary - Luzira.

3 – He started training Volleyball just for fun during his primary vacation.

4– He joined Standard High School Zzana in 2024 and is a senior one C student.

post.Title: USSSA Games: Paidha SS hold St Juliana Seeta
post.Content:
Paidha Secondary School and St Juliana Seeta shared spoils after one-all stalemate in the ongoing 2024 USSSA National Games on Sunday evening.

Simon Wanyama scored for St Juliana Seeta in the first stanza before Paidha SS leveled matters in the second stanza.

The game delayed by 20 minutes but as soon as Paidha Secondary School arrived at the ground they were sent onto the green.

Suprisingly, even without warming up Paidha SS started on the front foot creating several chances but hardly utilized their chances.

James Ssekate thought he had given St Juliana the lead but it was flagged offside as he wheeled away into celebrations.

Simon Wanyama finally broke the deadlock, shirt 9 won possession before he laid a cut back. Ssekate’s effort was blocked by the custodian before Wanyama tapped home from close range.

Five minutes into the second stanza, Javine Mungdit leveled matters with an easy finish after St Julian failed to clear their lines.

In the final minutes it was one way traffic as St Julian threw all bodies upfront to regain their lead but Paidha SS stood tall to ensure they secure the golden point.

post.Title: USSSA Games: STAHIZA register two victories on Day II
post.Content:
Standard High Zzana secured two victories in the two games they played on day two of the ongoing 2024 USSSA Games in Masaka on Sunday.

In the morning, STAHIZA edged Luwero SS in a 2-1 victory during an encounter played at Masaka Secondary School play ground.

Christine Nuwagaba and Sharif Sizza gave STAHIZA a 2-0 lead at the end of the first stanza before Luwero SS pulled back one from the spot.

In their second game of the day, STAHIZA secured a well deserved 4-1 victory against Wisdom High School.

Christian Nuwagaba, Benon Lutaaya, Emmanuel Ambayo, and David Mwebaze  scored STAHIZA’s goals before Wisdom HS pulled back one late in the game.

In the post match interview, Lutaya revealed that he longs to guide his team to the East Africa Games.

“I am glad that I scored today. I look forward to score more so that the team can qualify for East Africa games,” he stated.

“We have one target and that winning one game at a time. We know that all teams here are good but we are equally good and so we have to fight for the team,” he added.

Lutaya also added that the strikers have to work on their final touch so that they convert more.

“It’s sad that we score less yet we create a number of chances. We have to work on our final touch and chemistry in the final third so that we can score more goals.”

post.Title: Contrasting results in boys' basketball at 2024 FResh dairy secondary school games
post.Content:
The boys' basketball for the 2024 Fresh Dairy Secondary School Games officially threw off at Janan SS courts on Sunday, 28th April.

Thrilling action that composed of enticing dribbles, take-ons, dunks, free throws and eye-catching passes were witnessed under sunny conditions with a good crowd cheering on.

Defending champions (Boys) Buddo Secondary School earned two victories; 53-16 and 34-14 over Masaka SS and Kibuli SS respectively.

Buddo who are coached by John Omondi relied on the expertise and magic of different players as Kok, Anyunva, Luc and Ajang among others.

"We are approaching a day at a time. The players are ready for the title defence" Omondi spoke to USSSA media after their "sweet" win over rivals Kibuli SS.

In some of the other results, Mbogo Mixed defeated Kabalega 36-24, Elite won 32-22 over St Andrew Kaggwa, Amus College overcame Kabalega 30-17 and St Cyprian Kyabakadde overcame Ndejje SS 38-22.

Match day two of boy's basketball will be played on Monday, 29th April 2024.

post.Title: USSSA Games: Blessed Sacrament seal group stage with victory against Highway Kiganda
post.Content:
Blessed Sacrament Kimanya secured a well-deserved 3-0 victory against Highway Kiganda in the ongoing 2024 USSSA Games at Sports Arena on Monday evening.

Blessed Sacrament played their last group game with a lot of swag and confidence as they secured the third win in as many games played.

Patrick Mark Kafeero fired Blessed Sacrament ahead with a direct free kick that left Highway’s custodian totally beaten.

Before the end of the first stanza, Joel Kyeyune doubled Blessed Sacrament’s victory with a simple tap in from close range after a team attack.

Blessed Sacrament went into the second stanza with a man less, not because they received a red but the coach decided to play the other 35 minutes with 10 players.

Even with a man less, Blessed Sacrament extended their lead with Arnold Kayemba’s spectacular finish that left Highway’s backline helpless on the floor.

After the final whistle, Blessed Sacrament head coach Abby Kakumirizi revealed that they are happy to qualify for the round of 32 however they will take one game at a time.

“We are happy to reach this level (round of 32) because it has not been an easy journey to reach this far,” he stated.

“I want to thank the players that have put up a great show to win three games in the group. We don’t want to say that now the target is to win the trophy because want to plan for one game at a time,” he added.

The gaffer also added that playing the second half with a man less was intentional because they wanted to reduce the tempo of the game and resort to possession.

Blessed Sacrament Kimanya will return to action on Wednesday as they play at the round of 32 in the ongoing championship.

post.Title: FRESH DAIRY GAMES: Commissioner Physical Education and Sports gives hopes to sports students.
post.Content:
By Arnold Mukwaya

During the opening ceremony of this year's fresh dairy on Monday 29th April, the commissioner Emphasized that only bona-fide students should participate in school sports. "we believe that by 20 years someone is already done with A'level and someone beyond 20 years does not qualify to be in secondary since we believe that it's automatic promotion" Commissioner physical education and Sports Dr Rev Canon Duncan Mugumya.

He also said that no school should be banned for having non bona-fide players instead the head teacher of the school should be arrested and tried because the sports the sports act provides guidelines to follow and to protect the athletes.


"We wouldn't like to see a school being banned and other bona-fide players from that school loose the opportunity to participate in the national tournament which is very important since one will be awarded 4 free points as he/she joins University" he said
In 2023, a student registration system was introduced to help in the fight and overtime, new guidelines for registration, screening of players, and sanctioning of offending schools, administrators, and Players though over school so a lot of forgery and bribery.

The commissioner also advised local leaders to take part in the fighting of the vice and reporting the culprits to the police since screening will be done when police is available

The commissioner also appreciated the host head teacher who is to retire in the next 6 days and the administration of Ndejje University for good job done in making the championship successful

post.Title: USSSA GAMES: Official Opening ceremony of National Boys Football Championship as it happened.
post.Content: The USSSA National Boys Football championship officially got underway in Masaka graced by the chief guest State minister of Sports Hon. Peter Ogwang

post.Title: Hon Ogwang officially opens the 2024 USSSA National Games
post.Content:
The Minister of State for Sports, Peter Ogwang has officially opened the 2024 USSSA National Games.

The opening ceremony took place at Masaka Secondary School ground on Tuesday, April 30, 2024.

The ceremony was attended by different dignitaries including Ogwang, National Council of Sports General Secretary Dr Benard Patrick Ogwal and USSSA President Justus Mugisha.

The guest of honor Ogwang expressed his gratitude and appreciation to the well-established structure of sports management at secondary schools’ level.

“I commend the well established structure of sports management at secondary schools’ level, that is yielding good fruits by nurturing talent in various sports disciplines across the country,” he stated.

“I specifically recognize and appreciate the contribution of the schools’ management towards these championships. I know it’s quite difficult for you given the hard economic times, but you have managed to shoulder through,” he added.

“I would want to also thank the participating schools who have taken this component of co curricular activities are mandatory on the school’s program for all secondary schools.”

In the same breath, USSSA President Mugisha welcomed the athletes but sounded strong on the issue of age cheating.

“The Minister (Ogwang) questioned me to ensure that we use only school going students in this championship and I must say we have tried our best to curb the vice,” he said.

“But like you all know since cancer lands somewhere it’s not easy to fight it. Allow me remind those that are still practicing the vice that their days are numbered,” he added.

The third USSSA Vice President, Harriet Margaret Apolot cautioned the athletes to maintain discipline but also work hard to take up the slots for representing the country at a higher stage.

The tournament will continue to day five (Wednesday) as the round of 32 finally gets underway.

post.Title: USSSA GAMES: Round of 32 looms in Masaka.

Elsewhere, Jinja Progressive Academy beat Koch SS earlier in a game played at Kitovu 1 ground to come out of their group invicible having won three in as many games.

The round of 32 kick-starts on 1st May with defending champions St. Mary's Boarding School Kitende battling with St. Charles Lwanga Kasasa at 9:00 at Masaka recreation grounds.

Buddo SS will meet Bukedea Comprehensive at the round of 32 having beaten Kakungulu Memorial School 3-0 in their last group encounter.

post.Title: USSSA GAMES: Defending champions through to the round of 16.
Fresh Dairy Secondary Schools Games 2024 in thrilling climax
post.Content:
As the different schools have continued to exhibit sporting excellence, resilience, determination and gravel at the 2024 Fresh Dairy Secondary Schools games, there have been plenty of take-aways.

Over the past 7 days, there has been thrilling action in football (girls), basketball (Boys and girls), Table Tennis (boys and girls), rugby 15's (boys and girls), hockey (boys and girls) as well as badminton.

The sports facilities at host school; Ndejje SS, Ndejje University, Ndejje community and St Janan SS have been busy with vigorous action.

It is the final bend of the championship and Saturday, 4th May 2024 will virtually be the last day of action with all sports concluding business.

The stage is set to have the different finals and last classification duels to determine who takes home the gold, silver and bronze respectively.

Sporting egos will be solved and finally be put to bed, giants determined and crowned as the action winds down.

From the basketball action on the Ndejje SS courts to Hockey ground, Rugby field, Badminton and Table Tennis playing halls, the final thick of action is Saturday as the curtains to this year's edition of games will majestically be brought down.

Some of the closing games:

Kakungulu Memorial School will play Ntare School in boys' Hockey final. Another Kakungulu Memorial School team is also set for the final in the female docket against Bweranyangi Girls School.

Badminton finals has Kibuli SS against Kakungulu Memorial (boys) whilst Rubaga Girls will face Mbogo High School.

St Mary's College Kisubi (SMACK) and Kings College Budo will vie for gold in boy's rugby.

In Table Tennis; Kibuli SS will battle Mbogo Mixed in boy's finale with Kibuli SS taking on Mbogo College for the girls.

post.Title: USSSA Games: Amus Rout Paidha As Musaaba Nets Five
post.Content:
On Wednesday evening, Amus College secured a 5-0 victory against Paidha SS in the ongoing 2024 USSSA Games encounter at Muteesa Royal University Grounds.

Hakim Musaaba was the hero scoring five to ensure that Amus secured a spot in the round of 16 in the ongoing championship.

The youngster has written his name in the history box because he scored his second hat trick in the four games played thus far.

With four wins in as many games played, Amus have been tagged favorites of the championship since they have so far scored 23 goals and conceded one in four games.

Elsewhere, the holders St Mary’s Kitende edged St Charles Lwanga, Kasasa after a 2-0 victory in a game played at Masaka Recreational Grounds.

It was party mood as usual at Kitovu Ground One as Blessed Sacrament Kimanya squeezed past Kakungulu Memorial in a 2-1 win.

Like the norm, the crowd was huge as the natives turned up in high numbers to rally behind the local boys who were playing good football.

After a goalless draw, Patrick Kafeero fired Kimanya ahead in the 49th minute before Ahmed Kintu restored parity for Kakangulu.

With ten mutes left on the clock, Najib Taaali tapped into an empty net as Kimanya regained their lead before the ground erupted in celebrations.

Last year’s losing finalists, St Henry’s Kitovu were ejected by hosts Masaka Secondary Secondary in a 4-3 shootout after a goalless draw in normal time.

post.Title: USSSA Games: Kabalega SS believe after qualifying for round of 16

Kabalega Secondary School secured a spot in the round of 16 after edging Welden Secondary School 4-3 in a penalty shootout.

After a goalless draw in normal time, Kabalega SS held their nerves and secured a much-deserved victory on the day.

Kabalega SS, located in the Bunyoro Zone is making waves in the ongoing 2024 USSSA National Games after managing to be part of the last 16.

With the gaffer Ali at the helm, the boys have shown great determination and their style of play has gained them several fans each time they step on the green.

One of the factors contributing to the success of the team has been the tremendous support and guidance of the old boys of Kabalega SS under the umbrella known as KASSOBA (Kabalega Secondary School Old Boys Association).

KASSOBA has been instrumental in promoting sports in the school by providing the necessary resources for the team to excel.

post.Title: USSSA GAMES: Giants sent packing at the round of 16 in Masaka.
post.Content:
2024 might have just started in May for the people in Masaka City! The USSSA National Boys Football Championiship has brought back those happy days to their faces as the intensity in the quest for glory has significantly increased.

The round of 16 was not the best of days for Kampala zone finalists Kawempe Muslim SS as their FEASSSA hopes were ended by a surprisingly high spirited Kisozi Seed SS.

Kawempe Muslim SS got off to a flying start as they scored in the opening minutes of the game played at Muteesa stadium thanks to an Alvin Kitibwa well timed header in the fifth minute.

Kisozi Seed managed to come back from behind twice in a game that bared end to end action salvaging a two all draw. Kisozi Seed got the better of Kawempe Muslim in the penalty shootouts winning 5-4 to storm the quarter finals.

In the other last 16 ties, Amus College School crumbled against a much improved Jinja SS side in a game they could have easily killed off in the first half. Jinja SS were awarded a penalty in the closing stages of the game after Amus captain Toto Majub poorly timed his clearance and kicked Jinja SS player inside the forbidden area.

Toto Majub later missed a spot kick for Amus which sent the crowds into wild celebrations at Sports Arena- Masaka

The quarter finals and semi-finals come on Friday, alongside other classification duels ahead of grand climax on Saturday.

post.Title: USSSA GAMES: Semifinal bash in Masaka.
USSSA Games: Kitende bring Kimanya's fairytale to an end
post.Content:
St Mary's Kitende secured a 2-0 victory against Blessed Sacrament Kimanya in the ongoing 2024 USSSA Games at Sports Arena on Friday.

Fans' favourite Blessed Sacrament Kimanya was ejected from the tournament thanks to St Mary's Kitende's well-deserved victory.

Kitende took an early lead through Isa Bugembe who nodded home Hassan Mubiru's delivery in the sixth minute.

Despite being a goal down, Kimanya kept composed and tried to build from the back but was challenged by a waterlogged pitch.

Bugembe nearly doubled Kitende's lead but narrowly missed to connect with Hakim Mutebi's delightful finish.

Eight minutes to the break, towering defender Ronald Madoi scored Kitende's second goal with a powerful header off Mutebi's header.

Despite the mammoth crowd and chants, Kimanya was trailing by two goals at halftime.

In the 50th minute, Denis Kisiriko failed to convert from close range with only a goalkeeper to beat.

In the final minutes, second-half substitute Arafat Nkoola went past Kitende's backline but his resultant effort bounced off the frame.

After the final whistle, Kitende's head coach Daniel Male revealed that they were prepared to play in front of a huge crowd and take away their chances.

"It's been a tough game since we were against a home team that was backed up by a huge crowd. But we came prepared and we had to take away our chances," he said.

"We knew their backline is made up of short players and so we resorted to long balls that yielded two goals before the break," he added.

"We now shift our attention to the next game because each game matters till the end of the tournament. I will keep rallying the boys to fight so that we defend the title."

USSSA Games | Quarterfinals

  • St Mary's Kitende 2-0 Blessed Sacrament
  • Amus College 0-3 Jinja Progressive
  • St Juliana 0(3)-0(2) Masaka SS
  • Bukedea Comprehensive 0(5)-0(4) Kisozi Seed

post.Title: USSSA Games: Amus College knock out holders St Mary's Kitende
post.Content:
USSSA Games | Semifinals

  • Amus College 0(10)-0(9) St Mary's Kitende
  • St Julian 0(4)-0(2) Bukedea Comprehensive

Amus College knocked out holders St Mary's Secondary School, Kitende after a successful shootout in the 2024 USSSA Games on Saturday.

The two sides were held in a goalless draw in normal time before Amus College secured all the bragging rights.

It was the repeat of last year's final though this time round, Nimrod Kintu's charges came out of the kiln victorious.

Kitende were the better side as they pegged Amus College on the back foot however the latter was composed and stood tall all throughout the duel.

Isa Bugembe nearly fired Kitende ahead but his header was cleared off the line as they kept knocking on the door.

Steven Yige set up Denis Kisiriko in the dying minutes but the forward failed to connect with the ball by inches.

And after a tense game of 70 minutes, the two sides were sent in spot kicks to decide who would continue to the final of the ongoing tournament.

Genesis Odiya, Abdurazak Muzamir, Sam Owalamu, Toto Najub, John Otim, Christopher Lubulwa, Idd Rashid Juma, Musa Masengere and Alvin Ssekamatte scored Amus'penalties.

Isa Bugembe, Olimi Nyarwa, Ronald Madoi, Abubaker Walusimbi, Simon Mukisa, Juma Ssajjabi, Denis Kisiriko, Steven Yiga and Simon Mubiru scored for Kitende from the spot.

Second-half substitute Jamal Ssemwogerere's penalty was thwarted away as the holders were sent packing.

post.Title: Ssekate Steals Show As St Julian Stun Amus To Clinch USSSA Title
post.Content:
USSSA Games |Final

  • St Julian 3-0 Amus College

St Julian Seeta clinched the title as champions of the 2024 USSSA Games after humbling Amus College in a 3-0 victory at Mpungu Arena in Masaka on Sunday.

James Ssekate (brace) and Simon Wanyama scored the goals as St Julian lifted the title on their first attempt.

Patrick Ssenkusu nearly fired St Julian ahead in the ninth minute but the early effort was cleared off the line.

Six minutes later, Ssekate broke the deadlock with an easy tap-in from close range after goalkeeper Ben Sinalya fumbled with Elisa Mukasa’s powerful effort.

Ssekamate doubled St Juliana’s lead in the 20th minute with an easy tap-in from close range after Amus’ backline failed to clear their lines.

Amus tried to respond but St Julian was well organised at the back holding onto their 2-0 lead into the break.

In the second half, Amus threw bodies upfront trying to pull back one but failed to put the ball on target.

Devis Busulwa’s header and Samuel Owalamu’s effort from close range went wide of the target as Amus College tried to launch a comeback.

With 15 minutes on the clock, Toto Majub denied a goal-bound effort with his hand before he was sent off.

Wanyama stepped up and converted from the 12-yard mark to extend St Julian’s well-deserved lead.

To reach the finals, St Julian eliminated Bukedea Comprehensive on penalties while Amus College knocked out holders St Mary’s Kitende.

Tournament Awards

  • MVP: Isma Magala (Blessed Sacrament Kimanya)
  • Top Scorer: Hakim Musaaba (Amus College) - 11 goals
  • Best Goalkeeper: Denis Mugerwa (St Mary’s Kitende) - Concended only one goal

post.Title: USSSA GAMES: Boys Football Champions, St Julian Holds Trophy Parade in Mukono.
post.Content:
The 2024 Uganda Secondary Schools Sports Association Boys Football champions, St Julian High School Seeta held a trophy parade in their locality on Monday as they were celebrating their milestone.

St Julian beat Amus College 3-0 in the final held at Masaka SS in Masaka City on Sunday.

The team paraded the trophy from the school campus in Lumuli, through Seeta town, Mukono Kawuga, Mukono City and the parade climaxed at the District headquarters where they were received by the area deputy RDC.

Every one who got a chance to have the microphone, sang praises to Julian for ending the 22 years trophy drought in the district.

"For a very long time, Mukono District has cried and cried like Arsenal but now we smile, we thank St Julian for bringing us this long awaited joy and victory, I was reading it in news that schools have been using "bacuba" but i thank you that you have used the rightful players and again, you won. This is the first day of celebration but again this is a full year of celebration and we are going to come to St Julian to celebrate with you officially." Mukono District Deputy RDC, Micheal Ssegawa.

In the same line, the Association of secondary schools head teachers in Uganda, Mukono District representative, Gordon Katindo also thanked the School for ending the cry of Mukono people.

"This is the first trophy we're raising for the first time after 22 years of drought, so St Julian we're proud of you. Now you have been the national champions, we want you to win the East Africa championship." says, Gordon Katindo who represented Association of Secondary Schools Head teachers of Uganda in Mukono District.

The regional chairman, Richard Muhumuza also thanked Julian as well as promising the area that they will try their best to see that they retain the trophy.

"I want to thank the director, it's amazing, St Julian has represented Mukono and returned with the trophy in the first year, we want to work very hard to see that we maintain this trophy, we had three slots but now we have four slots because of St Julian, so I want to thank them very much for giving us this glory." Said Greater Mukono Region chairperson, Richard Muhumuza.

The School's director, Jeff Sserunjogi revealed that they are immediately starting preparation for the FEASSSA games slated to take place in late August 2024 in Bukedea.

Naggalama Islamic was the last school to win Mukono a trophy way back in 2002.

Source: Mbuga Swaibu

post.Title: TEAM UGANDA READY TO DEFEND ISF WORLD SCHOOL CROSSCOUNTRY CHAMPIONSHIP IN NAIROBI.
post.Content:
Team Uganda is ready for the World School Cross Country Championship according to coach Raphael Kasajja.

Uganda are the defending Champions from the previous edition that was held in Slovakia and this time round they boast of a bigger team according to head coach,Raphael Kassaja.

"In Slovakia we only had the under 18 team but we won the championship, this time round we have six teams in 3 categories and we are here to take back what we believe is ours". Coach Kasajja said after a training session held at Nairobi School this morning.

Team Uganda is comprised of 3 age categories 12,under 15 and under 18 with each category being represented by both boys and girls.

The event format is individual competition/ team ranking.

The students to take part in the Championship were selected after a training camp that was held by USSSA in January 2024 and they are from districts of Kween,Kapchorwa,Bukwo and Nakapiripirit.

Prior to the Championship another training camp was held at St. Peter's College Tororo for 2 weeks.
Uganda are the defending Champions from the previous edition that was held in Slovakia and this time round they boast of a bigger team according to head coach,Raphael Kassaja.

"We know we shall have challenge from the Kenyans as usual but we are ready for them, set and good to go". Concluded Coach Kasajja.

Races
Under 12
Boys 1000-1200m
Girls 1000-1200m

Under 15
Boys 3000-3500m
Girls 2000-2500m

Under 18
Boys 5000-5500m
Girls 3000-3500m

The competition will be run according to the current ISF and World Athletics rules under the ISF Technical Commission.

Four best runners from every country will score for the team rankings.

post.Title: Team Uganda shines at ISF World School Crosscountry Championship in Nairobi.
post.Content:
The Ngong race course was the venue for the much anticipated event that saw Uganda among the 8 African countries to take part.

Nigeria, Namibia, Morocco, Tanzania,Kenya,Rwanda and hosts Kenya were the other African countries present.

Kenya had a clean sweep of all individual except for one, where Uganda won a bronze in boys under 15 while for team rankings Uganda came second in all categories behind hosts Kenya except for the boys Under 15 where Morocco managed a second finish and Uganda third.

Uganda had the second biggest number of participants (44) behind hosts Kenya (78) participants of the total number of 481 athletes that took part in various representing 21 delegations from 5 continents.

Ugandan Captain Chebet Faith was grateful to have taken part in the event but advised her colleagues out there to take training lot more seriously.

“We should keep working hard when training because the competition we face is very talented and the only way we can beat them at races is by performing at our level best”.

This marks the first time the ISF Cross Country Championship has been held in Africa and featured competitions across three age groups: U18, U15, and U12, within a single championship.

President Ruto thanked the East African neighbors of Uganda, Tanzania and Rwanda for being a part of this event.

Kenyan President Mr. William Ruto delivered a speech at the event, extending a warm welcome to the visiting participants and congratulating the winning athletes.

"What we have here today is not just a competition. It is a celebration of our diversity, a celebration of our children, and a celebration of our talents. The children that have participated in this celebration, from different countries, from different cultures, from different parts of the world, have come together to compete in one race, to demonstrate our humanity, to demonstrate our oneness, and to confirm that the world is becoming a global village, and we all belong to that village." Said His Excellency William Ruto, the president of the Republic of Kenya.

Kenya had a clean sweep of all individual except for one, where Uganda won a bronze in boys under 15.

While for team rankings Uganda came second in all categories behind hosts Kenya except for the boys Under 15 where Morocco managed a second finish and Uganda third.

The World school sports body has 134 members and 36 of these countries are from Africa.

Founded in 1972, the International School Sport Federation (ISF) is an international non-profit sport organization, acting as the umbrella organization and governing body for national school sport organizations around the world, organizing sport, and educational events for youth from 12 to 18 years old.

ISF has 134 members across all continents and 36 of these countries are from Africa.

post.Title: Uganda in Kitgum for Athletics and SNE championship.
post.Content:
By Mukwaya Arnold

All is set for the 2024 National Primary Schools Kids Athletics and SNE Championship in Kitgum District.

This will be the first championship organised under the new leadership team of the Uganda Primary Schools Sports Association headed by William Bwambale.

Having held one in Luweero last year, this will be only the second time in the post -covid era. This edition has attracted teams from more than 100 district Local governments.
By press time more than 60 Districts had reported and more are expected to report very soon.

The teams shall reside at host school Kitgum Public School and the co-host St Janan Luwum primary School.

In contrast to the previous editions, in this year's edition there will be only two categories that is U-12 and U-14 with the U-16 scrapped from the Primary Schools championships and advised to take part in the Secondary Schools Championships but SNEs have been maintained.


The SNEs include the physically handicapped, blind, deaf, dumb and those with mental disabilities.


Participants will participate in 50m, 60m hurdles and sprints 4 X 50m relay, high jump fosbury, long jump, 5 multiple jumps, triple jumps, javelin, discus, shotput, cross country.

The president Uganda Primary Schools Sports Association, Bwambale William, says that the athletics talent sporting event targeting children under 14-years is a grooming ground for national talents.

"This is one of the greatest opportunities for our children to have their respective talents in athletics natured for national glory. We thank the respective local governments, cities and municipalities that have sponsored their respective teams,”

This is the 11th edition of kids Athletics in Uganda and it's expected to end on the 22nd May at Kitgum Public School playground

post.Title: Kids Athletics and SNEs Championship 2024 to set off today in Kitgum
post.Content:
The highly anticipated Kids Athletics and SNEs Championship 2024 is set to kick off today in Kitgum, with over 3000 pupils ready to showcase their athletic talents.

This year's edition marks the 11th anniversary of the championship, which was first introduced in 2012 and hosted by Mbarara District.

According to UPSSA President William Bwambale, a total of 146 District Local Government teams have registered for the championship, comprising 1523 male and 1522 female athletes. Notably, 12 primary two pupils will participate in the tournament, a rare occurrence in previous years.

In his address during the pre-championship meeting, President Bwambale expressed gratitude to the organizers and participants, highlighting the improvement in the championship since the new executive took office two months ago. He also emphasized the importance of security, with the Resident District Commissioner requesting that all children be in their camps by 7 pm.

Gilbert Orikiriza, from the Ministry of Education and Sports in the Physical Education and Sports Department welcomed the delegations to Kitgum and assured them of a successful championship. He encouraged participants to reach out to the welfare team for any issues and announced that colleagues from the ministry would join the tournament as it progresses.

The championship, which began on May 12 with arrivals, will culminate on May 22. Last year's edition was hosted by Luwero District, with Pader District emerging as the overall winner. This year's event promises to be an exciting display of talent and sportsmanship among the young athletes.

post.Title: ISF: Team Uganda flagged off to China for Football World cup.
post.Content:
Overview

Uganda will be represented by four schools at the Football World Cup in Dalian, China. St. Mary's College Kisubi, Bukedea Comprehensive School will compete in boys football category while Amus College School will play in both boys and girls.

The delegation that will represent Uganda has officially been flagged off today morning at an event that took place at Cooper Chimney-Lugogo by Hon Peter Ogwang, State Minister for Sports Ministry of Education and Sports.

During his speech as the chief guest and also leader of delegation, he emphasized the importance of being disciplined as ambassadors of the country on and off the field while in Dalian.

"As you go to China remain disciplined! I also want everyone traveling to forget about their schools. We are going as team Uganda that's why we were pooled as Uganda 1, 2, 3 and 4 and not the individual schools," he stressed further.

Team Uganda was flagged off in presence of other officials that included Rev. Can. Duncan Mugumya - Commissioner Physical Education and Sports, Ministry of Education and Sports, Patrick Okanya - Assistant Leader of Delegation to China and David Katende -Assistant General Secretary National Council of Sports.

"It's on record that since we started taking students for International competitions, we have not had any case of players running or remaining in those countries. That goes back to patriotism that we teach in our schools," Rev. Can. Duncan Mugumya remarked

Kazaire Mark, a student of St. Mary's College Kisubi will captain team Uganda as they compete in the Football World Cup.

The four schools already learned their opponents through the draws that were held last month in Dalian. Amus College girls' team is pooled in group C along side teams from Czech Republic, Canada and Nigeria.

In the boys' Football category, Amus College School (Uganda 1) was drawn into group G together with teams from Benin, Taipei and Kenya.Bukedea Comprehensive School (Uganda 2 ) in group F alongside teams from Brazil, Germany, Mexico and Turkimenistan. St. Mary's College Kisubi in group E with schools from Kingdom of Saudi Arabia , England, Hungary and Newzland.

Last year’s ISF World Cup at the Moulay Abdellah in Rabat, Morocco ( 27th Edition), Uganda was represented by two and one girls’ teams Amus , Kibuli SS, and St Noa Girls where St Noa finished as Bronze medalist, Amus 17th and Kibuli SS 22nd. China and France emerge victorious in the girls’ and boys’ categories respectively.

Team Uganda will hope to go stronger again and come back home with more medals.

post.Title: TEAM UGANDA ENJOYED MAGICAL KENYA BEYOND THE RUNNING COURSE.
post.Content:
After the ISF World School championship was concluded the athletes from all over the world had a chance to experience Kenya and all it had to offer. This was true to the President Ruto’s words during his speech at the Ngong race course where the athletes run and Kenya came first.

“Welcome to Kenya, to those who have come from far, this is home make it your home and know that Nairobi still has more to offer just make time explore Magical Kenya’. Said His Excellency William Ruto, the President of Kenya.

Most of the athletes in Team Uganda (under 12 and under 15) this was their very first time to visit a new country and as Ibn Battuta said “Travelling-it leaves you speechless, then turns you into a storyteller’.

A visit to the Nairobi National Park.

While they relaxed after a race day, the athletes visited Nairobi National Park, the oldest park in Kenya (gazetted in 1946). The athletes had a chance to walk at their own pace saw several animals for example the cheetahs, hyenas, buffaloes, giraffes, ostriches but to the awe of most Ugandans a crested crane.

A visit to the Bomas of Kenya.

Bomas of Kenya is a tourist village in Niarobi.Bomas means traditional villages belonging to several Kenyan tribes which simply justifies the several huts around the leafy area. A stone throw away from Nairobi National Park, Bomas of Kenya is home to one of the largest auditoriums in Africa. At this iconic location athletes planted trees.

The Friendship Relay

After a visit to the Nairobi National Park the athletes were put in groups from A to M, each country could only have one athlete per group and these run a short relay within the bomas of Kenya, handing over a baton (in form of a Masaai Irungu) to the next athletes. This race was purely a fun race and good way for athletes to know each other more and interact better.

This was after the visit to the Nairobi National park.

The closing ceremony/cultural night.

The crowning part of the whole championship saw athletes exchange different items, momentous and even jackets as souvenirs to take back to their various countries and continents. This was such a fun thing to do for all athletes that got a chance to exchange attire.

After all the exchanges came the cultural night, all athletes had to make a 3 to 5-minute presentation of their respective countries. The presentation could be dance or poem but most danced except for Ireland that presented a poem.

The performances were in alphabetical order and Uganda was the last one to perform before hosts Kenya crowned the event up. Throughout the performances anyone could join in and dance alongside the performers, everyone absolutely loved this part and will live to remember.

What the Uganda Athletes had to say.

“I am very happy to be here, this will inspire me to keep running and become a professional athlete”. Mercy Chemusto, Under 15.

“This is my first time to travel outside Uganda and I will stay in school so that I keep taking part in such activities”. Isaiah Kwemboi,Under 12.

post.Title: CAF: Uganda's St. Mary's Kitende and Kawempe Muslim Secondary School Set for CAF African Schools championship -Zanzibar
post.Content:
By John Wycliffe Musinguzi

After their impressive performance at the CECAFA Zonal Qualifiers last year, St. Mary's Kitende and Kawempe Muslim Secondary School are now set to represent the CECAFA region at the 2024 CAF African Schools Championship.

The girls' team from Kawempe Muslim Secondary School secured their spot after defeating Kenya 2-1 in the final. Shaluwa Butini and Shadia Nabirye scored crucial goals, with Kawempe's Huda Ayikeru named the best goalkeeper and Shadia Nabirye taking home the top scorer award.

St. Mary's Kitende, meanwhile, emerged victorious in the boys' category after a thrilling match against Tanzania. The team won 4-2 in a penalty shootout after a 1-1 draw, with Simon Wanyama earning the top scorer award for the boys.

The CAF African Schools Championship will be held in Zanzibar from May 21st to 24th, with the Ugandan teams expected to arrive on May 20th.

The championship will take place at the recently refurbished Amaan Stadium, with CAF President Dr. Motsepe and several African football legends in attendance.This prestigious tournament provides a platform for young athletes to compete internationally and develop their skills.

The Ugandan teams are eager to make a lasting impact at the championship, building on their success at the CECAFA Zonal Qualifiers last year.With their sights set on the top prize, St. Mary's Kitende and Kawempe Muslim Secondary School are ready to face the best teams from across Africa and make Uganda proud.

The teams have been training hard and are confident in their abilities, and their coaches are optimistic about their chances.The CAF African Schools Championship is a premier youth football competition that brings together the best teams from across the continent. The tournament is a showcase for young talent and provides a platform for teams to compete at the highest level.

St. Mary's Kitende and Kawempe Muslim Secondary School are proud to represent Uganda and the CECAFA region at this prestigious tournament. They are determined to make a positive impact and bring home the championship title.

post.Title: Opening ceremony of the National Kids Athletics and SNE championship in Kitgum - UPSSA ATHLETICS
post.Content:
By Arnold Mukwaya

The excitement and anticipation could be felt in the air as the Opening Ceremony of the National Kids Athletics and SNE Championship kicked off at the Kitgum Boma Grounds. With over 140 districts, cities, and municipalities participating, and whopping over 4000 participants, this year's championship is set to be another big one though under 16 was scrapped off and only left with under 12 and 14.

Hosted by the Kitgum Public School, the championship will run until the 22nd of May. Last year's championship was held in Luwero District, but this year, all eyes are on Kitgum as it hosts this prestigious sports event for the very first time.

The Chief Guest for the opening ceremony was none other than Honorable Dr. Joyce Moriku Kaducu, the Minister of State for Education and Sports (Primary Education).

She was welcomed by officials from both the Uganda Primary Schools Sports Association (UPSSA) and the Ministry of Education and Sports.

The District Education Officer of Kitgum, Lawot Anthony, expressed his gratitude for the opportunity to host the championship and stated that they are willing to host more events of this nature in the future.

He also highlighted the importance of such events in promoting sports and healthy competition among young children.

Speaking of the history of UPSSA, the association's President, William Bwambale, shared that it was established in 1989 in Tororo though it was not successful as now. He also thanked the elder association USSSA for their support and guidance.


The partnership between UPSSA and USSSA has proved to be a successful one, with USSSA providing a full secretariat for making accreditation cards and certification , 50 million shillings to facilitate officiating officials, and organizing capacity building training for primary teachers in coaching, refereeing, and umpiring last year in Mbarara .

Twahil Kiteezaala, the 1st President of USSSA, expressed his pride in being associated s with UPSSA and their commitment to promoting sports in the country.

"The Ministry of Education and Sports has also shown its support by providing 40 million shillings to every district, with 10 million shillings dedicated to capacity building" Honorable Dr. Joyce Moriku Kaducu.


She also emphasized the importance of investing in sports at a young age and how it can positively impact the development of children.

As the championship officially begins, the energy and enthusiasm of the participants and officials are palpable. With such strong support from various organizations and the government, the National Kids Athletics and SNE Championship is sure to be a success.

Kitgum is proud to be the host of this event and is looking forward to a memorable and competitive championship.

post.Title: Ugandan Young Referee Selected for CAF Pan African Schools Football Championship
post.Content:
By Musinguzi John Wycliffe

17-year-old Jabeth Elly Ojilong, a form five student at Amus College, has made history by becoming the only Ugandan referee selected for the CAF Pan African Schools Football Championship.

This prestigious tournament will take place in Zanzibar from May 21st to 24th, featuring two Ugandan schools, St. Mary's Kitende and Kawempe Muslim Secondary School.

Facts about Jabeth Elly Ojilong:

  • Name: Jabeth Elly Ojilong
  • Age: 17
  • Parents: Amoding Caroline (Mother) and Ojilong Samuel (Father)
  • School: Amus College
  • First international championship: CAF Pan African Schools Football Championship qualifiers 2022, Dar-es-Salaam, Tanzania
  • Uganda Premier League game covered: Express Vs SC Villa (Second Assistant Referee)
  • Role Model: Mike Dean
  • Dream: To officiate at the World Cup

Jabeth Elly Ojilong's selection for the CAF Pan African Schools Football Championship is a proud moment for Uganda and a testament to the country's growing talent in football refereeing. We wish him the best of luck in this championship and in his future endeavors.

Ojilong's journey to this point has been marked by hard work and dedication. He has been actively involved in refereeing since his early teenage years and has quickly risen through the ranks, earning his FUFA badge at the national level. His experience in officiating Uganda Premier League games has prepared him well for this international assignment.

The CAF Pan African Schools Football Championship is a premier youth football competition that brings together the best teams from across Africa. The tournament provides a platform for young players to showcase their talent and for referees like Ojilong to gain valuable experience.

As Ojilong prepares to take the field in Zanzibar, he is aware of the responsibility that comes with representing Uganda on the international stage. He is determined to make a positive impact and prove himself as a capable and skilled referee.

Ojilong is a product of the USSSA (Uganda Secondary Schools Sports Association) capacity building program, which aims to develop and nurture young talent in various sports disciplines.

The program has provided him with valuable training and exposure, helping him to develop his skills and achieve his goals.

We are proud to support Jabeth Elly Ojilong on his journey and wish him all the best in this championship and beyond.

post.Title: CAF PAN African schools championship -Zanzibar football bound teams flagged off
post.Content:
By Musinguzi John Wycliffe

Sketch

Kawempe Muslim Secondary School and St. Mary's Boarding School - Kitende will represent Uganda in the championship, which takes place in Zanzibar from May 21st to 24th.

The flag-off ceremony for the Ugandan teams representing the CECAFA Region at the CAF Pan African Schools Football Championship was held today at Copper Chimney Lugogo.

Rev. Can. Duncan Mugumya Commissioner Physical Education and Sports, who was also the chief guest at the ceremony urged the teams to maintain discipline and make Uganda proud.

"Go and do your very best! I urge you to keep disciplined because whatever you do in Zanzibar will be credited to Uganda, not your schools," he added

David Katende, Assistant General Secretary of the National Council of Sports, also addressed the teams where he emphasized Uganda's big expectations in the travelling teams.

"Uganda is no longer a participant in international championships but a competitor. We only expect that you are going to give us good results because we know you are very talented.

"Hajji Lwembawo Hussein, Leader of Delegation, praised the progress made in international engagements. "In the past, it was rare to see schools go outside the country for international engagements, but under your tenure, it has become a usual thing.

I would like to appreciate NCS, FUFA because we go to CAF through the Football Federation. We are going there as champions, and we should come back as champions!"

The teams received a warm send off, with officials and stakeholders expressing confidence in their abilities. The CAF Pan African Schools Football Championship is a premier youth football competition, and Uganda's participation is a testament to the country's growing talent and investment in football development.

post.Title: ISF: Opening ceremony and test matches in Dalian ahead of kick off of the ISF Football World Cup.
post.Content:
Team Uganda all vested in yellow and black shone at the opening ceremony in Dalian as the norm is before before kick off of any International School Federation Championship.

The Opening ceremony was witnessed 22.678 spectators at Dalian and more than 500.000 viewers through internet.

The ISF Football World Cup in China -2024 attracted an impressive number of 1350 participants.

Uganda is being represented by four teams; 3 in the boys category and one in the girls that is Bukedea Comprehensive School, St. Mary's College Kisubi and Amus College School (boys and girls).

Further more, four Ugandan referees will be officiating at the schools world cup.

Tonny Kalairewo already tested the waters in China as he was fourth official in the opening match between China and Chile.

The other referees to be involved are Makanga Hazahal, Lydia Auma and Barbra Nayebare are who will all be in action on Sunday morning.

Makanga will be fourth official in a game between China and New Zealand while the other three will team up in a game between Serbia and Macao China alongside Chinese Zhang Lichuan who will be fourth official.

Meanwhile, in a bid to kick off on a high note the teams carried out training sessions earlier alone to have the feel and momentum in Dalian.

Pictorial from the training sessions

post.Title: UPSSA ATHLETICS: Katakwi takes over Kitgum.
post.Content:
By Catherine Kasemeza

The stage was set for a day of thrilling competition at Boma Ground in Kitgum, as young athletes gathered to showcase their speed and agility in the 60m sprint races.

The under 12 and under 14 boys and girls took to the track, ready to give it their all and make their mark.

In the under 12 boys' category, Opule Moses from Katakwi district emerged victorious with a time of 5.99 seconds, closely followed by Olupot John Michael and Iupat Gilbert, also from Katakwi.

Meanwhile, in the under 12 girls' category, Malinga Ruth from Katakwi took the top spot with a time of 6.20 seconds, with Kedi Rachael and Onyang Rebecca, also from Katakwi, following closely behind.

In the under 14 boys' category, Ediedu Linus from Katakwi secured the top spot with a time of 6.01 seconds, with Waiswa Paul and Opius Fredrick, also from Katakwi, taking second and third place respectively.

As for the under 14 girls, Asio Jemimah from Katakwi emerged victorious with a remarkable time of 5.99 seconds, followed by Adedi Martha and Kulume Esther Naume, also from Katakwi.

Asio Jemimah, the overall winner proudly expressed towards her victory . "I'm very happy because I have won the 60m sprint race and I hope for better,"

The events also featured Special Needs Education (SNE) athletes, who showed resilience and determination, winning several races.

post.Title: ISF: Uganda off to a flying start in Dalian.
post.Content:
Overview

Matchday one was a very great outing for Ugandan teams.
Bukedea Comprehensive School secured a 6-0 victory over Turkimenistan as Amus College School (boys) won 7-2 against Taipei China while the girls' side won 3-2 against Nigeria. St. Mary's College Kisubi lost 2-6 to New Zealand

From each group only the top team qualifies for the next round.

Amus College School captain Toto Majub seems to know what it takes to land the golden prize having had a fairy tale of a championship in Morocco last year

"It is not the first time we are playing in this School's world cup. We came (to Morocco) last year and it didn't work out. We know we have to win our second game because from every group they take one team!

Toto Majub full interview

Scoring goals? No problem

Team Uganda enjoyed hitting the back of the net at the opposite end of the pitch having scored 18 goals in the the first 4 games.

Watch Bashir Mansoor goal for Amus College School

Can team Uganda deliver a maiden World Cup title? This can only be answered after the next round of matches although the early signs are very promising.

match day 2

post.Title: Roadmap for USSSA ball games II 2024 drawn
post.Content:
The eight point plan to the ball games II has been released. In a letter dated 20th May, 2024 the plan right from registration and transfers to qualifiers and the National championship all has been stipulated together with the time frames.

This year's ball games II will be hosted by Teso College Aloet in Soroti district in the month of July.

This year's edition is anticipated to be even much more competitive and booming in comparison to last year's that took place in Kigezi region Kabale district hosted by St. Mary's College Rushoroza.

The registration and transfer guidelines for this year's championship will be the same that have already been tried and tested in the Fresh Dairy Secondary School Games and Boys Football championship Masaka 2024 which were successful

The USSSA ball games II include the following sports disciplines;

  • Netball girls
  • volley ball (boys and girls)
  • Football U16 (boys and girls)
  • Basketball 3x3 (boys and girls)
  • rugby 7's (boys and girls )
  • handball (boys and girls)
  • athletics and cross country
  • woodball (boys and girls)
  • dance sport
  • Beach soccer ( boys and girls)
  • beach volleyball (boys and girls)
  • lacrosse (boys and girls )

post.Title: NATIONAL KIDS ATHLETICS AND SNE CHAMPIONSHIP CONCLUDES IN KITGUM WITH A CALL FOR FOR INCREASED SUPPORT FOR SPORTS.
post.Content:
By Catherine Kasemeza

The National Kids Athletics and SNE Championship, which took place in Kitgum from May 12th to 20th, 2024, came to a close with a vibrant closing ceremony. The event, which brought together over 4000 athletes and 1000 officials from 162 districts was a resounding success.

"I want to thank our brothers of USSSA for being very supportive.
I thank the government of Uganda for supporting sports because it's a uniting factor."

"In sports, we don't mind about colors. Most leaders in this country are in Sports." Bwambale William, President Uganda Primary Schools Sports Association remarked.

Further more, Nsubuga Mustafa, President of the Uganda Sports Officers Association, appealed to the Ministry of Education and Sports to increase the budget for community sports from 40 million to at least 100 million to ensure the smooth running of such events.

Gilbert Orikiriza, Desk Officer for Primary Schools Championships, announced that certificates would not be awarded on the spot but would be available for collection at a later date.

Sammy Odongo, the Assistant Commissioner for Physical Education and Sports, emphasized the importance of sports in enhancing health and education. He commended Kitgum for hosting a successful event.

The ceremony was attended by athletes, games teachers, and other stakeholders. The highlight of the event was the awarding of medals and trophies to the best-performing athletes, with the Special Needs Education (SNE) athletes scooping most of the awards.

The championship showcased the talent and dedication of young athletes from across the country and the closing ceremony marked a fitting end to a memorable event.

post.Title: Capacity building flag bearers championing refereeing excellence in Dalian.
post.Content:
In the ISF Football World Cup on going in Dalian China, Uganda is being represented by four football teams and four referees.

From Elite Games 2024 in Jinja, to USSSA Boys Football championship Masaka now in the World Cup in China.

Tonny Kalairewo, Makanga Hazahal Lydia Auma and Barbra Nayebare are the four Ugandan referees officiating at the world cup.

Yet to officiate a single game as a quadruple, matchday 3 in Dalian is the D-Day.

At 9:00, all the four will team up in a girls football game between Morocco and China. Makanga will be the Center referee, Nayebare (1st Assistant), Auma Lydia (2nd assistant) with Tonny Kalairewo the fourth official.

Tonny Kalairewo who was also fourth official in the opening match between China and Chile will be the center referee in the boys football match between Czech Republic and AEFE.

Here Auma Lydia and Nayebare Barbara will be first and second official respectively while Makanga will be fourth official.

post.Title: Debutants Kawempe Muslim SS Ready to Make History in Zanzibar
post.Content:
Kawempe Muslim Secondary School's football team has finally arrived in Zanzibar for the prestigious CAF African Schools Football Championship! The team touched down at 10:30 am today, eager to make their mark in the tournament.

Their opening fixture promises to be a thrilling encounter, as they face off against South Africa tomorrow morning at 9:30 am. South Africa, having hosted the championship last year, is a formidable opponent, but Kawempe Muslim is undaunted.

Led by skipper Shadia Nabirye, the team boasts talented players like goalkeeper Hudah Ayikoru, Tracy Nabaranzi, Cythnia Kirenga, and Hairah Nabbosa, among others. The girls are determined to make Uganda proud, and their spirits are high as they prepare to take on the best teams from across Africa.

The 2024 CAF African Schools Football Championship will be held at the Amman Stadium from May 21st to 25th, and Uganda is one of the participating countries in the U-15 age category. The girls are pooled in Group B alongside South Africa, Togo, and The Gambia, and they're ready to face the challenge head-on.

Kawempe Muslim Secondary School's participation in this championship is a historic moment for the school and Ugandan football. The team's determination and spirit have already made them champions in the eyes of their fans, and they're ready to make their mark on the African stage.

The stage is set for an exciting tournament, and Kawempe Muslim Secondary School's football team is ready to shine. With their opening fixture against South Africa just hours away, the team is focused and ready to give it their all.

post.Title: AGAGO AND OMORO DISTRICTS REIGN SUPREME IN THE NATIONAL KIDS ATHLETICS AND SNE CHAMPIONSHIP.
post.Content:
By Catherine

After a thrilling showdown at the National Kids Athletics and SNE Championship, the top-performing districts took home the coveted trophies confirming their dominance on the tracks and fields. Meanwhile, exceptional athletes settled for medals signifying their hard work and dedication.

Two trophies were awarded to Kitgum Public School and St.Janan Luwum for the good hospitality during the championship and hosting the workshop for officiating officials respectively.

post.Title: Kawempe Muslim Shares Spoils with South Africa in Thrilling Opener
post.Content:
The Amaani Stadium witnessed an electrifying match today morning as Kawempe Muslim and South Africa played to a draw in their CAF African Schools Championship opener. Shadia Nabirye put Uganda ahead in the 4th minute, and the team dominated the first half with several attacks.

South Africa's Rithabile Molefe came close to equalizing in the 25th minute, but goalkeeper Huda Ayikoru made a crucial save. However, South Africa was awarded a penalty in the 36th minute, which Molefe converted to level the score.

Ayub Khalifa, Kawempe Muslim Head Coach believes the team will perform better in the upcoming games.
"It's unfortunate that we didn't win this game, but we are to find ways to win the upcoming games." Ayub Khalifa, Head Coach Kawempe Muslim Secondary School.

Kawempe Muslim faces Togo tomorrow at 9:00 am, while South Africa takes on Gambia at the same time. Uganda's final group fixture against Gambia is scheduled for 11:00 am tomorrow, with a spot in the semi-finals on the line.

post.Title: ISF: Uganda closer to world cup glory in Dalian.
post.Content:
Uganda 2 (Bukedea Comprehensive School) scored twice to beat their German opponent to top the log.

Following the qualification of Uganda 1( Amus College School), Bukedea Comprehensive School too won their third match to top the log of group F in the ongoing ISF World Cup China 2024 in Dalian City.

Ssebumpenje Yusuf opened the scoring in the 10th Minute before Ssekisambu Reagan extended the lead in the 31st Minute.

Germany came to this encounter topping the log with 6 points but with a superior goal difference compared to that of Bukedea Comprehensive School (BCS).

This win follows Bukedea's two wins in their first fixtures where they beat Turkmenistan 6 goals to zero and a two zero score against Brazil. BCS is yet to concede a single goal in the tournament and have scored 10 goals out of three fixtures.

The next game for BCS will be against Mexico on Thursday 23rd May. The leader of group F will face the lead of group E which has England (log leaders with 12 points after 4 games), Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, New Zealand, Hungary, and Uganda 3 (SMACK).

In the other news, Uganda 1 (Amus College School) secured their spot in the last eight after winning two of their three fixtures of group G. They won against Chinese Taipei (7:), drew against Benin (0:0), and won against East African rivals Kenya (2:0) .

They face the leader of group H which is currently topped by Turkey (9 points) after winning all their three fixtures.

Uganda 3 ( SMACK) suffered their 3rd loss after losing three goals to nil against group E leaders (England). SMACK has so far scored 2 goals and conceded 14 goals in three fixtures.

The Ugandan Girls team (Amus College School) will face the Czech Republic in their 3rd fixture. Uganda is in group C which is topped by Nigeria with 6 points after three games. A win for Amus will give them an advantage ahead of game day 4 where they will face Canada who have played 2 (won 1, lost 1).

The winner of group C will face the leader of group D which is currently topped by Kenya with 7 points.

post.Title: ISF: Netbusters! advancing in style
post.Content:
Match day 4 Full time results

  • Uganda 2 (Bukedea Comprehensive School) 9-0 Mexico
  • Uganda 3 ( SMACK) 7-3 Hungary
  • Uganda (Amus College School Girls football) 32-0 Czech Republic

Three Ugandan sides were in action on Matchday 4 in the bid to secure a spot in the next round of the Schools World Cup in China.

Amus College School girls Football team ran riot as they thumped Canada 32-0

Amus goal scorers

Sadly, the star of the match Nasipwondi Edinar (scored 9) was shown matching orders after a retaliation on her opponent . Amus has won two and drawn one after three fixtures accumulating 7 points. Amus has one huddle to jump before confirming their spot in the last 4.

They face Canada in their last group C match on Friday 24th May 2024 at 11:30 AM Beijing time, (6:30 AM EAT)

Brazil lead the group on goal difference after scoring 37 past Canada. They have scored 63 and conceded just 2 giving them a goal difference of 61 goals while Amus has soces 37 and conceded 4 giving them a goal difference of 33.

Elsewhere, Bukedea Comprehensive continued their 100% record start as they put nine past Mexico. Elvis Ssekajugo netted 4 times while danger man Yusuf Ssebumpejje came up with a brace, Edwin Aine, Halid Asiga and and James Kaye grabbed a goal each to further the damage.

Meanwhile St. Mary's College Kisubi registered their first win of the championship as they beat Hungary 7-3.

Bukedea and Amus are through to the last eight while SMACK is destined for classification games. Bukedea (group F leaders) faces England (group E leaders) while Amus (group G leaders) faces Turkey (group H leaders).

post.Title: Kawempe Wins Bronze at CAF African Schools Football Championship
post.Content:
Kawempe made a remarkable debut at the CAF African Schools Football Championship, topping Group B with seven points and remaining unbeaten. They drew 1-1 with South Africa on Tuesday, 21st, and defeated Togo and Gambia 2-0 each on Wednesday, 22nd, securing a semi-final spot.

Although their title hopes were dashed when they faced Morocco, suffering a painful 1-0 loss after conceding in the first minute, Kawempe rebounded in the third-place playoff against Tanzania.

Exhibiting resilience and determination, they beat Tanzania 1-0 thanks to Cynthia Kirenga's second-half goal.

From the start, Kawempe showed their intent, and although the game was goalless at half-time.

They took a well-deserved lead nine minutes into the second half through Cynthia Kirenga's close-range finish. Kawempe's defense was solid, denying Tanzania's late efforts, and securing the bronze medal.

Shadia Nabirye was also named the championship's top scorer, netting three goals in five matches. She scored against South Africa, Togo, and Gambia.

As bronze medalists, Uganda (Kawempe) received $150,000 in prize money, a testament to their impressive performance throughout the tournament.
