post.Title: ISF: Two Uganda sides to fight for the final Slot
post.Content:
Only one Uganda side can make it into this year's ISF Football World Cup in Dalian City.

Amus College School and Bukedea Comprehensive School out to face each other in a final spot decider.

After both winning their quarter final games, it is all to play for in the semis. Amus beat Turkey in the penalty spots (5:4) after a two all draw in the stoppage time.

Two goals from Busuulwa Davis and Musabbah Hakim kept Amus alive in the game despite resistance from the tough Turkish counterpart.
Turkey took the lead, before Hakim equalized. Amus scored their second which was later levelled to dictate the game into the spot kicks

This win set a semi-final with their Bukedea rivals (BCS) that edged England 1 by two goals to 1.

England took the lead after converting from the spot in the 20th minute, but Bukedea made a quick response after just 6 minutes (26') to level the score through Ssekisambu Reagan.

On return in the second half, Bukedea scored just after 7 minutes courtesy of Ssekisambu Reagan in the forty seventh minute to take the lead that they maintenaned despite missing a number of clear chances in the encounter with England 1.

In the other boys games, China 3 played China 1 while China 2 played Croatia to determine the other semi final.

In the girls games, Amus college failed to qualify for the semis despite beating Canada 24 goals to zero. Their goal difference could not match that of Brazil who beat Nigeria 5:0 in the last group C fixture and 37 against Canada in the third match the previous day. Amus had a goal difference of 57 while Brazili made it 66.

post.Title: ISF: Uganda 2 out, Uganda 1 final bound at the Schools World Cup -Dalian
post.Content:
overview

Amus College School (Uganda 1) beat Bukedea Comprehensive School (Uganda 2) 4-2 in penalties after playing out a goalless draw. Amus College will play China in the boys football final.

The ISF Football World Cup -Dalian China witnessed a very tense, end to end action packed clash "Teso Derby in the foreign Land"

With either team well stocked with quality players and coaches, the tactical battles were eye catching. Both teams played out a goalless draw with none coming close to taking a stride into the final in normal time.

A Penalty shoot out was the savior of the day. Amus shotstopper Ben Sinalya was up to the task as he saved the first two spotkicks of Bukedea Comprehensive School.

Elvis Ssekajugo and Ssekibengo Godfrey missed penalties for Bukedea while Amus captain Toto Majub scored the final penalty to send Amus into the final.

Watch Ben Sinalya penalty saves

Amus College School who lost the Boys Football Final in Masaka earlier this month will hope to win their first major trophy this year and the first one as well for team Uganda.

Meanwhile Amus College School girls team lost 2-0 to England in the classification matches whereas Uganda 3 (St. Mary's College Kisubi) lost 2-4 against Taipei China. Amus will play for 7/8th place while SMACK will play for 31/32rd place.

post.Title: ISF: Finals and fan fare! Minister in Dalian to grace the last dance.
post.Content:
The state minister for Sports, Ministry of Education and Sports, Hon. Peter Ogwang is in Dalian City to grace the finale of the ISF World Cup China 2024.

Uganda 1 (Amus College) will draw battle lines with the hosts (China 1) in the Romantic City at Suoyuwan Stadium 16:10 Beijing Time | 10:10AM EAT.

Hon. Peter Ogwang flagged off team Uganda a couple of days ago at Cooper Chimney Lugogo- Kampala

In the battle for positions, Bukedea Comprehensive School (Uganda 2) will face China 2 in the third place play off on pitch 5 at 11:00AM Beijing Time | 6:30 AM EAT

Amus College School girls Football team will play with Chinese Taipei for positions 7 and 8 at 8:30 AM Beijing Time | 2:30 AM EAT on pitch 6 while SMACK (Uganda 3 boys) will play with India at 8:30 AM Beijing Time | 2:30 AM EAT - pitch 9 for positions 31 and 32

post.Title: ISF: silver and bronze for Uganda in Dalian
post.Content:
overview

Uganda bagged two medals that is silver and bronze at the ISF Football World Cup in Dalian City- China. Uganda 1 (Amus College School) settled for silver having fallen short against China 1 in the penalty shootouts while Bukedea Comprehensive (Uganda 2) beat China 2 to cement third place.

Amus College School who finished 17th in the same championship last year in Morocco outdone themselves to clinch second position where they narrowly lost to China in the penalty shootouts.

Davis Busuulwa was the man of the moment for team Uganda in the final. His brace was all Amus needed to come back into the game having gone a goal down on two occasions.

China 1 bagged boys football gold winning 5-4 after the two all draw in the captivating eighty minutes.

Meanwhile, Bukedea Comprehensive School (Uganda 2) cemented position number 3 after defeating China 2 1-0 thanks to a 76th minute strike by Karim Abdul Ssengozi.

Uganda 3 (SMACK) beat India 7-0 to mark position 31.

Amus College School girls team lost 3-0 to Taipei China which left them in 8th position.

The boys' category featured 36 teams compared to the 19 that participated in the girls'.

post.Title: ISF: Heroes of the World Cup Return with Glory
post.Content:
The first batch of the team that represented Uganda at the ISF Football World Cup 2024 in Dalian China has safely returned.

Team Uganda that comprised of four football teams that is Amus College (boys and girls), St. Mary's College Kisubi and Bukedea Comprehensive School has been in Dalian City for close to a fortnight to compete in the Football World Cup.

Amus College School (boys and girls) and St. Mary's College Kisubi have been warmly welcomed at the airdrome by the respective school officials and parents.

Amus' Edna Wanda emerged top scorer at the tourney in girls football category.

Later, The World Cup silver medalists Amus College School boys returned in even much glory as they finished second out of the 36 teams that participated in this year's world cup where they narrowly lost to China in spot kicks.

This batch also included officials that is The Minister Education and Sports (Sports) Hon. Peter Ogwang, Patrick Okanya who was leader of Delegation and other USSSA officials.

Meanwhile, bronze medalists Bukedea Comprehensive School will return on Wednesday 29th as the last part of team Uganda.

post.Title: Progressive learning curve for Uganda's representatives at the 2024 ISF Football World Cup in China
post.Content:
Part of the delegation that represented Uganda at the 2024 ISF Football World Cup in Dalian city, China safely returned home on Tuesday, 28th May.

These comprised of students and officials from Amus College School, St Mary's College Kisubi (SMACK) and the the accompanying officials who included the state minister of sports Hon. Peter Ogwang as well as the USSSA CEO Christopher Mugisha Banage and the overall head of delegation Patrick Okanya.

"It has been an amazing journey for Uganda teams in China. The performances of our team was impressive as we managed to take silver and bronze for the boys. As a country, we shall continue to bench-mark from the hosts China as we eye an improvement in Uganda's sports sub-sector" Hon. Ogwang told USSSA Media.

The Amus College School boys' team captained by Bran Toto Majub scooped silver after falling to hosts China in the final, 5-3 in post match penalties following a 2-all draw in the final.

Majub cites crucial positives from the championship which had schools from the different parts of the world.

"We faced off teams from the different countries and we learnt a lot from them. One key element was how to be assertive and aggressive" Toto remarked.

The girls team (Amus College) which also had the tournament top scorer Edna Wandera finished eighth overall in the championship and looks forward towards better times ahead.

Nimrod Kintu, the school football team head coach (Boys) picks key learning points coming to the 2024 FEASSSA Games that will be hosted in Bukedea zone.

"The tournament in China put us in shape for the forthcoming FEASSSA Games in August 2024. The players look forward improved performances" Kintu remarked.

Team Uganda head of delegation Okanya lauded God for the journey mercies. Okanya continued to thank the Government, mother ministry - of education and sports, the schools for the collective team-work.

"China was good and has taught us very many good lessons. The Lord has been good for the safe journeys to and from. I continue to thank the Almighty Lord. I thank the Government, the ministry of Education and Sports, the schools, parents, players, coaches and other officials for the collective teamwork. We have also learnt a lot many good things from the China expedition going forward. Best of all, all the people who traveled are back to the country" Okanya revealed.

Veteran coach Frank Video Anyau, the girls' team head coach is grateful to the different stakeholders including Government and ISF as well as the school management for facilitating the travel of the team.

"We traveled well to China and I would like to thank the players, coaches, Government, USSSA and the schools' management committees for the successful trip. We also learnt a lot going forward" Anyau noted.

Amus and SMACK returned on Tuesday, Uganda's other representative, Bukedea Comprehensive (who finished third to take the bronze medals) are expected back home on Wednesday.

post.Title: Just In: Two teams to represent Uganda at the ISF World Schools Basketball Championship 2024 in China
post.Content:
In a thrilling development, two teams from Uganda have been selected to represent the country at the prestigious ISF World Schools Basketball Championship 2024. Elite High School Entebbe will be flying the flag for the boys' team, while a joint team comprising talented players from various schools will represent the girls' team.

This marks a historic debut for both teams, as they prepare to take on some of the best school teams from around the world.

The boys' team has been drawn in Group D and will face off against some tough opponents, including Mongolia, China 2, Brazil, and Serbia.

The girls' team, meanwhile, has been drawn in Group C and will face China 2, France, and Chinese Taipei.

The championship, scheduled to take place in Macao, China, from June 23rd to July 3rd, promises to be an exciting event, with the Ugandan teams determined to make a strong impression in their debut appearance.

post.Title: ISF World Cup bronze medalists return from China
post.Content:
sketch

Bukedea Comprehensive School (Uganda 2) is back from the ISF Football World Cup. Bukedea are bronze medalists having defeated China 2 in the third place play off thanks to a Karim Abdul Ssengozi strike.

Bukedea Comprehensive pulled off high quality performances at the World Cup having finished off the championship unbeaten in regular time despite falling to fellow Ugandan side Amus College School at the semi finals.

Coach Ssali Ronald's boys were up to the task throughout the ten- days tourney dispatching away opponents with ease at all stages bar semis.

The Teso based side will now turn all their attention towards the FEASSSA games which they will host in the coming months.

Bukedea Comprehensive School's return means all representatives for team Uganda at the World Cup have returned home safe and sound.

post.Title: Feast of victory for Team Uganda.
post.Content:
Overview

The ISF and CAF contingent including athletes, USSSA and Ministry of Education and Sports officials and Members of August house will be treated to a luncheon at Imperial Hotel on Friday 31st May.

Five Ugandan schools represented Uganda on the International stage that is CAF Schools Football championship in Zanzibar and International Schools Federation Football World Cup in Dalian China.

Kawempe Muslim SS (girls) and St. Mary's Boarding School Kitende (boys) represented Uganda in Zanzibar whereas Amus College School (boys and girls), Bukedea Comprehensive School and St. Mary's College Kisubi competed in China.

Uganda reaped 3 medals in the process; one silver and 2 bronze medals. Amus College School won silver in Dalian while Bukedea and Kawempe scooped bronze medals.

post.Title: ISF and CAF welcome luncheon - As it happened.
post.Content:
In brief

The five schools that represented Uganda in China and Zanzibar were treated to a luncheon at Hotel Imperial Royale. David Katende the Assistant General Secretary National Council of Sports represented Hon. Peter Ogwang State Minister of Sports as chief guest on the occasion.

The celebratory occasion that occurred at Imperial Royale Hotel was attended by Ministry of Education and Sports and USSSA officials, Justus Mugisha USSSA President, Al- Said president USPA, Deborah Basekanabyo - ASSHU, gallant athletes and the media.

David Katende, chief guest appreciated the Secondary School Sports Association and extended a warning to schools that form clubs in school.

"There are four aspects in sports; practicing, participating, Performance and recognition. Therefore I would like to thank USSSA for taking us through these steps and now we are at the point of recognizing these athletes. To the students, use your time in school to reach the best version of yourself. Schools should desist from creating clubs inside schools. You find a school and students refer to some students as "ballers" Are ballers not students?"

Groovy melodies from the traditional dance troupe engraved the ceremony, with some students showcasing extra their extra abilities in dance before the guests. Video

The USSSA president, Justus Mugisha emphasized the need to take very many students for International engagements at this level.

"While in Dalian, Uganda had the second highest number of teams just two behind China who were the hosts. The main reason is that in sport, usually from about a thousand athletes, you may find that only three make it to the very highest level. Therefore it's very important to take a pool such that we can have the very best."

Hajji Lwembawo Hussein who was the head of delegation to Zanzibar at the CAF Schools Football championship

"In Zanzibar, I realized that we need to adjust in the ways we organize our competitions especially for the under 15' as I realized we could have performed even much better. The girls were used to playing in full pitches, playing long balls but there short passes were required since they were playing in a much smaller space and playing a shorter time."

The school captains were full of praise and appreciation for the Ministry and USSSA for the opportunity to represent the country at the International stage as it brings invaluable experience to them at a tender age.

post.Title: Fresh Dairy Secondary School Games, Girls' football quarterfinals to be played.
post.Content:
The girls' football quarterfinals of the Fresh Dairy Secondary school games are to be played. The games stopped after most teams sent their players for National team duty where Uganda's teen cranes had to face Zambia in a home and away clash in the FIFA U17 Women's World Cup Qualifiers.

The games will be played at Ndejje University and Standard High School Zzana, Ndejje campus starting on 19th June and ending on 21st June 2024.

Teams will arrive at Ndejje University on the 18th of June 2024, the games will kick off on the 19th of June, the semi-finals and classification on the 20th of June, and the final will be held on the 21st of June. Games will kick off from 8:00 am and to 4:00 pm.

The Quarterfinal fixtures will see defending Champions Amus College vs Sacred Heart SS, Gulu, Uganda Martyrs High School Lubaga vs Kawempe Muslim SS, Rines SS vs Sheema Girls, and Boni Concilli Girls' Vocational vs St. Noa Girls' School.

The association will cater for the welfare of the teams (accommodation and feeding).

All participating schools must submit FORM A of registration by 14th June 2024 with a maximum number of 20 participants and 2 officials. Only students who were verified in the first place shall participate in the games and screening will be done on the day of arrival.

post.Title: Hope SS Watoto - Brave League champions.
post.Content:
Overview

USSSA joined hands with the Reach A Hand as Hope Secondary School Watoto were crowned champions of the second edition of the Brave Girls Tournament Hope SS beat God Cares School 1-0 to dethrone Elite High School -Entebbe that won the first edition.

Brave Girls tournament was organized by Reach a Hand Foundation in collaboration with the Uganda Secondary Schools Sports Association ( USSSA) for technical aspects at International University of East Africa - Grounds with an aim of showcasing the stigma surrounding stereotypical beliefs in sports.

Fourteen girls' football teams participated in the 7-aside format of play tournament played by in the Under -18 category.

Hope SS Watoto beat God Cares courtesy of Alice Ayo's strike to scoop a giant trophy together with six millions prize money on top of the silverware while the second placed bagged one million. Runners up God Cares SS pocketed shs. 3,000,000 whilst Exodus College took home a million shillings.

Some of the schools that participated include Luzira SS, Bishop Cyprian Kihangire, Elite High School (defending champions), Boston High School, Exodus, Golden High School, Alliance High School Nansana among others.

Elite High School -Entebbe were unsuccessful in the fight to defend their title having failed to make it past the group stages. Elite High School lost 2-1 to Bishop Cyprian Kihangire which dented their title defence hopes.

Other partners included Imara Girls Foundation, SRHR Alliance Uganda, Watoto Wasoka, UNESCO, The Girl Child and her long walk to freedom, International University of East Africa (IUEA), 10 & bold, FOWODE, Imago Dei Fund, Planned Parenthood, Eddy Kenzo Foundation, Sauti Media Hub, NBS Sport, Movit and Aquafina, among others.

Founder of Reach A Hand Humphrey Nabimanya lauded all the participating teams and saluted all the supportive partners. He emphasized the relevance of this tournament in the right upbringing of the girl child.

“We managed to hold the second edition of the Brave Girls football league. I thank the teams that took part and all the partners we worked with. This is just the second edition and the Brave Girls League will move a long away. There is need to value girls education, empower girls, help young girls speak out against the vices that affect them and also reduce on the number of school drop outs due to early pregnancies” Nabimanya stated.

post.Title: Ministry of Education and Sports institutes FEASSA National Organizing Committee, Sub Committees
post.Content:
Ahead of the 2024 East African Schools Games organised by the Federation of East African Schools Sports Association (FEASSA), the State Minister for Sports Hon. Peter Ogwang has instituted a Local Organizing Committee (LOC) that will take charge with effectively planning and executing a successful championship.

The games are scheduled for 16th - 27th August 2024 in Eastern Uganda hosted by Bukedea Comprehensive School and Amus College School in Bukedea District.

The Ministry commissioned the committees at a meeting that was hosted at the Ministry of Education and Sports offices at Embassy House - Kampala on Thursday, June 13, 2024.

The FEASSA 2024 Local Organising Committee is chaired by the State Minister of Sports Hon. Peter Ogwang, and deputized by Rev.Can Dr. Duncans Mugumya the Commissioner Physical Education and Sports, MoES.

The committee has people of vast experience from different fields, including Justus Mugisha (USSSA and FEASSA President), William Bwambale (UPSSA President ), David Katende (Assistant General Secretary NCS), Sarah Ayesiga. (Commissioner Special Needs Education), and others to be nominated by different entities such as the Ministry of Internal Affairs, Foreign Affairs, Uganda Police, and Office of the President

Sub-committees will be constituted in the due course chaired by members of the Local Organizing Committee and mandated with various functionalities.

At the meeting Commissioner Rev.Can Dr. Duncans Mugumya on behalf of the State Minister for Sports Hon. Peter Ogwang reminded the committee about the need for teamwork and the collective responsibility of all members and always put Uganda above their own interests.

He thanked the members for accepting the responsibility to serve on the committee and urged them to ensure that Uganda prepares adequately as a country to give pride to the community and country at large.

“We must take on this assignment and execute it to the satisfaction of Ugandans. Our actions will be followed keenly and scrutinized by the public. We must know that we shall be held accountable. Let us work together as a team”, Mugumya urged the team

FEASSA members countries: Kenya, Tanzania, Rwanda ,South Sudan and Burundi.

post.Title: USSSA National Ball Games II: Teso College Aloet Ready To Host
post.Content:
A team comprising of Ministry of Education and Sports, USSSA, ASSHU and Technical Officials was led by Hajj Twahil Kiteezaala the Chairman of the National Organizing Committee (NOC) to ascertain the readiness of Teso College Aloet (TCA) to host the USSSA National Ball Games II.


Areas of focus included accommodation, playing grounds, safety and security, feeding and general welfare of the athletes.
Despite a few areas to fix in certain aspects, the NOC believes TCA has shown full potential to host this year's edition and with a positive mind towards fixing all the areas that need any upgrade.


The games will attract over 11,000 athletes if the non FEASSA qualifying games are considered but the number might go down to over 6,000 if the split of the games is approved by the Ministry of Education and Sports


We have visited venues and facilities for games and accommodation. We are satisfied beyond doubt that TCA is in a position to host USSSA National Ball Games II 2024. They have more than enough grounds for the games, accommodation facilities are generally satisfactory and ready to compensate for the inadequacies. Noted Hajji Twahil.


The school can ably accommodate 6500 athletes, this potential is achieved thanks to the fact that TCA has up to 56 classroom and 18 dormitories. The grounds to be used will include and not limited to Sports Ground, UCC, St. Kizito, Pioneer ground, Busitema University. Among other facilities are the main halls, dining halls and libraries from both the Eastern and Western Wings of the school.


Mind games have made their way into the USSSA activities and will feature in this year's edition with 7 mind games lined to be competed for.
We also have under age category games that will be played, Under 16 for the ball games of Football, volleyball, netball, among others.


These games are scheduled for 9th - 17th July 2024 and will feature both boys and girls in up to 14 sports disciplines and all will be hosted by Teso College Aloet (TCA).

post.Title: FEASSA: pre - inspection of Bukedea Comprehensive and Amus College SchoolS
post.Content:
Minister of State for Sports and Chairman Local Organizing Committee (LOC) Hon. Peter Ogwang made a pre - inspection of Bukedea Comprehensive School and Amus College School ahead of the FEASSA delegation's arrival to inspect the preparedness of the two schools. The delegation will assess the available accommodation and games facilities to host this year's games, inspection will commence on Monday 17th to Thursday 20th June 2024

The Minister who was accompanied by officials led by the USSSA President Justus Mugisha, Hajji Twahil Kiteezaala, Commissioner Physical Education Rev. Dr. Ducans Mugumya, host headteachers (Opio Richard of Amus and Jona Gumisiriza of Bukedea Comprehensive School) and President emeritus Partrick Okanya.

The Minister kicked off the pre-inspection tour at Amus College School Eastern Uganda where they visited five playgrounds, three basketball courts and accommodation facilities. Ogwang also proceeded to inspect Bukedea Comprehensive School.

While there, the minister expressed disappointment with how work is slowly going on most especially on the side of playing facilities.

"With only 40 days left, we cannot be in this state of progress. We have to double our efforts because this benefits Uganda as a country but nevertheless the hope is still high that we shall host these games come August.
Our work as government is to see that these games are hosted in Eastern Uganda holistically" Ogwang said.

The minister observed that in the two host schools work is going on but at a slow pace and this may affect the country's hope of hosting these games in the region but ruded the efforts of the two host schools as he promised continuous supervision both from him and the Local Organizing Committee.

In his address, the minister delivered the good news of the head of state officiating the games.

"This hosting is historical that the head of state the President H.E Yoweri Kaguta Museveni and the first lady who is also the minister of Education and Sports Mama Janet Kataha Museveni will be guests to this event." Ogwang noted.

The FEASSA inspection delegation will be in the country from Monday 17th to Thursday 21st July to check on the preparedness as far as hosting is concerned.

USSSA President who also doubles as the FEASSA President Justus Mugisha expressed his gratitude to the minister for accepting to be the Chairperson National Organising committee and noted that as a country there is trust in the minister.

"We thank you for accepting to be the chairman NOC, we know that you have never failed. What we thought couldn't be possible is going to be possible because you accepted."

He also noted that he had a lot of trust in the people behind the schools that are to host the games however, added that there is another option in case the two schools fail.

"The reputation of the people behind the schools gives us confidence and we are so hopeful that whatever isn't done yet will be done. Even when we were picking the host, we had plan B in Namilyango College as communicated during the bidding process. We have notified them and are also ready in case the worst comes to worst." Justus said.

"Uganda is hosting for the 6th time and there is no time we have been as organized as this time. In the 21 editions, no head of state has ever graced the event, this goes into history as the first of its kind so lets support the two schools."

He also assured the minister of the readiness of the teams to represent Uganda.

"The teams going to feature don't only have national exposure, they have gone to the international stage, represented ably which makes us believe that we have very good teams and we are going to make sure over-aged players don't feature in these games." Mugisha added.

Having looked at all factors, we believe Uganda will host, hosting FEASSA gives us even more ground ahead of hosting the AFCON and other Continental events.

Checklist will have accommodation facilities, Playing facilities, Medical ,transport accessibility, utilities and others.

Uganda last hosted these games in Gulu, Northern Uganda

post.Title: USSSA Ball games II count down
post.Content:
An exciting showdown, tension, adrenaline rush is coming down from the terrains of Soroti City.

The USSSA ball games II running from the 9th to 17 of July. The countdown is on.

Get ready for the exciting USSSA National Ball Games II 2024 as events unfold from Teso College Aloet, Soroti City.

Theme: "Fuel Your Passion, Ignite Your Game". Let's Go!

post.Title: Bukedea Comprehensive, Amus College School facilities inspected prior to 2024 FEASSSA Games
post.Content:
FEASSSA Games 2024

Chief Host: Bukedea Comprehensive School

Co-host: Amus College School

Dates: 16th – 27th August 2024

A delegation of officials from Uganda, Kenya, Tanzania, Rwanda and Burundi has on Tuesday, 18th June 2024 visited the facilities at the two host schools of this year’s FEASSSA Games in Bukedea region.

The inspection at Bukedea Comprehensive school and Amus College included the sports amenities, accommodation, medical, transport, administrative facilities and other utilities as water and electricity.

The Commissioner of physical education and sports in the ministry of education and sports Rev. Dr. Canon Duncans Mugumya was the chief guest during the inspection.

Rev. Dr. Mugumya, also the vice president of the Local Organizing Committee (LOC) represented the minister of state for sports Hon. Peter Ogwang.
“We are impressed by the facilities at both Bukedea Comprehensive and Amus College. This is a step in the right direction for Uganda’s sports to blossom. We believe that with the remaining time to come, the facilities will be polished up to have the best games” Rev. Dr. Canon Mugumya stated.
FEASSSA and USSSA president Justus Mugisha who chaired a plenary session at the Wash and Wills Hotel, Mbale city before the inspections briefed the members of the delegation about the entire developments.

He confirmed that the games village will be in Bukedea Comprehensive with all the girls accommodated at Bukedea Comprehensive whilst the boys will be at Amus College School with each having the ability to host over 2000 students.

Mugisha also notified about the special needs games village and the secretariat which is proposed to be at Amus College School.

“Uganda is ready to host the 2024 FEASSSA Games and this will be the first time that such games are played on facilities put in place entirely by school management. This is a milestone for FEASSSA as the sports facilities in place will also be used by other sports federations in the country, the region and on the continent. There is a race against time to have the facilities polished up which is achievable” Mugisha hinted.

Mugisha confirmed that the nation and cultural festivities will be held for all the schools from the different countries which will take part in the championship; a reason why these games have been extended from 10 to 11 days.

The inspection team also put into consideration other aspects as security of athletes, access to medical services and other essential utilities as electricity and water.

David Ngugi, the general secretary of FEASSSA lauded the management of Bukedea Comprehensive and Amus College with special caution to speeden up the process of putting up the facilities.

“As FEASSSA, we remain impressed by Bukedea Comprehensive and Amus College for putting in place such sports facilities. This is the first time that schools in FEASSSA region construct facilities specially for the games. There is however need to speed up the constructions and the necessary finishings to have the games successfully held. We shall have a plenary session on Wednesday for a Plan B in case the facilities fail on time” Ngugi remarked.

There are 17 competition grounds for the 2024 FEASSSA Games with a state of art swimming pool, in-door facility and a football stadium being constructed at Bukedea Comprehensive.

Five football grounds have been put up at Amus College School including four natural grass pitches and the main astro turf stadium.

The games will commence on 16th August and run until 27th August 2024.

post.Title: All is set for the fresh Dairy girls' football - Ndejje
post.Content:
What you need to know

The eight schools that qualified for quarter finals reported to Ndejje University where they shall be residing. The games will kick off on Wednesday 19th at Standard High School Zzana.

The Girls Football games resume at quarter final stage having been halted last month due to National team engagements.

Defending champions, Amus College School will taste the waters first as they take on Sacred Heart SSS Gulu in an early morning encounter.

Amus College captain Tamisi Shafiga expressed confidence in her teammates to deliver the trophy to Teso once more.

"As we managed to win it last year, we are here defend it. We know how good our opponents are but we believe we can beat them."

Later, all attention will be driven onto the Kampala derby featuring Uganda Martyrs High School Lubaga and Kawempe Muslim SS. A repeat of Kampala zone final that was played at Kibuli SS in April where the former triumphed and lifted the girls' crown.

Uganda Martyrs will look to seal a place at the FEASSSA games in August hosted by Bukedea Comprehensive and Amus while Kawempe already booked their slot in Teso as defending champions.

2022 East Africa champions St. Noa Girls' School will climax the day as they lock horns with Isingiro based Boni Consili Vocational Girls' School.

All the last 8 games will be played at Standard High School Zana and will be live on FUFA TV

  • Amus College School vs Sacred Heart SSS Gulu
  • Kawempe Muslim SS vs Uganda Martyrs High School Lubaga
  • Rines SS vs Sheema Girls
  • Boni Consili Vocational Girls School vs St. Noa Girls' School

post.Title: Fresh Dairy Games: Amus seals semi final spot.
post.Content:
Overview

Opisa Shayine hatrick was instrumental in seeing Teso zone representatives step foot in the semi finals. Amus have progressed following an impressive 5-0 win over Sacred Heart SSS Gulu

Amus has resumed from where they stopped in the Fresh Dairy Girls Football Quarter finals played at Standard High School Zana.

Opisa Shayine opened the score for Amus College School in the 3rd minute of the game with a well driven shot just in front of the 18 yard box.

Opisa put a fine ball past the Sacred Heart shot stopper minutes later to double her and Amus' tally just before the break.

The quarter final became an Opisa affair as she completed a perfect hattrick just at the restart of the game. Edna Wanda got on the score sheet having tapped in at a close range from a corner kick before Doreen Wandera added the fifth.

Amus College is through to the semi finals and will await the winner between Rines SS and Sheema Girls who will play later in the day.

Meanwhile Sacred Heart SSS who looked a shadow of themselves for large spells of the game will embark on the classification matches to confirm their National ranking.

post.Title: Kawempe Muslim SS sidelines Uganda Martyrs to book semi final Slot.
post.Content:
By Catherine Kasemeza

Overview

Kawempe Muslim and Uganda Martyrs High School Lubaga played out a goalless draw in regular time. Uganda Martyrs captain Immaculate Nakanjako missed the first penalty while Kawempe were inch perfect to outshoot the Lubaga based school.

The first half was an intense and action-packed one, with neither team able to score, ending in a goalless draw. The second half was equally thrilling, with both teams creating scoring opportunities but failing to capitalize, resulting in another goalless encounter which was great for the neutrals.

With the score still deadlocked at 0-0 after full-time, the match went to penalties. Kawempe Muslim High School showed their prowess, converting all five of their penalties to win 5-3 and advance to the semifinals.

Shamusa Najjuma, Uganda Martyrs player emphasized the need for her teammates to stay heads up after their loss to Kawempe Muslim S.S

"Although we lost Kawempe Muslim S.S, I hope that we did our best. I thank my team and our coaches for the efforts and I ask them not to give up because we have other games to play, next time better. "

Kawempe Muslim will play the winner between St. Noa and Boni Consili Girls' School.

post.Title: FRESH DAIRY GAMES: St. Noa books a date with Kawempe in the semi finals.
post.Content:
overview

St. Noa Girls' School outshone Boni Consili Girls' School as they put seven past them. Sumaiyah Nalumu and Sylvia Kabeene steered the Wakiso side as they scored a brace and hatrick respectively

St. Noa put up a seven star performance in the last quarter final of the day that was played at Standard High School Zzana Ndejje campus.

Nancy Mandera's strike and Boni Consili Girls' Mackline Niwandinda own goal completed the week to nil score.

Today's hatrick takes Sylvia Kabeene's goal tally to 22 so far in this year's championship.

St. Noa now match to the semi finals where they will play Kampala's Kawempe Muslim SS. Kawempe defeated Uganda Martyrs High School Lubaga 5-3 in penalties after playing out a stalemate in regular time.

Meanwhile Ankole representatives Consili will embark on the classification games to mark their National position.

post.Title: FRESH DAIRY GAMES: Semi final show down in Ndejje.
post.Content:
In brief

Kawempe Muslim SS will face St. Noa Girls' School while Amus College School will lock horns with Rines SS to fight for a slot in the final. All the four schools will represent Uganda in FEASSSA that will be hosted in Bukedea.

Quarter final results

  • Amus College School 5-0 Sacred Heart SSS Gulu
  • Kawempe Muslim SS 5 (0)-(0)3 Uganda Martyrs High School Lubaga
  • Rines SS 2-1 Sheema Girls School
  • St. Noa Girls' School 7-0 Boni Consili Girls School

Wakiso- Kawempe, Wakiso - Teso affairs will lighten Ndejje in the semi finals to be played tomorrow.

Kawempe Muslim SS who is reigning East African champion will look to lift a first Nationals trophy post- covid while St. Noa will look to bounce back from a finals defeat to Amus College School last year in Mbarara.

Amus College School, also holders of the National Fresh Dairy prestigious trophy will look to return with joy to Teso having failed to deliver in the boy's category.

Rines SS look will take aim to stamp themselves among the nation's best having secured back to back FEASSSA qualifications in the championship.

Thursday fixtures

  • 9:00 Sheema Girls School vs Boni Consili Girls' School
  • 11:00 Uganda Martyrs High School Lubaga
  • 2:00 Amus College School vs Rines SS (live on FUFA TV)
  • 4:00 Kawempe Muslim SS vs St. Noa Girls' School (live on FUFA TV)

post.Title: Bukedea given greenlight in readiness to host FEASSSA games 2024.
post.Content:
FEASSA (Federation of East Africa School Sports Associations) Inspections for 2024 has been concluded in Eastern Uganda the hosting region, and positive feedback from the visiting delegation have been put forward . The inspection contingent, comprising representatives from Rwanda, Kenya, Tanzania, and Uganda(hosts) was warmly welcomed by Rev.Can .Dr. Duncans Mugumya – Head of Delegation Uganda

During their visit, the Commissioner of physical education Rev.Can .Dr. Duncans Mugumya on behalf of the state minister of sports Hon. Peter Ogwang assured the delegation of Uganda’s readiness to host the games and thanked them for the sprint of East Africa brotherhood.

The inspection started on 18th of June 2024, and the delegation embarked on the activities in Bukedea district, to assess progress of the host schools (Bukedea Comprehensive and) in both accommodation and competition venues with the primary objective of ensuring that the proposed facilities meet the high standards set by FEASSA. The delegation carefully evaluated various aspects, including the quality and suitability of accommodation, as well as the venues for different sporting disciplines.

As a result of the inspection, the delegation has made remarks regarding the sports pitches and facilities. There was a need to identify pitches for specific disciplines as follows: one hockey pitch, one football pitch, and one rugby pitch. These recommendations aim to ensure that each sporting discipline has suitable and dedicated venues for the upcoming games.

The inspection team was pleased with the level of preparedness displayed by Uganda through the two host schools, the recommended venues and accommodations meet the required standards for hosting the FEASSSA games though with further improvements. These recommendations will contribute to the smooth organization and execution of the sporting event.

With the conclusion of the first FEASSA Inspection 2024, Uganda is now supposed to improve on not yet to be finished facilities before the final inspection in mid July. The positive feedback from the visiting delegation along with the approved venues and accommodations further solidifies Uganda’s position as a capable and well-prepared host nation but with some improvement .

post.Title: FRESH DAIRY GAMES : Sheema stings Sacred Heart Gulu.
post.Content:
Overview

Sheema Girls triumphed over Sacred Heart SSS Gulu girls team after a narrow 1-0 win. In the fight for positions 5 - 8 the win takes Sheema Girls to compete for 5/6th place while Sacred Heart can only fight for 7/8th position.

Daniela Ahumuza strike in the 13th minute gave Sheema Girls' School a lead which they fought tooth and nail to preserve for the remaining minutes of the first period.

The second half was a much balanced end to end action packed as either side pushed for a goal. Neither of the two was able to utilize the clear cut chances they managed with Sheema Girls denied by the wood work on two occasions while Sacred Heart often lacked the final pass.

Sheema Girls' School will play the winner between Uganda Martyrs High School Lubaga and Boni Consili Girls' School for 5/6th place.

Meanwhile Sacred Heart SSS Gulu will play the loser of the two for the 7/8th position.

post.Title: FRESH DAIRY GAMES: Uganda Martyrs sidelines Boni Consili
post.Content:
Overview

Shamusa Najjuma and Sharon Kanyiginya first half goals were enough for Uganda Martyrs Lubaga to see off a resilient Boni Consili who only managed to pull a single goal back. The two played in the second classification of the day for positions 5-8.

Kampala zone champions Uganda Martyrs High School Lubaga had a great start to the game scoring twice in the Opening ten minutes.

Shamusa Najjuma came up with an out of the world strike where she caught Boni Consili's shotstopper in no man's land to give the Lubaga side an early lead.

The Kiddas continued to pile pressure on the Boni Consili defence where their efforts were rewarded in the 9th minute where Sharon Kanyiginya shot deflected off the defender to beat Ninsima Benitah the Amus goalie.

It all seemed like a smooth ride for Uganda Martyrs until the 29th minute where Ariho Rinah pulled one back.

The Boni Consili goal was the turning point of the game as they were more direct which caused Uganda Martyrs plenty of problems.

Uganda Martyrs fended off the pressure and held onto their lead which takes them to vie for 5/6th position.

Following this defeat, Boni Consili Girls' School will play Sacred Heart SSS Gulu on 21st June for 7/8th position while Uganda Martyrs High School Lubaga will take on Sheema Girls' School to confirm 5/6th position holders.

  • 8:00 am Sacred Heart SSS Gulu vs Boni Consili (Ndejje SSS) - position 7-8
  • 8:00 am Sheema Girls School vs Uganda Martyrs High School Lubaga - 5-6th

post.Title: FRESH DAIRY GAMES : Rines heads Amus out, through to final.
post.Content:
Overview

A header in either half was enough to send Rines SS to the final. Rines beat Amus College 2-0 to seal a place in the girls football final 2024.

Amus played Rines SS at Standard High School Zzana Ndejje campus play ground in the first semi finals of the day.

Rines SS struck first in the first half with Rinah Ayerango's eighteenth minute header making the difference on the day.

Amus who were second best in most parts of the first period, suffered as they couldn't match the pace of Rines' forwards.

Amus College's best chance came in the 34th minute where Edinah Wandera sliced through Rines' defence to set up Edna Wanda on her right. Rines goalie had all it took to save Wanda's strike and a corner was the best they attained from the move.

In the 50th minute goal scorer Ayerango turned provider to Halima Mupyanga with a sweet cross.

Halima's header squandered Amus' hopes for a comeback as they failed to create any clear cut chances.

Meanwhile, Rines SS will wait for winner between Kawempe Muslim SS and St. Noa Girls' School to know their opponent in the final while Amus College will play the loser in the same fixture.

post.Title: FRESH DAIRY GAMES: Kawempe through to the final.
post.Content:
Overview

Kawempe Muslim put St. Noa at an arms length to match into the final. Hadijah Babirye's first half header was enough to guarantee them a spot in the final.

Semi final 2 full time result

Kawempe Muslim SS 1-0 St. Noa Girls' School

A goal at the half hour mark was enough to seal victory for the Kampala zone finalists.

Kawempe captain Sharifah Nakimera delivered a nice free kick into the forbidden area where Babirye Hadijah was on time to head the Kawempe side into the lead.

St. Noa troubled Kawempe's defence with intricate passes from speed stars like Sylvia Kabeene and Sumaiyah Nalumu but all went in vain

St. Noa largely depended on Sumaiyah Nalumu's magic in whipping crosses into the box but didn't materialize for this game as Kawempe defence were up to the mark.

The victory means Kawempe will battle Rines SS in the girls football final that will be played tomorrow at Standard High School Zzana Ndejje campus at 10:00 am EAT.

Meanwhile St. Noa will lock horns with Amus College in the third place play off at 8:00 am.

post.Title: FRESH DAIRY GAMES : Rines eyes maiden National title against Kawempe.
post.Content:
Overview

Kawempe Muslim SS are the record champions of the Fresh Dairy Girls Football championship while Rines SS will look to make history by lifting their first.

Final Matchday fixtures

  • Rines SS vs Kawempe Muslim SS 2:00 pm -Final
  • Amus College School vs St. Noa Girls' School 12:00 pm - 3rd place play off
  • Sheema Girls' School vs Uganda Martyrs High School Lubaga
  • Boni Consili vs Sacred Heart SSS Gulu

Route to the final

Kawempe Muslim SS edged Uganda Martyrs High School Lubaga 5-3 in penalties having played a goalless draw at the quarter finals. They went ahead to beat St. Noa Girls' School 1-0 in the semi final thanks to a Hadijah Babirye first half header.

Meanwhile, Rines SS came from a goal down to defeat Sheema Girls' School 2-1 to qualify for the semi finals. The Wakiso based sided went ahead and beat Amus College School 2-0 thanks to goals by Ayerango Prisca and Halima Mupyanga.

Will Rines make history or will Kawempe continue to seal their spot at the top of the game?

Elsewhere, Amus College School will battle for third place against St. Noa Girls's School while Uganda Martyrs and Sheema Girls' School will vie for 5/6th positions as Boni Consili Girls' will fight for 7/8th place.

post.Title: FRESH DAIRY GAMES : Boni Consili seal 7th place.
post.Content:
Overview

In the 7/8th place play off played at Standard High School Zzana Ndejje campus, Boni Consili defeated Sacred Heart SSS Gulu to cement themselves in 7th position nationwide.

7/8th place play off Full time result

Boni Consili 4-0 Sacred Heart SSS Gulu

    Boni Consili started on the front foot from the first whistle as they exhibited a lot of hunger for goals.

    Boni Consili's efforts were rewarded later as they managed to score two goals in the opening twenty minutes of the duel.

    Peace Ayirwoth and Precious Ankunda gave Boni a two goals advantage before the end of the first period.

    Peace Ayirwoth later added Boni's 3rd and fourth which completed her hatrick ten minutes into the second half.

    This result installs Boni Consili in 7th position and Sacred Heart SSS Gulu 8th in the Fresh Dairy Girls Football championship 2024- Ndejje.

    With either team failing to replicate the fine form they had in the opening games of the championship, they will be glad to have atleast finished among the national's best eight.

post.Title: FRESH DAIRY GAMES : Sheema Girls' School, Uganda Martyrs confirm 6th, 5th places.
post.Content:
Overview

From the Fresh Dairy Girls Football 2024, Uganda Martyrs High School Lubaga and Sheema Girls' School have been confirmed as 5th and 6th respectively in the National rankings.

Full time result - 5/6th place play off

Uganda Martyrs High School Lubaga 3-0 Sheema Girls' School

Three first half goals for Uganda Martyrs were all it took to separate the two sides.

Shamusa Najjuma struck first to give Uganda Martyrs an early lead into the game before Sharon Kanyiginya and Nusurah Nakintu added to the score line.

In the second half, Sheema pushed hard to get back into the game but nothing came into fruition. The closest they came to scoring was in the 60th minute when they were awarded an indirect penalty after Uganda Martyrs goalie made a blunder but failed to capitalize.

Uganda Martyrs went ahead to win the game with a 3-0 score line.

Therefore, from the Fresh Dairy Girls Football 2024, Uganda Martyrs High School Lubaga and Sheema Girls' School have been confirmed as 5th and 6th respectively in the National rankings.

post.Title: FRESH DAIRY GAMES : Kawempe Muslim SS are 2024 champions.
post.Content:
Overview

Kawempe Muslim SS are the champions of the fresh Dairy Girls Football 2024! They beat Rines SS 5-4 in penalties having played out a goalless draw in regular time.

Full time result

Kawempe Muslim SS 5(0)-(0)4 Rines SS

Crowds in Ndejje were served a game of their lives as two top sides all fought tooth and nail to clinch the girls' football title 2024.

The clash full of end to end action, ended in a goalless draw and therefore spot kicks were the day's savior.

Kawempe goalie Haira Nabbosa made two superb stops from the spot kicks to deliver the trophy to the Kawempe based side.

What does this victory imply?

This victory cements Kawempe Muslim at the epitome of Fresh Dairy Girls' Football. Kawempe Muslim is the record champion of the championship having won it a record 8 times and this only widens it's gap at the top.

Coach Moses Nkata will be very proud of the girls for delivering their second USSSA trophy this year having won the Elite Games in Jinja that took place in January.

Meanwhile, Rines SS will be proud to have made it to their first Fresh Dairy Girls' Football final. Rines SS under the stewardship of head coach Bright Nyanzi experienced third place finishes on a couple of occasions in the championship even recently in Mbarara although they qualified for FEASSA games in Rwanda.

A silver medal is not a mean feat that anyone would underlook.

Amus College School scooped bronze at this year's edition.

Following the conclusion of this year's Fresh Dairy Girls' Football edition, Kawempe Muslim SS will represent Uganda as gold medalists, Rines - silver, Amus College School - bronze and St. Noa in Bukedea later this year.

Individual accolades

Most valuable Player - Ayerango Prisca

Top scorer - Sylvia Kabeene, St. Noa Girls' School (22 goals)

Best Goal keeper - Nansamba Bridget (Rines SS)

post.Title: ISF BASKETBALL : Two teams to represent Uganda in Macao, China flagged off.
post.Content:
Overview

Uganda will be represented by Elite High School in the boys category and the U-18 FIBA Africa Zone V Basketball qualifiers champions in the girls category. The ISF Basketball will run from 23rd June to 3rd July in Macao- China.

The two teams two represent Uganda in Macao, China at the ISF Basketball world cup have been flagged off at Africa Bible University.

Ambrose Tashobya, chairman National Council of Sports was the chief guest at the flag off ceremony. Justus Mugisha USSSA President will be the head of delegation to China.

Other officials present at the flag off ceremony.

  • Rev. Can. Dr. Duncans Mugumya - Commissioner Physical Education and Sports Ministry of Education and Sports.
  • Justus Mugisha -USSSA President (leader of delegation)
  • Patrick Okanya - President Emeritus - USSSA
  • Mugisha Christopher Banange - CEO, USSSA

Ambrose Tashobya the chief guest on the occasion emphasized athletes to remember as they play, they are still students.

"As you play, keep it in mind that you are student athletes. As you compete keep it in mind that in basketball, ball possession is the most important thing. Once you have the possession you will have a higher chance to win because you will have very many opportunities to shoot. "- Ambrose Tashobya, chief guest

Rev. Can. Duncans Mugumya encouraged the athletes to represent Uganda in their best versions and to the fullest on and off the court.

"I urge you to be disciplined, representing Uganda is a big opportunity which you must use well to expose yourself. I want to thank USSSA for the work they are doing most especially with the measures put in place to remove age cheating in sports. Go and do your best the results will come."- Rev. Can. Dr.Duncans Mugumya Commissioner Physical Education and Sports

Justus Mugisha also USSSA President expressed his gratitude to the government for the funding and also encouraged athletes to perform at their very best.

"We are currently performing well in international championships, currently we are one of the most active members of ISF. We were represented by three teams at the Volleyball Championship in Serbia, four teams at the football championship in China, A team for athletics in Kenya and we have been performing well."-Justus Mugisha USSSA President also head of delegation.

Team Uganda will be captained by Christine Namyalo with the commissioner as head of delegation.

post.Title: USSSA BALL GAMES II QUALIFIERS: Road to Teso in Otuke.
post.Content:
What you need to know

The top teams will now proceed to the zonal qualifiers at Doctor Obote College in Lira from the 26th to the 28th June, where they will compete for a spot at the National Championship in Soroti City next Month.

The USSSA District qualifiers in Otuke District came to a thrilling conclusion at Okwang Secondary School, with five schools competing in a showcase of athletic excellence.

Adwari Secondary School, Okwang Secondary School the host School and the defending champion, Ogor Secondary School, Otuke Secondary School, and Orum Secondary School all vied for top honors in the sole sport of athletics.

After a day of intense competition, Adwari SS emerged victorious with an impressive 373 points. Okwang SS followed with 286 points, while Ogor SS, Orum SS, and Otuke SS trailed with 249, 182, and 93 points, respectively.


SUMMARY OF RESULTS
1.Adwari SS 373
2.Okwang SS 286
3.Ogor SS 249
4.Orum SS 182
5.Otuke SS 93

The Chairperson of USSSA Otuke District commended the participants on their hard work and dedication, warning games teachers against bringing non-bonafide students to these events. "We will not tolerate any form of age cheating," they emphasized.

Otuke District Sports Officer, Obira James, expressed his gratitude to Okwang SS and the local community for their warm hospitality. He also announced plans to expand the district's sporting horizons, introducing volleyball and netball to the tournament roster next year.

The top teams will now proceed to the zonal qualifiers at Doctor Obote College in Lira from the 26th to the 28th June, where they will compete for a spot at the National Championship in Soroti City next Month.

Source: Mukwaya Arnold

post.Title: Uganda Secures Thrilling Victory in ISF World Schools Basketball Championship Opener
post.Content:
In an electrifying start to the ISF World Schools Basketball Championship, Uganda's national team emerged victorious in their opening game against Brazil, winning 45-41 in overtime.

The highly anticipated match took place at the University of Macao arena in China, with Uganda facing off against a formidable Brazilian team. Despite a slow start, which saw Uganda trailing 9-8 at the end of the first quarter, the team rallied in the second quarter to take a 16-10 lead.

Brazil refused to back down, however, and the two teams engaged in a back-and-forth battle that saw Uganda ultimately prevail in overtime. Marial Mandiria was the star of the show, scoring 10 points and leading his team to a hard-fought victory.

Coach Egau Johnathan praised his team's resilience and determination despite the fatigue after arriving late.

The boy's were down but in the upcoming games we will rectify the mistakes and return when we are more strong to fight for more wins" he said

The Ugandan team will face off against Chile in their next match, scheduled for June 25 at 13:45 local time in Macao. With their confidence soaring and their sights set on the championship title.

Match Highlights:

  • Uganda vs Brazil: Uganda won 45-41 (overtime)
  • First Quarter Uganda 8-9 Brazil
  • Second Quarter Uganda 16-10 Brazil
  • Third Quarter Uganda 10-16
  • Fourth Quarter Uganda 6-5 Brazil
  • Top scorer: Marial Mandiria (10 points)
  • Next match: Uganda vs Chile, June 25, 13:45 local time (Macao)

Upcoming Schedule:

  • Uganda vs Chile: June 25, 8:45 am EAT
  • Uganda vs Mongolia: June 26, 8:45 am EAT
  • Uganda vs Serbia: June 27, 6:45 am EAT

post.Title: USSSA SPLITS BALL GAMES II INTO TWO.
post.Content:
BALL GAMES II

The Uganda Secondary Schools Sports Association (USSSA) has announced the split of Ball Games II. This is the largest championship and has attracted even more games. Just last year, the championship brought together over 7,000 participants and officials

The split has been due to the introduction of the under-16 category games and new disciplines namely mind games(Luddo, Chess, and Scrabble) which has led to the surge of participants and officials from 7,000 to over 11,000.

The FEASSSA qualifiers scheduled for July 9th to 17th at Teso College Aloet include Netball, Volleyball, Basketball 3x3, Handball, Rugby 7s, and Athletics. On the other hand, the non-FEASSSA qualifiers, taking place from September 1st to 9th, 2024 will comprise of U16 participants in (Football, Basketball 3x3, Netball, Volleyball, Basketball, Handball) DanceSport, Lacrosse, Woodball, Mind Games, Beach Soccer, and Beach Volleyball.

According to Justus Mugisha the USSSA President

“One of our main aims this year is to increase participation of secondary school students in sports at the district, zonal, and National levels, referred to as mass sports." He highlighted their participation in international school sports tournaments, including Volleyball (Belgrade, Serbia), Athletics (Nairobi, Kenya), Football (Dalian city, China), and Basketball (Macau, China).

Patrick Okanya, President Emeritus USSSA and Head of Capacity Building Training Program, emphasized their focus on capacity building, giving examples of referees who have had a chance to officiate at national championships and international engagements, including the ISF World Schools Cup in Dalian, China.

FEASSSA GAMES IN BUKEDEA 2024

This year's FEASSSA games will be hosted in Uganda at Bukedea Comprehensive and Amus College School in Eastern Uganda.

The president noted that preparations are underway and the swimming pool is 95 percent complete and assured everyone of a successful championship.

The construction of a swimming pool at Bukedea Comprehensive while the stadium is at Amus College School. ISF President, Laurent Petrynka is expected to be present at the event, and dignitaries from the Federation of Africa School Sports(FASS).

The National Organising Committee was by the First Lady and Minister of Education of Sports, the committee is chaired by State Minister for Sports - Hon. Ogwang Peter, and Deputised by the Commissioner of Physical Education and Sports - Rev. Can. Dr. Duncans Mugumya

post.Title: ISF BASKETBALL: Uganda's winning streak ends with a narrow loss to Mongolia.
post.Content:
Uganda's basketball team fell short against Mongolia, losing 51-50 in a nail-biting contest today. Despite leading the first two quarters, Uganda's momentum faltered in the third, allowing Mongolia to tie the game in the final quarter.

Edrine Ekau emerged as Uganda's standout player, scoring an impressive 20 points. However, the team's inability to secure a win means they missed an opportunity to cement their quarterfinal spot.

Uganda now tops Group D with 5 points, while Serbia and Mongolia trail closely with 4 points each. The team will face Serbia in their final group fixture on Saturday, 29th.

Coach Egau Jonathan attributed the loss to his team's lack of focus and failure to follow instructions. "The boys lacked concentration on the court, and we failed to win comfortably as we had planned. They relaxed and didn't follow instructions," he said.

However, Coach Egau remains optimistic, viewing this setback as a valuable lesson for both the players and the technical team. "This will serve as a lesson for us in the upcoming games," he added.

post.Title: Uganda girls' basketball Team faces setback in ISF World Schools Championship
post.Content:
The Ugandan girls' basketball team got off to a disappointing start at the ISF World Schools Basketball Championship, losing to Chinese Taipei 43-69.

Abigail Mpoza Lucy was a bright spot for Uganda, showcasing her skills in defense and transition play. Despite her efforts, the team struggled to keep pace with their opponents.

The match seemed to slip away from Uganda's grasp from the outset, with Chinese Taipei dominating all four quarters. The final whistle blew with the scoreboard reading 43-69 in favor of the Taiwanese team.

Coach Jonathan Egau attributed the loss to his team's respect for their opponents and poor game management. "The girls panicked and failed to handle the speedy and accurate Chinese Taipei team," he said. "We could have closed the gap, but poor game management and concentration held us back."

Despite the setback, Coach Egau remains optimistic about his team's chances in the tournament. "We will work on improving our defense, shooting, and game management," he said. "We still have a chance to advance to the next level, and we're determined to grab it."

The Ugandan team, the only African representative in Group C, will face China 2 on Thursday, June 27th, at 11:45 local time (6:45 AM EAT). With a renewed focus on strategy and teamwork, they hope to bounce back from this initial loss and make a stronger showing in the tournament.

The team's next match against China 2 promises to be a thrilling encounter, with Uganda seeking redemption and China 2 looking to maintain their momentum.

The ISF World Schools Basketball Championship continues to showcase the talents of young basketball players from around the world, with Uganda's team determined to make their mark on the competition.

post.Title: ISF BASKETBALL: Uganda girls' team falls to China II in second game.
post.Content:
Match Statistics

1st quarter: Uganda 13-16 China; 2nd quarter: Uganda 7-16 China; 3rd quarter: Uganda 11-11 China; 4th quarter: Uganda 10-18 China.

Uganda's girls basketball team suffered their second defeat in the tournament, losing 61-41 to China II. This follows their 69-43 loss to Chinese Taipei in the first game.

The game was closely contested, with China II edging out Uganda in each quarter.

Despite the loss, Uganda showed improvement in their performance, with Captain Christine Namyalo leading the charge with an impressive 12 points. Uganda's performance in the third quarter, where they tied with China, showed their potential and growth in the tournament.

Uganda currently sits last in their group with 2 points from two games played. Their final group game is against France on Saturday.

While their chances of advancing to the knockout stage are slim, Coach Egau Johnathan remains optimistic, viewing this tournament as a valuable learning experience for his team.

This is a learning ground for us to prepare these girls for future games," Coach Egau said. "We will approach the game against France as a big game and aim to end on a high note."

post.Title: MPIGI ZONE CONCLUDES BALL GAMES II QUALIFIERS.
post.Content:
Mpigi zone finalized all their games for the upcoming Ball games II on 27th June 2024 at St. Joseph of Nazareth in Mpigi district. The disciplines that were competed for on the final day included athletics, basketball 3x3, beach soccer and Dance Sport.

Volleyball, netball and football all in the under 16 categories were played earlier at Bukandula Mixed and Kabulasoke PTC in Gomba district.

Royal Giant High School Mityana scored two unanswered goals against Kisozi Seed School to lift the boys’ football trophy while Highway SS Kiganda in Mubende were the girls’ champions.

“We are so grateful for the competition, we are looking forward to see our teams go to Soroti and we are going to make it. I can’t forget to thank the directors, head teachers and games teacher of the schools that have participated in all the competitions”. Ssebanenya Vincent, Mpigi Zone Chairperson

The schools that competed in Netball included Ssingo SS, Kyasanku Hill College, Shammah High, Wamatovu Muslim, Bageza Seed, St. Thereza Kungu, St. Balikuddembe Mitala Maria, Kibibi Standard SS, Mpigi Light College, Kibibi Standard SS and Ngando SS who lifted the girls’ trophy at the end of the day.

Football: Kisozi Seed, Ngando SS, Butawuka Magezi, Mubende Army, St Balikudembe Mitala Maria,Bulo Parents,Gombe SS,Royal Giant Mityana

Volleyball (Boys) Wamatovu Muslim SS, St. Balikuddembe

The Most Valuable players included The following:

Beach Soccer -Atiku Fred –St. Lawrence Paris Palais

Dance Sport (Girls) –Ishimwe Shamim –St. Lawrence Paris Palais

Dance Sport (Boys)-Ntulume –St. Lawrence Crown City

Mpigi will be represented by the following schools

Ngando SS and Gombe SS - Netball

Royal Giant Mityana and Kisozi Seed SS –Football (Boys)

Highway SS Kiganda and Shammah High, Mityana-Football (Girls)

Gombe SS and St. Maria Goretti Katende –Basketball (Girls)

Mubende Army and St. Balikudembe –Volleyball (Boys)

St. Balikudembe and Kitenga SS,Mubende –Volleyball (Girls)

St. Lawrence Paris Palais – Basketball (Boys)

St. Balikudembe-DanceSport (Boys)

St. Lawrence Paris Palais-DanceSport (Girls)

Mubende Army –Beach Soccer (Boys)

Destiny Eagles Katende-Beach Soccer (Girls)

Mpigi Zone is made of up Mubende, Butamabala, Gomba, Mityana, Kasanda and Mpigi districts.

The FEASSSA qualifiers will be played at Teso College Aloet 9-18th July 2024 while the Non-FEASSSA qualifiers will take place during the second term holiday from 1st to 9th September at the same venue.

post.Title: Ball Games II: Kitgum Ready For Acholi Zonal Qualifiers – Okot P’ Bitek USSSA 2nd Vice President
post.Content:
Kitgum district will host USSSA Ball Games II Acholi Zonal qualifiers scheduled for 28-30th June 2024 at Bomah Grounds, 8 districts that make up the Acholi Region are expected to present their teams.
Over 500 athletes are expected to participate in the games, including Javelin, Short Put, Discuss, High Jump, Track events, Rugby 7s, Netball, Handball and Volleyball.
All teams are expected to arrive on Friday 28th June and will be subject to commence at 2 pm, this is done to verify the eligibility of participants.
Teams that qualify from here will represent the Acholi Zone in the USSSA National Ball Games II that will take place in Soroti (Teso Region) at Teso College Aloet from 9th -17th July.

According to the host led by their chairperson who doubles as the 2nd Vice President of USSSA, Kitgum is ready to host the games.
“Kitgum preparation is in high gear, the girls will be accommodated at Y.Y Okot Memorial College and the boys at Kitgum Core PTC, we have done all the necessary mobilization. Athletics (Track and field events) will be held at the Bomah Grounds while the Ball games will be at Y.Y Okot playgrounds.”

Okot P' Biteke while speaking to Omaria Bosco the USSSADirector Marketing and Communications


In the same spirit the District Schools Sports Chairperson Oringa Richard added, “for the preparations, the Municipal has helped to clean the toilets and grounds to see that the games go on well.


Amena Bosco the delegate representing the UAF “we are here to witness how the games are organized and to offer technical guidance, and in addition, these games help the federation to identify talent which is nurtured to international champions, we also measured the field and confirmed that it meets the standards”.

The head coach of Kitgum athletics team stated that his team is ready to defend their title as zonal champions.

"My team is ready to defend our title as the zonal champions and also go represent the zone in the national championship. We want to go back and also defender our national title since we wee the overall winners in both boys and girls in last year's competitions that were held in Kabale at St Mary's College Rushoroza"

Aloyo Charity a student-athlete from Comprehensive Main Campus believes she and the entire team will ably compete and defend their reign.

"I was the champion in short put and I believe with the hard work we put in, we are going achieve as we head into the games tomorrow". She stated


Agago, Amuru, Gulu, Kitgum, Lamwo, Nyoya, and Pader Omoro are the 8 districts that make up the Acholi zone and we expect many teams from different schools to participate in the USSSA National Ball Games II Acholi zone qualifiers.

post.Title: USSSA Ball Games II : Mukono zone qualifiers a whistle away.
post.Content:
Overview

Latifah Mixed SS- Mukono will play host for the boys and girls under- 16 football to be played on 29th June. Netball, volleyball and handball will be hosted by Hilton SS Mukono on Sunday 30th June.

In the boys' under-16 category, the 8 participating teams were grouped into 2 in a meeting that was chaired by Mukono zone Chairperson Mr. Richard Muhumuza at Mukono Kings High School on 27th in attendance of the different games teachers.

Group A ( Kikube C/U playground)

  • Quality High School Buikwe
  • Dynamic SS
  • Vision For Africa
  • Lord's Meade SS - Buikwe

Group B (Kabimbiri Play ground)

  • Mt. St. Henry's Mukono
  • Namagabi SS
  • Latifah Mixed SS
  • St. Andrew's Lugazi

Meanwhile in the girls' category, four teams will compete for the coveted slot at the National championship. The five will play in round robin format and the one that collects the highest amount of points will be champion.

The Girls' Football matches will be played at Mubanda Secondary School- Kasawo play ground.

Girls U16 ( Mubanda SS playground)

  • Mukono Kings H/S
    •St. John's HS Mukono
  • Amazima School - Buikwe
  • Home stone Lugazi
  • Lord's Mead SS

Luboyera Herbert, games teacher at Latifah Mixed SS (host) was on site to address the USSSA Media about the readiness of the Mukono zone to host the games.

"The playgrounds are in the right conditions, well marked and available for the zone games. Girls' Football will be played for only one day that is Sunday since the teams are few. For the boys, group stages will be played on Saturday 29th and later semi finals, classification and the final will be played on Sunday at Kabimbiri play ground."-Luboyera Herbert.

Slot allocation

Mukono zone as per 2024 has 2 slots for the U16 boys in contrast to the one slot available for the girls' football. Therefore, the winner in the girls' category and the two that will qualify for the boys' final will book their slots at the National championship.

Football grouped under the non- FEASSA ball games will be played later via this year at Teso College Aloet- Soroti from 1st to 9th September.

post.Title: USSSA LANGO ZONAL QUALIFIERS BECOME EXCITING.
post.Content:
Day two of Lango zonal qualifiers has been yet a great day like no other with very high expectations from different camps on who will make it to Teso.
By the close of the day some teams were already on cloud nine because of their excellent performance that earned them slots to Ball games II.

In handball Maruzi Seed School and Doctor College qualified for Ball Games II and finishing first and second in their groups respectively since Lango Zone has only two slots in handball boys compared one for girls who are Maruzi Seed School girls team that won St Katherine by 11:9.

Football under 16 boys which saw two teams that is Mentor SS and Lira Town College compete for the only one slot allocated to the Zone. Mentor SS emerged victorious after winning Lira Town College by 2 the nil in a highly anticipated game. The Zone did not have teams participating in girls football.

Winners of Volleyball boys are Mentor SS and Akalo SS and topping their group and girls teams are St Katherine SS and St Mary's Magdalen SS who are the only girls teams that have taken part in the tournament.

post.Title: Bunyoro Zonal Secondary School Ball Games II Kick off with a Bang.
post.Content:
The Bunyoro Zone Secondary School Ball Games II kicked off yesterday with great excitement as schools from around the region arrived at the St Theresa Girls Secondary School and Victory High School Masindi, eager to compete in the highly anticipated tournament.

However, the excitement was short-lived for some schools as the organizers announced a serious screening process to ensure that all participating students met the age and eligibility requirements.

The screening process, which took place at the beginning of the tournament, revealed that some schools had overaged and fake education document students participating in the under 16 football championship. Unfortunately, St Adolf and Premier SS from Hoima City were disqualified from the competition due to these infractions.

Despite the setbacks, the tournament continued with a bang as the remaining schools took to the field to showcase their skills. Panyadoli SS dominated St Patrick SS with a convincing 4-0 win, while Mandela SS and St Patrick SS played out a thrilling 1-1 draw.

Meanwhile, Nalweyo SS put up a good fight but ultimately lost 1-3 to St Charlene.

As the dust settled on the first day of competition, the teams looked forward to the remaining fixtures, which are set to take place tomorrow starting at 8am. The excitement is building, and fans are eagerly anticipating another day of thrilling matches and intense competition.

Will Panyadoli SS continue their winning streak? Can Mandela SS bounce back from their draw? And what surprises do the remaining fixtures have in store? All these questions and more will be answered tomorrow as the Bunyoro Zonal Secondary School Ball Games II continue to captivate fans and spectators alike.

post.Title: Uganda miss out on ISF quarter finals by goal difference
post.Content:
Uganda's boys' and girls' basketball teams have been eliminated from the quarterfinals at the ISF World Schools Basketball Championship in Macao, China.

The girls' team lost 51-26 to France, finishing last in Group C without a win. The boys' team narrowly lost 60-58 to unbeaten Serbia, missing out on the quarterfinals by a single point in goal difference.

Despite their efforts, both teams will now play in classification games to determine their final rankings.

The boys will face Czech Republic tomorrow morning at 6:45 AM EAT while the girls will take on India at 5:00 AM EAT.

Coach Johnathan Egau with the technical team during the boys game vs Serbia |ISF Image

The tournament has been a valuable experience for the young Ugandan players, who have shown great potential and determination on the court. Although their medal hopes have been dashed, they will return home with their heads held high and a wealth of experience to build on for future competitions.

Coach Johnathan Egau, Teams Coach.

post.Title: USSSA MUKONO ZONE QUALIFIERS: Five Girls' teams out for slot to represent Mukono in Teso.
post.Content:
Overview

Boys' and girls' football for the Under 16 category kicked off on 29th June in Mukono zone qualifiers. A total of 5 girls football teams are vying for one spot at the National Ball Games 2.

Girls' Football U-16 Matchday results

  • Mukono Kings High School 0-2 Lugazi Homestone
  • St. John's High School 3-0 St. Mary's College Lugazi
  • Lord's Meade 0-10 Mukono Kings High School
    •Lugazi Homestone 1-1 St. John's High School
  • St. Mary's College Lugazi 2-2 Lord's Meade

The 5 Girls' Football teams played in round robin format. With the teams totalling to 5, a minimum of ten matches will be played before the champion Mukono zone can be determined.

Matchday 1 played at Kikube C/U saw a total of 21 goals scored in 5 matches.

Mukono Kings High School made a statement victory in their second game of the day as they beat 10-0 Lord's Meade SS despite an underwhelming start in the opening fixture.

Action resumes on Sunday 30th for the remaining 5 games.

U16-GIRLS-FOOTBALL-MUKONO-ZONE-FIXTURE-1Download

post.Title: Ball Games II: Schools Of Kampala Zone Secure Slots
post.Content:
Kibuli S.S, the host school excelled on their home grounds, winning gold medals in U16 Boys Football(boys), Handball (girls) and Volleyball (boys), and silver in other categories.


Nabisunsa Girls' School dominated the girls' basketball category, emerging as champions. Mariam High School impressed in Volleyball, clinching the girls' title, while Kibuli S.S secured the boys' title.

Meanwhile, Kawempe Muslim S.S, the fresh dairy champions, cemented their position by winning the girls' football title once again, taking home the U16 Girls Football trophy.


St. Andrew Kaggwa S.S Gombe showcased their mastery of mind games, topping in Chess in both boys and girls categories. Caltec Academy took silver in Chess.

The overall results were as follows:

  • Chess Boys: St. Andrew Kaggwa S.S Gombe (1st), Caltec Academy (2nd)
  • Chess Girls: St. Andrew Kaggwa S.S Gombe (1st), Caltec Academy (2nd)
  • Handball Boys: Lubiri S.S (1st), Kakungulu Memorial School (2nd)
  • Handball Girls: Kibuli S.S (1st), Mbogo H/S (2nd)
  • Netball: Baptist H/S (1st), Kibuli S.S (2nd)
  • Football U16 Boys: Kibuli S.S (1st), St. Janan School Kabalagala (2nd)
  • Football U16 Girls: Kawempe Muslim S.S (1st), Highland H/S Kisaasi (2nd)
  • Volleyball Boys: Kibuli S.S (1st), St. Peter's Nsambya (2nd)
  • Volleyball Girls: Mariam H/S (1st), Nabisunsa Girls' School (2nd)
  • Basketball 3x3 Boys: Kibuli S.S (1st), Mengo S.S (2nd)
  • Basketball 3x3 Girls: Nabisunsa Girls' School (1st)
  • Kibuli S.S (2nd)

post.Title: USSSA ZONAL QUALIFIERS: Quest to represent Teso into the last four
post.Content:
Results
Bukedea Comprehensive School 2:0 Atutur
Nyero Rock 2:0 Serere SSS
Amus College School 2:0 St. Thereza
Ngora High school 2:0 Wiggins SS

Semi - Finals
Bukedea Comprehensive School Vs Nyero Rock

Amus College School Vs Ngora High school

Bukedea Comprehensive School , Nyero Rock,Amus College School and Ngora High school secured their spots in the semi-finals after winning their games respectively at the Teso Zonal Qualifiers of Volleyball taking place at Serere SSS - Serere district.

Bukedea Comprehensive School 2:0 win against Atutur showed a green light to the next level .
In the group stage Bukedea Comprehensive School tightned the muscle winning all the games in the group that hard Kamod SS and Wiggins SS.

The good blocks, spikes and services made the team more tactical and technical.

Bukedea Comprehensive School will now face Nyero Rock SS in the last four with the side eliminating Serere district ’s Serere SSS 2-0.

Amus College School who also come from Bukedea district will battle it out with Ngora High school volleyball team that defeated St.Thereza at the quarter finals of Teso Zone 2:0 straight.

The finalists will represent Teso Zone at the National ball games II hosted by the same Zone at Teso College Aleot.

post.Title: ISF World Schools Basketball Championship: Shifrah, Abigail Shines As Uganda Brutals India In The First Classification Match
post.Content:
Having failed to advance to quarter finals , the girls regrouped and registered their first win against India in the first classification game played today morning.

Match Statistics

  • India 2-19 Uganda
  • India 0-15 Uganda
  • India 4-29 Uganda
  • India 10-25 Uganda

After failing to advance to the quarterfinals, Uganda's girls' basketball team delivered a resounding performance, crushing India 88-16!

Shifrah Kiranda and Abigail Mpoza Lucy were the stars of the show, scoring 18 and 13 points respectively. The Ugandan team was on fire, dominating all four quarters with their impressive defense and offense.

Abigail Lucy Mpoza in action against Chinese Taipei| ISF Image

The match saw Uganda take a commanding lead of 19-2 in the first quarter, which they further extended to 34-2 by the second quarter. India struggled to find their footing, trailing 63-6 by the end of the third quarter. The final quarter saw Uganda seal the deal with a 25-10 win.

Shifrah's 18 points and Abigail's 13 points were the highlights of the game, showcasing their commitment ,skills, talent, and team work.

Shifrah Kiranda in action in one of the games | ISF Image

Uganda returns on court on Tuesday for its final championship game.
